story:
After 9 years of training I need your help!


Help me fund 1 year of dance training.


Supplies needed for the year:

10 pairs of pointe shoes (pointe shoes, ribbons, elastics)

24 pairs of convertible dance tights

12 black leotards 

Tuition

Dance clothing


**Please note that we have 2 campaigns running with the same end date. We learned about "go go  factor" a little late. All funds raised support Coral's ballet training should it exceed the $5,000 goal for one year of training those funds would go toward attending a summer dance intensive. The summer intensive is completely secondary, the goal is to keep Coral dancing in this next very uncertain year. 


Who is Coral?:

                            

           

                            Coral backstage at her first dance recital (age 3)

               

                 Coral celebrating her teacher's birthday- John Grensback      (center- NYC Ballet, Joffrey Ballet, and Principal- Houston Ballet)

                                

 

The need:

One year of dance training:

100% of funds received will go directly to support my dance training during the next year.                                       

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can’t contribute, but that doesn’t mean they can’t help:

  • Get the word out and make some noise about my campaign. Share what a  great gift this is for the holiday season.
  • Encourage others to make a difference by giving the gift of dance. The perfect gift for anyone on your holiday list, especially dancers or dance enthusiasts in your life!
  • Put my campaign on your Christmas list! Let family and friends know that you would love to receive a donation made in your name to my campaign!
  • SHARE THIS CAMPAIGN! Remember to use the Indiegogo share tools to share the Give Dance campaign on your social media sites.

And that’s all there is to it. Change the life of this dancer one gift at a time. Feel good about it, and let others know that they can do it too. GIVE DANCE!


Your gift matters!

story:
Un résumé du spectacle ?

Fêter ses 50 ans c'est avoir une nouvelle étiquette : senior !

En 1950 cette étiquette signifiait attendre la retraite, puis une fois à la retraite attendre la mort. 

Aujourd'hui, à 50 ans on cherche un nouvel amour, une nouvelle maison, un nouveau boulot, un nouveau voyage à faire ou un nouveau sport mais une chose est certaine : on n'attend plus que le temps passe !

Matisse disait : "on ne peut s'empêcher de vieillir, mais on peut s'empêcher de devenir vieux" 

Tous les plus de 50 ans l'ont bien compris et semblent l'appliquer chaque jour. Ils en donneraient des complexes aux plus jeunes ! 

Après des dizaines d'années à vouloir être de plus en plus jeunes, si le but ultime n'était pas de vieillir de mieux en mieux ? 

Venez voyager dans le temps de 1900 à nos jours, vous remémorer de bons souvenirs ou découvrir un monde qui semble si lointain tout en étant si proche. Plus que jamais le temps ne compte plus, votre âge n'est plus déterminé par votre date de naissance mais par la façon dont vous vivez. 

Petits ou grands vivez un moment drôle et tendre, qui vous permettra de répondre à la question : à quel âge es-tu né ?

Qui a le plus de chance ? 

La jeune fille des années 50 

Ou celle des années 2010 ?

Il faudra sans doute plus d'une heure trente pour faire le tour du siècle mais il promet de bonnes surprises.

Qui fait partie de l'équipe de ce spectacle ?

Moi ! Pour le moment toute seule sur scène, un rien abandonnée et soutenue par mes deux filleuls qui ont tout donné pour la photo de l'affiche, parce qu'il n'y a pas à dire : "Marraine a quand même un job bizarre ! Surtout qu'elle nous saoule depuis qu'on est dans le ventre de nos mères avec ce spectacle, 5 ans qu'elle prépare ça ! Pitié aidez-la ou tuez-la mais faites la taire !"

Une équipe technique et de diffusion : 

Avec dans le désordre : une chargée de diffusion et de communication, un régisseur, un co-auteur, une créatrice de costume, un guitariste (oui je ne suis pas totalement seule sur scène) et :

Un metteur en scène :  

Pour le moment je l'imagine : grand, blond, les yeux bleus... Ah non ! Pardon ça c'est pour le mec idéal... Si par hasard vous avez ça en plus contactez-moi...

La collecte servira à financer son salaire (que j'espère minime) et si vous êtes tous très généreux (bon très très très) mon idéal s'appelle Nicolas Briançon... Oui mon rêve pour un "seule en scène" avec un budget minime c'est un mec qui monte des spectacles avec 30 personnes sur scène et le fric qui va avec. Il faut savoir rêver quand on fait ce métier. Mais qui sait ? Là encore vous avez peut-être ça dans vos bagages ?  

En tous cas si vous avez envie de vous impliquer dans le spectacle à quelque niveau que ce soit n'hésitez pas à me le faire savoir, je sens qu'on peux se marrer et c'est bien l'essentiel !

A quoi servira la collecte ?

La collecte de dons actuelle servira à compléter le budget (nous avons déjà collecté 8878 euros) pour plusieurs choses et permettre ainsi à 7 intermittents du spectacle de vivre pendant deux ans.

- Faire refaire l'affiche en se basant sur les premières critiques formulées.

- Payer un metteur en scène (oui tout travail mérite salaire)

- Payer les frais pour Avignon 2014 (théâtre, logement, affiches, flyers, déplacements et tout le toutim)

- Payer les frais des représentations à caractère  "social". J'ai choisi de jouer le spectacle pour des associations du 3ème âge qui n'ont pas vraiment les moyens de se payer ce luxe. Nous avons déjà reçu plus d'une quarantaine de demandes auxquelles nous aimerions pouvoir répondre positivement malgré des budgets moyens aux alentours de 100 euros (ce qui n'est souvent pas assez pour le déplacement).

- Payer les frais du Festival d'Aurillac (logement, affiches, flyers, déplacement etc etc)

- Payer le début d'une programmation parisienne avec une fois encore des affiches, flyers and co.

Voilà pourquoi chaque euro, même au-delà du montant de la collecte est important !

story:
Help us raise awareness of breast cancer issues through Your Disco Needs You - The Musical.

Target: £28,000
Deadline: 9th May 2014

Summary

Neet Neilson is a Breast Cancer Survivor. She has made it her mission in life to promote breast cancer awareness by any means possible.  Having always been a Kylie fan, who also went through breast cancer treatments at the same time her, Neet was inspired by her music as she exercised through treatments. Exercise helped Neet feel normal and immensely better.  Research shows that exercise is good for you before, during and after breast cancer but this message is not being embraced by patients. Neet feels passionately about this subject, so much so that she wrote a musical using the music of Kylie to share a motivational, feel good story to inspire people to exercise through their treatments, promote breast awareness and raise funds for the 3 cancer charities close to her heart.  There will be 5 performances between the 24-26th October 2014 to coincide with Breast Cancer Awareness Month, staged at the Mitchell Theatre, Glasgow, UK.

Your Disco Needs You - The Musical is set around the struggles of ordinary people united in a mission to save a local dance studio hit by recession.  The main characters come to the dance class to escape their own personal dilemmas but find their problems being resolved through new friends and relationships made at the class. The audience is brought into the story as each of the character’s drama unfolds; triggering the viewer’s emotions along in tandem with the characters experiences. 

Your Disco Needs You - The Musical  will make you laugh, cry, and laugh again while the characters triumph over their issues as they work together to establish new found confidences, hold on to self-respect, and find love with the help of their family and fellow dancers to achieve their united mission. Although the script touches on such sober subjects such as relationship problems and cancer, the musical is delightfully witty, honest, and uplifting. This musical gives you everything you would ask for in musical theatre. Expect comedy, romance and sadness, with a feel good ending. It will put a smile on your face and leave you genuinely satisfied and wanting more.

The story is told through the songs of Kylie Minogue which makes it a must see for all fans. Even those who haven’t succumbed to the charms of Kylie’s music (yet) will be entertained, moved and unable to resist singing and tapping along. Expect comedy, romance and sadness, with a feel good ending.  This musical gives you everything you would ask for in musical theatre.

The YDNY script has been positively reviewed by many musical theatre professionals with the advice that it NEEDED to be showcased as it was "meant for the stage".  It has been workshopped to perfection by theatre professionals and it is now ready for the next big step.

The AMAZING Tim Noble choreographer to the stars, and to Kylie herself, said he "would love to help us" with this project and will choreograph the dances for OUR musical! How AWESOME is that?

Why we need YOUR support

To stage this inspiring musical we would love your help to raise enough for the productions costs and hire of the theatre. This means we can give all the profit from ticket sales to 3 cancer charities. 

What we need to raise:

To ensure Your Disco Needs You - The Musical  is the success it is envisaged to be, we need to hire the theatre, enlist a choreographer, musical director and director as well as hire rehearsal space, none of which come for free. We also need to fund programme printing, leaflet printing, main actors, audio visual requirements, costumes and props, all of which cost money. We estimate it will cost £28,000 to stage 5 performances and rehearse for 3 months. We hope the ticket sales will generate approximately £40,000 which we would divide amongst the 3 cancer charities. Half will be equally shared between the 2 big charities Macmillan Cancer and Breakthrough Breast Cancer. The other half will go to MBrace - a 12 week exercise programme designed specifically for breast cancer patients which operates within the Greater Glasgow and Clyde Health Board. The programme is run entirely from donations and is in desperate need of funding to continue; it is a popular programme and already has a waiting list of patients.

Our dream is that by showcasing this musical, professional producers will want to stage it elsewhere on the condition that they donate a generous portion of the profits to cancer charities. The more we can raise, the more professional a performance we can stage and the bigger the opportunity for professional producers wanting it for bigger theatres.  Broadway, Movie – who knows? You can always say you were part of something BIG and WORTHWHILE!

Giving it back to YOU:

If you choose to help us, you will have the joy of knowing that through this production you are not only contributing to 3 very worthy charities but also raising the profile of breast cancer awareness in a very unique and different way. 

We want to provide you, our sponsors, with some unique rewards as a way of saying thanks. Rewards range from our heart-felt gratitude to some major unique limited prizes.  Rewards are linked to sponsorship of a number of different amount from £5 - £5,000. You can also make contributions of as small as £1 or $1.  Contributions can be made through PayPal, Debit or Credit Card. Every little amount counts, no matter how small. All contributions are gratefully received. 

Perks:

We want to offer you some unique rewards from our deepest gratitude to major unique limited prizes.  There is a selection of amounts from £5 to £5000. There is something for everyone here. 

Impact:

Your sponsorship WILL help RAISE AWARENESS and SAVE LIVES through generation of publicity via the Musical.  

All literature associated with the musical will have links to cancer sites informing and raising awareness. All programmes will have information about cancer awareness issues and links for further help and advice.  The website for the musical will also have links to self checks, gene testing information, exercise information and awareness issues.

Macmillan Cancer Information Services will attend all performances and a Breast Cancer Nurse Specialist will be available for advice before, after the show and intervals. Self check demonstrations [on plastic inflated boobs] will also be done at the intervals.

Our ultimate goal is for it to become a charity in its own right!

Other Ways You Can Help:

We recognise that not everyone can afford to sponsor our cause. For those of you who fall in to this category, perhaps you will consider helping us by spreading the word and sharing this link to others via email, Facebook or Twitter.  Spreading the message amongst family and friends is just as important as assisting with funding. Use the Indiegogo share tools at the bottom of this page and start spreading the word. 

Check out our website to keep updated and learn more about our cause www.ydny-musical.com

Follow us on Facebook, Twitter, and Vimeo, Thanks!


Performances: Mitchell Theatre Glasgow 

Friday 24th October 2014 - 7pm evening performance

Saturday 25th October 2014 -  2pm matinee performance

Saturday 25th October 2014 - 7pm evening performance

Sunday 26th October 2014 - 2pm matinee performance

Sunday 26th October 2014 -  7pm evening performance

story:
HELP PRODUCE A MIRACLE!

June - August, Los Angeles, 2014

The World Premier of the musical Visionary Man (formerly Hands of the Spirit) in Los Angeles 2014 is a large undertaking. WE NEED YOUR HELP!  Please help us produce a miracle. Make your contribution today. 

THE PROJECT: Hands of the Spirit – LA 2014 is an artist & community sponsored project dedicated to developing the original stage musical Visionary Man by Mary Padgelek & Tom Coleman. Visionary Man is a work developed over several years by a team of Georgia musical theater and visual arts professionals. It is the real-life account of the outsider artist J.B. Murray and his call by the spirit to create “paintings and script.” It is a story of friendship, art, and redemption; of creativity and controversy; of passion, vision, and the miraculous.

THE FACTS: In 1978 a seventy-year-old African American subsistence farmer in rural Glascock County, Georgia, received what he believed to be a call from God. Though unable to read or write, J. B. Murray began to draw and paint flowing abstractions under what he understood to be the inspiration of the Holy Spirit. 

Murray created paintings of ghostly figures and elongated shapes swimming in words and texts legible only to Murray himself. Murray would often read his work by viewing his text through a glass of divine water.  By the time of his death in 1988, Murray's work had been shown in art galleries all over the world: from Atlanta, Washington, D.C., New York, and Los Angeles to London and Tokyo.Today, Murray’s work remains highly sought after internationally by major museums and private collectors. 

OUR GOAL: If you decide to contribute, you will be helping to stage an original musical that we hope will have great significance in the world of theater, art and dance. Our goal is to produce the World Premier in Los Angeles with the ultimate goal of staging the off-Broadway debut in New York, 2015. Please join us and come along for the ride!

Spirited Hands Productions is grateful for the fiscal sponsorship of Fractured Atlas, NYC.

story:
Welcome to the newest collaboration by trend-setting author Nancy Stohlman and internationally known musician/composer Nick Busheff. The Monster Opera defies description on many levels. First written as a flash novel by Stohlman, The Monster Opera is now being adapted for the theater.  With your help, the book and musical production will be premiered at one of Denver's most popular venues, The Mercury Cafe on October 4, 2013.

THE STORY:  A writer travels to Mexico City in search of a new story...but the monsters are already waiting for her. The more she writes, the more their whereabouts, as well as their desperation, are revealed. The Monster Opera is a gothic literary noir, a genre-bending novel-meets-libretto that combines recitative with dialogue, aria with prose, and ultimately asks the question: Who owns a story? The Monster Opera is a multi-genre extravaganza and the second flash novel available from Bartleby Snopes Press.

THE PRODUCTION:  Fans of opera, musical theater and the classic stage will love The Monster Opera.  This multi-genre extravaganza features the best of Colorado's talent.  From experienced operatic singers, actors and musicians to behind the scenes costume and stage designers, this will prove to be an unforgettable evening.

THE MUSIC:  Using sources both ancient and avante-garde, Nick Busheff's original score brings to life what has been described as "a rising crescendo of action in a haunting tale of love."   Legendary composer George Crumb was influential in Busheff's career and has given permission to use a graphic from his composition "Spiral Galaxy" for the cover of the novel. 

HISTORY: The first act of the Monster Opera was produced in April of 2011 and received rave reviews from a capacity crowd.  Check out actual footage in the book trailer above.

REVIEWS:

"The Monster Opera is a brilliant and beautiful work, a rising crescendo of action in a haunting tale of love. Many authors strive for that perfect note, yet Stohlman does the unbelievable, turning words on the page into a truly operatic monster which comes alive in the very first scene."

--J.A. Kazimer, author of Dopesick: A Love Story and Shank

"At one point I found myself pledging my life and allegiance like an old Camelot knight to the life and the legacy of the Opera. If a dragon were to threaten it for some dragon reason, I would've totally put down this pint of whiskey and slain it. Because this Opera must live on! Its safety is more important than my own."

--Rob Geisen, author of The Aftermath, Etc.

"In a swell of lyrical prose that drips itself across the borders of music and literature, Nancy Stohlman delivers a self-aware story that sings out from the page like an opera trapped in the belly of an Old World curse. A love affair drunk on magical realism, somehow as ancient as it is avant-garde. "

--Kona Morris, author of Godless Comics

WHAT WE NEED:  In order to put on the full production of The Monster Opera we need your help in funding the project.  We believe in paying our cast and production team what we can based on fund-raising and ticket sales.  Our goal of $1000 by October 4 will be used as payment for:

 8 actors/singers

4 musicians/sound personnel

2 directors

costumes/props

venue rental

videographer

promotional materials

Obviously with such a large production we would love to exceed our goal to offset the tremendous amount of time and energy our team has put in.  For most of us this is a labor of love but many are sacrificing work and spare time to be a part of this unique project.

THE FUTURE:  We hope The Monster Opera will be recognized as a pioneer in the world of multi-genre creations.  Nancy Stohlman and Nick Busheff are known for creating unique performances combining elements of story, music, history, art, film, dance and special effects.  They have created and directed such theatrical productions as The Wilderness (spiritual theater), Brecht on Brecht (Kurt Weill), The F-Bomb series (flash fiction) and Kinky Mink (lounge-metal band). 

We would like to put on more productions of The Monster Opera in cities nationwide and are considering adapting it as a screenplay.

YOU'RE INVITED:  We would love to see you at the  October 4th performance but if you can't make it you can still contribute to our effort.  Check out the perks we have for you based on funding amounts and we would greatly appreciated getting the word out via social media, the Indiegogo share tools or any other way in which you are comfortable.  (FOR GROUP DISCOUNT RATES Contact: nickbusheff@gmail.com)

Thanks so much for your consideration and we would LOVE to have you help us bring our MONSTER to life!!

http://nancystohlman.com/monsteropera/

story:
Hi Everybody!

My name is Omer Lavie, I am a 17-year-old dancer, a proud gay, originally from the north of Israel.

When I was 14, I fell in love with theatre dance, and started working very hard in order to succeed in this world, which I found enchanting. My passion and devotion to dance have led me to Thelma Yellin High School of the Art, which I was good enough to be accepted to.

And so, at the age of 15, I found myself leave my home, family and friends in northern Israel to a rented apartment next to Tel Aviv – just like a mature student.

Upon arriving to my new school, I met Shaked, a most charming person, who helped me to be absorbed in my new surroundings. Shaked is a year and a half older than me, and just like me, he is a dancer who left his home to a rented apartment near Tel Aviv.

As time went by, we both fell deeply in love, and our relationship started blossoming. We both are extremely grateful for having each other's love, which grew stronger and stronger in the recent year.

We have learned together, danced together, and as time went by – we moved in together. Living together only strengthened our relationship and love. We are everything for each other.

Approximately six months ago, Shaked got a scholarship to study at The Academy Ballet of Washington, a once in a lifetime opportunity. Four months ago he left to DC, yet we never gave up our love, and although all the difficulties there are in a long distance relationship, we know we can make through all of them. There is nothing that can defeat our unbreakable love.

I miss my boyfriend a lot, and really want to visit him in Washington. Unfortunately, the expensive tuition fee and rent is a heavy burden on my parents, and they can't help me with financing a flight ticket (approximately $1,700). As I study every day from 8am to 9pm, I can't find any time to work, in order to save the needed money. Shaked doesn't have a working visa, so he also can't work.

Of course, our love is strong enough, even if we will see each other only in one year. But please, help us making this precious dream come true, help us raise the money for a flight ticket, so we could meet each other this year, even if it's for a short period. Please help us ease, even slightly, on our longings.

We shall never forget you, and will always be thankful for your kindness.

Yours Sincerely, Omer

story:
The Idea

At the age of fifteen, I was out of school due to severe mental health problems, and with a lot of time on my hands and a lot of teenage angst in my heart, I decided to write a Catcher-in-the-Rye-style story about what happens to people who get lost in the school system.  A few months later, I had written Winter of Our Discotheque, a play which has since been described as "St Trinians crossed with Lord of the Flies". 

Putting on a play when you're fifteen is very difficult, so while I kept on trying, unreliable teenage actors and lack of funds kept letting me down.
Then, years later at university, I met the redoubtable Laura, and we decided that with her as producer and me as director, we could put the play on a professional stage, and Tambourgi Productions was born.
After a small but well-received run, we are now taking this same play up to the Edinburgh Fringe 2014!  Winter of Our Discotheque explores the fringes of teenage society, and the isolation of mental illness in children, and asks what we can do to help troubled friends when our best intentions just aren't enough.
The actors are cast, the theatre is booked, the poster is designed, and we have been running fundraisers all year.  As a group aged between 19-22, we have very little money to back this ourselves, but we are working tirelessly to make this happen, for the great difference it could make in our careers and to get our best work out there for hundreds of people to see.
Where is the money going?
Of course, the ultimate goal of our campaign is to stage a piece of work that we love, and we think you will too!  Here's what your contributions will be going towards...
  • £2100 for the hire of the theatre (this is actually a very good deal for Edinburgh!)
  • £200 to build a set, complete with beds and costumes
  • £100 for transport of set from York to Edinburgh
  • £195 for 10,000 flyers so we can pull in as many crowds as possible

Why should you donate?

Did you know that the Edinburgh Festival Fringe is the biggest platform for theatre in the world?  Theatre is often a difficult business to get into if you don't come from a wealthy background, so this is a unique opportunity for many of the young people on our team to showcase their outstanding talent.  
And we aren't just relying on your generosity.  This year we have held fundraisers including:
CELIA - a Latin club night
HEROES - a David Bowie club night
UNISEX - a play
Weathering Lows - a play
Soccatui - an accoustic night
But we are still only 2/3 of the way to our goal, and to make this happen (without financially crippling us!) we really do need your help.  Any amount would be greatly appreciated, and we understand that some people simply don't have the means to contribute - if this is you, but you still want to help our cause, we would really appreciate you sharing this campaign around your friends and social media pages.  
Thank you very much for your time.
Love,
Tambourgi Productions

story:
Short Summary

ESA's award-winning Show Choirs SPLASH and GLO wish to compete this year in NYC's Fame Show Choir Competition and Show Choir Canada with a full stage band, which will help them become even better than they already are.  

What We Need & What You Get

Travelling with a stage band of approximately 12 performers requires extra money in the show choir budget, to help off-set the expensive travelling budget, re-arranging orchestrations for both choirs, the extra cost of purchasing orchestral arrangements, and supplementing the band with a few professional players for mentoring.

We will provide you with the PERK of free tickets to our performances this year at ESA.  

    The Impact

    For the past two years, Indiegogo has helped Splash reach their goals of purchasing new show choir risers, which both choirs have benefited from and last year, many students had their trip to Chicago's Fame competition supplemented, which allowed for the whole choir to participate.  This year, both show choirs will be featured in our musical revue of SWING at ESA!  Exciting new opportunities lie ahead for these two groups.  The impact of performing with a live band is going to bring both choirs to new levels of success!

      Other Ways You Can Help

      We understand if you are not in a position to help.  Please help this campaign by sharing the link with as many people as you can.  Adding a personal plea for help will make the request even more successful.  Sharing on social media sites can be very encouraging for the campaign!

story:
THIS YEAR'S EXPERIMENT

theLAB is always primarily focused on artists of color, but each performance will have its own unique theme. This year, theLAB presents Experiment A: Color Stories, where we will be showing works by Beatrice Capote, Antonio Brown Dance, Shay Bland, Ma'atworks Dance Collective, and SGalberth.  

 

WHAT TYPE OF WORK WILL I SEE?

No matter what your preferences are, there’s something for every audience member here! Expect to see a diverse mix of contemporary dance, performance art, media, and more. No two artists are alike, and we encourage our collaborators to be as authentic and innovative as possible.

 

WHERE AND HOW MUCH ARE TICKETS?

The show will be at the County Prep Theater,  525 Montgomery Street, Jersey City, NJ, which is just a twenty minute walk from the Journal Square PATH station. Tickets are $17 online and $18 at the door. Your program will be your ticket to be mindful of the environment. 

 

HOW WILL MY DONATION BE USED?

Donations will be used to offset the cost of costumes/props, rehearsal space and artist stipends. Paying artists for their hard work is our TOP PRIORITY, and we want everyone to feel appreciated throughout this process. 

 

WHAT WE HAVE:

  • Dancers
  • Performance Venue (County Prep Theater)
  • Rehearsal Space
  • Projector
  • Lighting
  • Security for Performance
  • Marketing Manager
  • Video Editor
  • Ushers
  • House Manager

 

WHAT WE NEED:

  • Costumes & Materials
  • Dancer & Choreographer Pay
  • Props
  • Programs
  • Flyers/Postcards
  • Promo Photoshoot
  • Online Advertisements
  • Lighting & Sound Designer
  • Theater Technician
  • Stage Manager
  • Administrative Assistant
  • Box Office Manager
  • Videographer
  • House Manager

 

WHO IS PART OF THE LAB?

theLAB was founded by SGalberth, a New Jersey-based dancer and choreographer from Washington, D.C. Our team consists of Stephen Galberth (Artistic Director), Malcolm McMichael (Media Consultant & Administrator), and Tiara Knox (Marketing & Administrative Support).

 

WHO IS SGalberth?

SGalberth is a shortened name for theLAB’s Artistic Director, Stephen Galberth. He's a dancer and choreographer based in Jersey City, N.J. In 2016, he graduated with a BFA in Dance from Montclair State University. SGalberth has presented work at Dixon Place, Triskelion Arts, SMUSH Moves Vol 4., and Love Is The Message, and was the second runner up in the American College Dance Association to perform his piece "M-A-RGIN" at the Kennedy Center. He has most recently performed works by Nathan Trice Rituals, Kinesis Project, Antonio Brown Dance, and 277 Dance Project.

story:
I wrote this play on a plane to Chicago in 2016.  I wrote it as an ode to my friends and fellow artists.  I wrote it as an offering to the art community.  I wrote it as a letter to myself.  Writing a full length play and producing it has been a dream of mine since I started theater in 3rd grade.  I am fortunate enough to have an immensely supportive group of friends who share my passions, and together Sophie Falvey, Catherine Horowitz, Sophia Varnia and I formed Purple Crayon Productions.  We performed our first show, Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead, in April 2017, and in January of 2018 performed Love and Information.  Producing at 17 and 18 years old is exhausting and stressful, but I've never felt more fulfilled in my life.  

Producing is expensive, and as high schoolers we don't have a massive amount of funds.  Our first production was produced with a budget of little more than $1000 all of which was crowdfunded.  Our goal is to make theater accessible and therefore, purposefully price tickets at an affordable price, but that means we don't make a massive amount of money after ticket sales.  Donating to this campaign would help our company pay for the insurance and participation fees we are required to pay to participate in the fringe festival, as well as set pieces, and costumes.  

 

The past two Purple Crayon Production shows have been huge successes, although they were performed for a short time span and audiences were intimate, that's what made the shows so memorable.  Most of all we want to tell our a story, whether that audience is 50 people, or 5.  Help support young artists, a help us tell our audience a new story.

We understand that not everyone can contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help with this production:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about the show and the campaign
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Come see the performance:

Saturday 7/14 @ 1:30 PM, Sunday 7/15 @ 8:15 PM, Sunday 7/22 @ 4:00 PM, Saturday 7/28 @ 7:45 PM, Sunday 7/29 @ 2:30 PM

At the Westinster Church

400 I (eye) Street SW,

Washington DC 20024

story:
Overview:

Drapinski Dance Company is a newly found contemporary dance company in Orlando Florida that is trying their best to provide a platform for concert dance in the Orlando area through a show series called “The Catharsis Series.” This Series brings in magnificent artists from all over to showcase new works all for the purpose of raising money for a grant foundation called The ARTSHIELD Foundation. The goal for the Series to grant funds for all participating artists in the event, but in order to do that, we need your help!

We had our first Catharsis Series last June and it was received extremely well, to the point where we went from 9 independent artists and organizations performing to 18. Drapinski Dance Company is extremely happy the series has grown so quickly but having more artists performing in the series means needing longer rental time which equals more money.

 

About The Catharsis Series:

The Catharsis Series is an event designed to provide an opportunity for visual and performing artists in concert dance to reveal what’s hiding behind their metaphorical masks. The goal is to allow artists to purge through art in a protected setting. Catharsis is the process of releasing strong, repressed emotions, and this event strives to find artists who do just that. There is no limit of topic to this series; we promote to speak your truth, whatever that might be. We encourage educational concepts directed towards our audience, to inspire and engage the Orlando arts community. This event is not a popularity contest or a time to flaunt talent; this event is a time to showcase artistic creations that come from the heart, mind, and soul.

The proceeds of this series directly entrusts to our grant program called the ARTSHIELD Foundation. The end objective for the artists involved in the Catharsis Series is to receive a commission from profit that awards them for their participation, as well as funds their organization and impending projects. We want visual and performing artists to continue to create imaginative and aesthetic masterpieces for the Orlando community, and we understand that organizations, dance studios, and independent artists need finances to make those come to life.

 

About The ARTSHIELD Foundation:

                The ARTSHIELD Foundation was established in 2018 to support emerging visual and performing artists in the United States of America. The foundation was formed to provide funding for artists that believe in protecting the visual and performing art form in concert dance by engaging and inspiring their participating audiences within their projects. Artists are encouraged to continue to discover imaginative material and new approaches to the creative process by communicating through art. The foundation strives to continue properly demonstrating the definition of art by financing individual artists, projects, and students’ education in visual and performing arts that plan to validate similar sentiments. We do not put limits to how the funds granted are to be used; but we do ask that the finances that are granted be used for the better of a community by producing a variety of material that will broaden minds of not only your audiences but your participating artists as well.

 

The Impact:

It is crucial to provide creative opportunity in concert dance for artists and students in Orlando Florida, due to the community being extremely industrialized in entertainment. An artistically diverse community not only feeds the artists but provides educational, thought provoking, and eye engaging material for the audiences in the area. Due to Orlando being a state heavy with entertainment, we must strive as a community to broaden those designated limits and fund art in other ways such as this.
 

What We Need:

 We are looking to raise $5,000.00 to cover the cost of the venue and Drapinski Dance Company (DDC) plans on covering the rest of the expenses. This may seem like a lot and honestly it is. DDC has chosen a magnificent theater space to give the participating performers an opportunity to perform in an established professional setting. The $5,000.00 not only covers the venue rental but also a lighting and music technician, janitorial and security staff, programs and advertisement of the event, water and fuel for the performers and more .

 

Other Way You Can Help:

                Please do everything in your power to let people know about The Catharsis Series and The ARTSHIELD Foundation. Our next Catharsis Series takes place on January 12, 2020 at 8:00PM and then we will have another early June of 2020. You can purchase tickets starting December 1, 2019 on our website which is listed below.

 

Read more about Drapinski Dance Company, The Catharsis Series, & The ARTSHIELD Foundation at our website:

WWW.DRAPINSKIDANCE.COM

Like us on Facebook:

WWW.FACEBOOK.COM/DRAPINSKIDANCE

Follow us on Instagram and Twitter:

@DRAPINSKIDANCE

Watch our dances on YouTube:

https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCsQ2LB16mPcB41...

story:
My name is Perlizbeth De Leon and I am a choreographer and artist based out of Atlanta, GA. My style is a unique fusion of hip hop, contemporary, jazz, popping, house, and waacking. I am slowly finding my own community of dancers here in Atlanta.

(In terms of COVID-19, we will be properly masked during rehearsals and during filming. At no point in time, except to consume water and food, will we remove our masks.)

This project: "Us" uses the song "Us" by Ruby Ibarra, Rocky Rivera, Klassy, and Faith Santilla in it's entirety, creating something akin to a music video. This video concept seeks to do the following:

  • Empower mga pinay everywhere.
  • Inspire people to seek their own culture and roots.
  • Cultivate the pinay dance community in Atlanta, GA.

Budgeting Needs

  • Compensation for eight dancers for their talent and hard work.
  • Studio rental for rehearsals for the entire month of October.
  • Costuming for four different shots and three different styles of dance: contemporary, hip hop, and heels.
  • Compensation for videographer, production, and editing team.

Donor Benefits

  • Inside look into creative process and rehearsals. You get to see exactly what you're funding and actual progress of the video project.
  • Access to behind the scenes footage of interviews, teasers, snippets of footage.
  • If we don't reach our goal, I will be cutting some shots and costuming and paying dancers slightly less for their time.

The Impact

I tried my hardest to find every female Filipino dancer in Atlanta and came up with nine dancers, including myself. 

  • Cultivating a presence for mga Pinay and the community around us.
  • Creating cultural awareness for those who may not know about Filipino culture.
  • Giving Pinay dancers a voice to express.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share this campaign! Ask others who may be able to help.
  • Shout our project out on your personal social media.
  • Send us some words of encouragement. (:

story:
OUR MISSION STATEMENT 

The Black Ensemble Players seeks to empower black artists and the black community by fostering black representation in the theatre.

  • OUR STORY

    The impulse to form The Black Ensemble Players came from a lack of black representation in the Twin Cities theatre community as it pertains to Shakespearean productions. We strive to hold a space for black creatives to explore their artistic expression with classical texts on their own cultural and historical terms. TOPDOG/UNDERDOG by Suzan Lori Parks is a classical piece of theatre within the black dramatic canon.

    We will make our company's second production with Suzan Lori Parks TOPDOG/UNDERDOG. This epic tale of brotherhood will be directed by the brilliant H. Adam Harris. 

H. Adam Harris is an actor, director, teaching artist, and cultural equity consultant. He works at the intersection of theatre, education, social justice, and community engagement. Recent theatrical credits include puppeteering and voicing the title role of Dr. Seuss’ The Lorax in the U.S premiere at the Children’s Theatre Company (CTC) and The Old Globe Theatre. He’s a frequent performer with CTC: The Hobbit, The Snowy Day, The Jungle Book and How the Grinch Stole Christmas. He has worked with the Guthrie Theater, Seattle Children’s Theater, New Conservatory Theatre Center, Park Square Theatre, Pillsbury House Theatre, and the Minnesota Orchestra. He is a proud Penumbra Theatre Company member, credits with Penumbra include The Owl Answers, The Dutchman, The Ballad of Emmett Till, and The Amen Corner. Along with serving on the Ten Thousand Things board, he is also a member of Artist Core, credits with the company include The Unsinkable Molly Brown, Dirt Sticks, The Seven, and Park & Lake. H. Adam is the Education Coordinator at the Playwrights’ Center; a resident teaching artist with the Guthrie Theater and CTC, and a freelance equity, diversity, and inclusion consultant for various organizations. He is a graduate of the University of Minnesota/Guthrie Theater BFA Actor Training Program. Next up, he will direct the regional premiere of Redwood at the Jungle Theater.  

  • Domino D’Lorion (he/him/his) is an actor, dancer, writer, teaching artist, stage manager, and a drag queen in the Twin Cities. Originally from Chicago, Domino is an alum of The Chicago Academy for the Arts, Northwestern’s NHSI Theater/Musical Theater program, and he holds a degree from the UMN/Guthrie Theater BFA Actor Training Program, with a B.A. in Business Management from the Carlson School of Management. Domino has appeared in Boudica in the Dowling Studio at the Guthrie Theater, his award-winning original show STOOPIDITY at the Minnesota Fringe Festival, Hit the Wall at the Southern Theater with Mixed Precipitation, and most recently in After The Fires at the Illusion Theater with Transatlantic Love Affair. Domino is thrilled to make his debut with Black Ensemble Players with TopDog/UnderDog.  

  • Dominique Jones is a multi-versed performance artist and mentor who has participated in many reputable performances through theatre, music, poetry, and dance. From the twin cities but artistically born in Wabasha, MN, He has been grateful to compose original music for Stepping Stone Theatre in St. Paul; as well as perform at Minnesota State University, Mankato, the University of Iowa, and various events in the Rochester area like the DFL fundraiser and Art Blitz. He also has choreographed for musicals and groups as well as taught classes through 125 Live, Community Ed, and ACT Now. Through his involvement in the community as a teacher, mentor, and artist, he was honored to be named one of the first U.S. Bank Future Leaders in 2018. 

 

Ty Chapman is a Twin Cities based puppeteer, poet, curator, writer, and stage manager. He got his start with puppetry at In the Heart of the Beast’s “Puppet Cabaret” and honed his skills through Monkeybear’s “New Puppetworks Program.” Ty also crafted a plethora of puppets in the “Barebones 26th Annual Halloween Extravaganza.”, and performed in Open Eye Figure Theatre’s “The Holiday Pageant”. When he finds a moment away from puppets, he co-curates “Collabaret,” a cabaret night with a focus on creating space for new and developmental works of any medium, with shows occurring quarterly. Recently, Ty finished crafting a one-man marionette/shadow puppet show though Puppet Lab, and began the process of writing a children’s book through the Loft’s “Mirrors and Windows” program.

PRODUCTION DATES 

Friday MAY 1st @ 7:30pm

Saturday MAY 2nd @ 7:30pm

Sunday MAY 3rd @ 2:00pm

Friday MAY 8th @ 7:30pm

Saturday MAY 9th @ 7:30pm

Sunday MAY 10th  @ 2:00pm

PRODUCTION LOCATION 

TBA

story:
The Project: (de)classified, a performance of ancestry, culture, and change honoring the Asian American experiences that our media and documentation of history have overlooked. It is radically created in collaboration with a cast of 6 Asian American women rooted in examining their cultural evolution growing up in this country. In order to move forward in this deeply divided time, we reconcile and heal from our pasts. Asian American stories about growing up in this country have a history of being overlooked in the media, textbooks and curriculum. We aim to engage distant and near communities in conversation about this topic.

Five Feet Dance was founded in 2016 in hopes of “making dance/sharing stories/creating community”. The company works with an ever-growing list of collaborators who invest their time in a reflective, thorough, investigative process of the chosen topic that encourages empathy and courageous vulnerability.

This year we have been selected as an Artist in Residence at CounterPulse, San Francisco, to present a (de)classified April 5th-7th and 12th-14th, 2018.

The company and our composer are already hard at work. We spent September-October, 2017 recording personal interviews through StoryCorps San Francisco to gather materials for movement and sound, as well document these Asian American voices beyond this project, and have now jumped into rehearsal mode. We are also excited to be sharing our work at Dance Mission Theater’s Choreographer’s Showcase on January 20-21, 2018 and at other to be announced venues.

We are raising $2,500+ for...

1) Collaborator compensation. The collaborators range in age from 21 through their 50s and are working artists, students, and professionals. Our goal to raise awareness and representation of Asian American experiences and voices, and part of that is to compensate them fairly for their time.

To find out more about these awesome people, click here!

2) Project Documentation. We hope to create an excerpt reel about the process and performance so that these individual stories and experiences continue to exist and be affective well beyond the performance in April; preserved on the internet and encouraging genuine Asian American representation in art making.

3) Dance Mission Choreographer’s Showcase & other. We have lined up public appearances around our April performance, to not only promote our work but to also engage further communities in conversation. We will need to compensate fees and costs to participate in these events.

What We Need & What You Get

Excluding the ticket sales, that will directly compensate collaborators; we are in need of $2,500+. 

Costs:

6 dancers x $700 (~$13 x54hrs of rehearsal) = $4,200

1 Composer = $700

Film/Documentation Costs = $300

Choreographers Showcase & Other Fees = $250

(Our main priority is to use funds to compensate the 7 collaborators, no matter how much is raised.)

Perks!

$15+ Instagram dance improvisation dedicated to you from one of our dancers, to a song of your choice!

$25+ Instagram dance improvisation dedicated to you from the entire cast, to a song of your choice!

$40+ In addition to the above, the company will mail you a thank you card.

$60+ In addition to the above, the company will mail you a thank you card with a signed cast photo.

$100+ In addition to the above, we will invite you to a private rehearsal to get a sneak peek of the piece.

The Impact

Here are some quotes from our dancers:

"In sharing my family history through StoryCorps, I feel that I am breaking some taboos that families and more specifically, Asian families have."-Kathleen Moore

"Sometimes there are no solutions or answers. Only stories and the space to hold them. To be listened to, to be really heard — it is radical; it is personal and political for me...Unpacking my stories to refresh and re-render my identity on my terms. "-Melissa Lewis

"What a great way to help people come together and better understand each other."-Joyce Lien Kushner

"...to being reminded about the inherent power of storytelling and dialogue, to internal, intrapersonal realizations about my own personal history, how it relates to the cultures I identify with, and my varying levels of comfort discussing it."-Malia Byrne

"I felt it was completely indulgent - people listening to me and my story!..."-Nina Wu

“…I was forming my understanding of how this is a part of the Fil-Am experience: being raised by the hands of multiple generations and being surrounded by things that time my family back to the homeland.” –Jazlynn G. Eugenio Pastor

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute to our fundraising campaign, we completely understand, we hope you can share this campaign so that others who can pledge a donation know about us.  

Thank you for taking the time to learn more about Five Feet Dance and our (de)classified project. Please spread the word about our project and this campaign using the Indiegogo share tools.

Follow us on social media to know when to come see us in action in Spring 2018!!

www.fivefeetdance.com / Facebook: Five Feet Dance / Instagram: @fivefeetdance

story:
Summary.

We're tired of being asked to sit back, watch the lights dim, and see a story play out in front of us. We know you are too. We want to create an experience for you. 

Theatre is an evolving, breathing, surprising and wholly unique form, and it's the perfect medium to explore the shadowy world of Elizabeth Bathory. Whether it's from historical documents or folklore -- everything we find about this woman only adds further nuance and shadow to her story. We need your perspective now. 

  • In short, without your help, we cannot make this show happen. 

 

What We Need.

While we have ambitious aims for this show, we first want to ensure we can achieve the basics. For the first phase of our fundraising campaign, our goal is: $4000

$4000 covers:

  • Space use for our development workshop this November
  • Space use for rehearsals as well as performances
  • Budgets for Lighting and Sound
  • Partial budget for Costumes, Props and Set 
  • Publicity costs
  • Designer stipends

First and foremost: since this is a site-specific piece, our first priority is securing the site itself. The majority of our budget is dedicated to rehearsing as well as performing in the venue we think perfectly suites this story. 

All funds following will be allocated to ensuring our designers have the budgets they need, compensating them for their time and work, and then investing in publicity for a show that requires an audience to function. 

 

The Impact

Chicago has an incredibly diverse and ever-growing theatrical landscape, and we have something new to contribute. Your contributions make a compelling and thrilling type of theatre come to life in a community of people who want to take action, who want to participate in their art. 

  • You have the chance to make a wholly unique experience realized for every person who comes to the show (hopefully, including you!). 
  • If you are unable to see the show for yourself, your contribution still invests in a rapidly developing type of theatre -- the immersive experience. We want to both create and participate in these theatrical experiences in Chicago for years to come, and your investment heralds that it can happen. 
  • We want to connect with people. We want to move every person who comes on this journey with us. That's what this is really about. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Looking to participate, but unable to donate? That's okay! Here are some ways you can still help: 

  • Please spread the word. Tell your friends about this cool project. Hell, tell your family, distant relatives, that pen pal from middle school...
  • Follow us in this journey! Like our Facebook Page, follow us on Instagram, or check out our website for updates

 

Team. 

Kristina McCloskey: Executive Producer

Molly Donahue: Director 

Robin Waisanen: Co-creator/Associate Producer/Actor

Millie Rose: Co-creator/Playwright/Actor

Thanks, thanks, and thanks again,

The Bloody Bathory Team
story_txt:
Summary.
We're tired of being asked to sit back, watch the lights dim, and see a story play out in front of us. We know you are too. We want to create an experience for you. 
Theatre is an evolving, breathing, surprising and wholly unique form, and it's the perfect medium to explore the shadowy world of Elizabeth Bathory. Whether it's from historical documents or folklore -- everything we find about this woman only adds further nuance and shadow to her story. We need your perspective now. 

In short, without your help, we cannot make this show happen. 
 

What We Need.
While we have ambitious aims for this show, we first want to ensure we can achieve the basics. For the first phase of our fundraising campaign, our goal is: $4000
$4000 covers:

Space use for our development workshop this November
Space use for rehearsals as well as performances
Budgets for Lighting and Sound
Partial budget for Costumes, Props and Set 
Publicity costs
Designer stipends

First and foremost: since this is a site-specific piece, our first priority is securing the site itself. The majority of our budget is dedicated to rehearsing as well as performing in the venue we think perfectly suites this story. 
All funds following will be allocated to ensuring our designers have the budgets they need, compensating them for their time and work, and then investing in publicity for a show that requires an audience to function.

story:
Our Story

Indian myths are often interpreted in two different ways. The most popular is a version rooted in patriarchy, where women are depicted as virtuous and pure with everlasting devotion for their husbands. The other view portrays women as multi-dimensional and tenacious in their pursuit for sensuality and passion. And while this opinion is still very much debated and controversial in today's society, we think it's more authentic in describing womanhood.

Through this lens, we examine the love affair between Radha and Krishna. Radha was a married woman who longed for Krishna emotionally, but especially, physically. Using Bharatnatyam and Odissi, we bring the story alive for you to shed light on old notions.

 

How You Can Help

‘The Affair’ is being hosted by San Francisco West Wave Dance festival 2017 on October 6th and September 30, but we need your help to make it happen! We're asking for $4500 to go toward:

  • Artist Stipend - This helps pay for artists' transportation to and from rehearsals/performances. Additionally, Sri Thina ardently believes in paying her artists for their time and effort in upkeeping the classical Indian arts. 
  • Rehearsal Space - We were granted 10 hours of studio time by SAFEHouse Arts, but need an additional 12 hours. Rehearsal space generally costs about $17 - $20 an hour.
  • Costuming - Parts of our costuming has been stitched and sent from Malaysia. 
  • Music Composition - Composers of the production are Jyotsna Prakash and Renu Suresh from Malaysia and Singapore.

 

 

About the Choreographer/Artistic Director

Sri Thina has danced professionally as a soloist and collaborator for 15 years both. She's worked with renowned choreographers, such as Mavin Khoo and Shobana Jeyasingh, and performed on international venues including The Lincoln Center, The Royal Opera House, and Buckingham Palace.

story:
In FEST's inaugural festival, we produced six shows. In our second year the festival featured four original works. In the third year, the festival had six original works. Last year, we had one play, four devised pieces, and three dance pieces. This year, we will be putting up three devised pieces, a video, and a fashion instillation . Hundreds have come to see and support the festival over the past four years, and we are excited for another year of festival growth! We are thrilled that the Bard community is so eager to begin this collaborative process once more.

 

Gideon Lester, the Director of Theater and Performance at Bard, recognizes FEST as "a major addition to Bard’s cultural landscape.”

 

Bard college fosters a dynamic community of intelligent, compassionate and eager artists who go on to become valued members of their artistic communities throughout the world. Therefore, a contribution is not only an investment in art at Bard, but also in the art of the future. When you contribute, you are contributing to the future of American Theater and Dance.


We're raising money for costumes, props, and sets. Please help support these costs. Theater, though paying little, costs a lot. As FEST operates without financial support from the college, in order to produce these eight pieces, securing funds is critical. Support from a wide community will enable FEST productions possible.  We think it's worth it. Each year of FEST has catalyzed the Bard student arts scene and inspired the creation of work for senior projects, solo projects, and works outside of Bard.

This year's festival:

 

Devised Performance:

Cora Katz and Cathey Bloom

Imogen Thomas

Bill Wang

Leon Gonzalez

 

Choreography:

Cluno Clark-Bruno with the Baddie Collective

 

Video:

Brigid Pfiefer

 

Fashion Instillation:

Sam Harmann

 

Technical Crew:

Lighting Design - Janine Rogers

Sound Design - Mana Taylor

Producers/Curators - Elise Alexander, Amanda Houser, Imogen Thomas, Cathey Bloom, and Francesca Keller

 

As producers, as Bard students, and as artists ourselves, we would like to thank you for supporting the arts. Our work is has been and continues to be made possible by the generosity of performance-lovers like you.

story:
Our Story

Hello, my name is Julie Rosier. Almost seven years ago I had a vision of how to bind together my burning passions for theater and social change.  In that moment, even before it had a name, Red Thread Theater was born.  According to Chinese legend, an invisible red thread connects all human beings together. It is said that though this magical cord may stretch or tangle it will never break. 


Here's how this unique theater-making process works: I assemble a small cast of Performer-Writers.  Then, working together as an ensemble, each individual mines through personal experience in search of a story that confronts and transcends a central point of internal conflict.  Finally, we weave these stories into a transformative multi-plot narrative, giving the audience an intimate and interconnected look at the fabric of individual and collective change.  


After an enthusiastic response to our inaugural production in Detroit, Red Thread Theater is very excited to introduce a new ensemble and a New York City premiere coming on June 3, 2011 to The Spoon Theater (38 W 38th Street, NYC). Since January, the NYC ensemble has gathered around the fertile soil of creation and recently five courageous stories came shooting out of the ground just in time for spring.  But we still need your support to ensure that this production is in glorious bloom by early summer.


Buy tickets to Facing the Minotaur, Red Thread Theater's new show!

The Impact

Red Thread Theater provides a creative forum for personal introspection and interpersonal dialogue, while simultaneously raising the social, political and spiritual consciousness of each of the group members.  These authentic performances unmask divisive prejudices and rigid assumptions to reveal the human vulnerability and deep resiliency found beneath the surface of everyday life.  Thus, the company uses the transformative power of theater to shed light on the self-actualization potential of performers and audience members alike.

What We Need and What Your Support Provides

In a city where space of any kind is hard to come by, the rental rehearsal and performance space is the highest price tag we face.  We will need individual donations to cover these hard costs.  Please consider donating today; no contribution is too small.  Your financial support will be critical to our continued creative development and artistic success.  


Here are some examples of how we will utilize your contributions: 

  • $25 covers rehearsal space rental for HALF a week

  • $50 covers rehearsal space rental for a FULL week

  • $100 covers printing of promotional materials

  • $500 covers performance venue rental for BOTH nights!

Other Ways You Can Help

Not everyone has cash - something we understand well! - but there are other ways you can help. Spreading the word via facebook, twitter, and emailing the link to this project to your network will all help tremendously.  If you know people who may be interested in funding the project, please forward this information on to them, even if you are unable to contribute yourself. We also welcome volunteer support and in-kind donations (printing supplies or equipment, discounted or free rehearsal space for May, etc).

story:
Our Story

My daughter, Sarvani Eloheimo, was born at International Mission of Hope, an orphanage in Kolkata, India.  She was 3-months-old when she came home to me in Olympia, Washington. She is now 14. Fate would have it that Olympia is also the home of Dr. Ratna Roy, Master Artist in the female tradition of Odissi, one of the classical dance forms of India. Remarkably, Odissi originated less than three hundred miles from where Sarvani was born! At the age of 5, here on the other side of the world, Sarvani began studying with Dr. Roy, known as the foremost proponent of this lineage in the world! Sarvani's first performance, a solo, took place at the age of 8. Since then, Sarvani has performed widely throughout the Puget Sound Region of Washington as well as at the Third International Odissi Festival in Bhubaneswar, India when she was 10. Notably, she and Dr. Roy have together received four Washington State Arts Commission Master-Apprentice Awards between the ages of 9 and 14.  Now, Dr. Roy has invited Sarvani to perform with her company, Urvasi Dance Ensemble, in two international festivals and one national festival in Bhubaneswar in December 2011. We are seeking help with travel expenses for this wonderful opportunity.  


The Impact

In order for Sarvani’s training with Dr. Roy to continue, along with performances in India, Sarvani will need new financial support. This is due to the fact that, after receiving the Washington State Master-Apprentice Awards four times (which is rare in itself), the likelihood of additional awards, at least in the near future, is very slim.  Additionally, the ability for Sarvani to perform in India depends upon her ability to travel to India. The Master-Apprentice Award does not support such travel.  Realizing now that Sarvani’s long-term commitment to study, practice and performance – and the support that I, as a single mother, am able to provide her – will simply not be enough, I am reaching out in hopes that we may be able to find support for this opportunity, and perhaps beyond. 


You can see Sarvani performing in the following YouTube videos:


http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5nbrkX1yxO0


This is an acting dance about Krishna as a young child.  In it, Sarvani dances multiple parts including young mischievous Krishna, his mother, and Krishna's playmates.


http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=SZce0JmPXFc


This group dance took place in the summer of 2010 when Sarvani was 12.  It was part of the Seattle Theater Group's "Dance This!" presented at Seattle's Paramount Theater.  This variation on a traditional dance features Sarvani as a young girl "waking" into a dream (she begins lying down on the far right) where she sees the temple sculptures, from which much of the dance form has been reconstructed, coming to life.


What We Need & What You Get

What do we need at this time? Specifically, we need assistance with costs involved in a three-week trip to India in December 2011.  So far, being a part-time college teacher, I have drawn upon family and community support in various ways:  I have held garage/estate sales (offering belongings from Sarvani's grandfather who had Alzheimer's and lived with us for six years until he passed last year); I have held Zumba benefits (as a Zumba instructor myself); and I have produced an evening of community music, food, and silent auction.  While these events have raised nearly $2500 - along with lots of moral support! - they have reached one-third of the overall travel costs. The costs are so high because this includes myself and  Sarvani's 11-year-old sister, Meena, who came home from Mumbai at the age of 5 and will, on this trip, be returning to India for the very first time!  In this campaign, however, we are only seeking specific help with Sarvani's own international ticket that will cost nearly $1900 ($1870 to be precise).


What will you receive? During the trip, to the extent possible, we wish to share our experiences with all of Sarvani's supporters by maintaining a blog.  Back home, I plan to produce a performance of Odissi dance that includes some of the dances performed at the festivals in India.  All local contributors of $10 or more (past and future) will receive a complimentary ticket to the performance. All contributors of $20 or more, near or far, will also receive a signed photograph of Sarvani performing.  Beyond that, I hope all will feel the rich satisfaction of knowing they are supporting a young talent as she transitions through her teen years as well as of knowing they are helping her share with others the joy her dancing can bring. 


A most sincere "thank you."


Other Ways You Can Help

Watch for Sarvani's website.

"Like" us on facebook: Sarvani's Odissi Odyssey 2011.

Share us on facebook!

Share this page with colleagues and friends.

story:
Our Story

We're participating in The Ismene Project, a world-wide theatrical endeavor to raise awareness and funds for breast cancer support organizations. The St. John's production will run May 11-15, 2011 at Rabbittown Theatre and will be donating its box office proceeds to the Dr. H. Bliss Murphy Cancer Care Foundation.


Ismene is a play written by Jeremy Menekseoglu, soon to be featured in seven cities around the world (Dublin, Toronto, Chicago, Los Angeles, Las Vegas & Chamberlain, SD). Based on a new chapter in the stories of lesser-known heroines in Greek Theatre and Mythology, Ismene is the tale of a young woman who is sent away to a School for Arktoi (unruly children) in the wake of great tragedy. Fate comes knocking in the form of a deadly Chorus, and Ismene is trapped inside the school with four other fierce women. Will they fight their fate or give in to their tragedies once and for all?


With a cast and crew split evenly between professional and emerging artists, we'll take our audiences on a journey they won't forget, literally guiding them through the halls of the School for Arktoi while the story unfolds.


The Impact

Ismene is a great opportunity for the artists involved to get up-close-and-personal with their audience, and for the audience to experience theatre more personally and directly than usual. Your donation will help us pay professional fees, buy materials for sets and costumes, and promote the show so that we pack the house every night!


Our goal is to produce a professional production of Ismene while donating all of our box office profits to the Dr. H. Bliss Murphy Cancer Care Foundation. The foundation is dedicated to providing support for cancer patients and their families, and to give them hope for a full recovery. 1 in 9 Canadian women will be diagnosed with breast cancer at some point in their lives - we all know someone who's been affected. The Ismene Project is a unique way to raise some funds to help them do their work.


What We Need & What You Get

We're looking for $3000 from our IndieGoGo campaign to help us cover production costs, including fees, materials and promotions. No matter how much or how little we raise through IndieGoGo, your contribution will go directly into the production. We have other irons in the fire (grant applications, corporate sponsorship, etc) so we'll go ahead with the show regardless - but we need your help to make it the spectacular success we know it can be: better fees, better sets and costumes, better tech, better publicity.


Perks start at $10! Donate $50 or more and you get a free ticket to the performance of your choice!


Other Ways You Can Help

Tell your friends! Word of mouth and social media are our best friends, so help us get the word out! And clicking on the "Share" tools makes it a snap!

No matter how much or how little we raise through IndieGoGo, your contribution will go directly into the production. We have other irons in the fire (grant applications, corporate sponsorship, etc) so we'll go ahead with the show regardless - but we need your help to make it the spectacular success we know it can be: better fees, better sets and costumes, better tech, better publicity.

Perks start at $10! Donate $50 or more and you get a free ticket to the performance of your choice!


Other Ways You Can Help
Tell your friends! Word of mouth and social media are our best friends, so help us get the word out! And clicking on the "Share" tools makes it a snap!

story:
The Adaptations Project creates a theatrical body of work by an ever-growing roster of associate artists.  Founded by Donnie Mather, The Adaptations Project adapts new forms of storytelling to create new works for a new century. 

The first production is "Kaddish (or The Key in the Window)" based on the poem by Allen Ginsberg.  
Performed by Donnie Mather & Directed by Kim Weild.  Ginsberg's poetry springs to life in this multi-media, memory play.

The Impact

This initial campaign allows us to meet our first production expenses toward our inaugural production.

What We Need & What You Get

Meeting this goal will allow us launch our PR campaign and to secure the rental on the theatre space for September.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you prefer to make a TAX-DEDUCTIBLE donation:

1) Please visit http://www.TheField.org/ContributionToSA.aspx?

2) Select ADAPTATIONS PROJECT/Donnie Mather from the list of artists

3) Enter the amount to donate.


The Adaptations Project is a Sponsored Artist with The Field, a not-for-profit, tax-exempt 501(c)(3) organization serving the New York City performing arts community.

story:
BE PART OF THE WORLD PREMIERE OF A NEW PLAY!!

"Minogue is a promising writer. Those don't show up everyday"- Colin Thomas, Georgia Straight

From the playwright and company that created Prodigals comes a brand new play called Us & Everything We Own about a young couple whose hunger for home ownership and meaningful careers threatens to destroy their relationship.

This project has been in development for almost two years. In May of 2012, the City of Vancouver supported a public staged reading and since then, we've cast the play, assembled a great crew, and locked down our venue. Rehearsals are quickly approaching and we couldn't be more excited to share this story with all of you!

This exciting World Premiere production of Us & Everything We Own will appear on stage at Vancouver's PAL Studio Theatre, 581 Cardero Street, from April 5-13, 2013 (Preview performance on April 4 for $12!)

Tickets $12-$22, available through Brown Paper http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/305306

Us & Everything We Own is directed by Artistic Producer, Sabrina Evertt  featuring local actors, Adam Lolacher (Christmas Carol, Belfry Theatre), Julie McIsaac (Hamlet, Honest Fishmonger's, Jessie Nomination), Genevieve Fleming (Death of Salesman, Vancouver Playhouse) and Jason Clift (Zombie Syndome, Virtual Stage).

The fabulous production team to help bring the world of the play alive includes Mark Carter (Production Manager), Melanie Thompson (Stage Manager), Craig Alfredson (Set Designer), Alia Stephens (Lighting Designer) & Kaitlin Williams (Costume Designer).

The Company & Our Impact

Coming off an award winning 2012 season with The Bomb-itty of Errors - nominated for 4 Jessie Richardson Theatre awards including Outstanding Production & Outstanding Direction and won for Outstanding Costume Design & Significant Artistic Achievement-Outstanding Ensemble Performance with Music & Live DJ - Twenty Something Theatre is back and excited to bring you another great season of theatre!

Twenty-Something Theatre is an award-winning Vancouver based independent theatre company dedicated to producing contemporary theatre that is provocative, edgy and relevant to our generation. We are committed to providing Vancouver's next generation of theatre artists with opportunities to pursue their craft and we strive to enhance Vancouver’s theatre community with productions that entertain and evoke the lives of today’s young people. 

Now in our 8th season, Twenty Something Theatre has featured some of the city’s best up-and-coming artists in such highly acclaimed works as Tough! by George F. Walker, Nocturne by Adam Rapp, Blue Surge by Rebecca Gilman, Unidentified Human Remains and the True Nature of Love by Brad Fraser, Suburbia by Eric Bogosian, The Fever by Wallace Shawn, The Shape of Things by Neil Labute and This Is Our Youth by Kenneth Lonergan. 

Twenty-Something Theatre fills an important function in Vancouvers cultural ecology: it offers edgier scripts, including original works such as Sean Minogue's Prodigals, and even in its name attempts to appeal to a younger demographic. --Colin Thomas, Georgia Straight

How Can You Help? 

In order to mount the World Premiere of Us & Everything We Own we need to fundraise approximately $2000 through individual contributions from people like you.

We're asking for your support to make sure this is a memorable production. As a small, independent theatre company any amount you're able to contribute turns into tangible results as to what actually goes up on the stage.

A $25 contribution might put a costume piece on an actors back while $50 or $125 might put a set piece such as a couch, or a couple of chairs, on stage. 

And, in return, we're putting the “fun” back in “fundraising”. (Huh? Huh? Hmm.) Check out the unique perks we're offering. With love and relationships as one of the main themes of the play, we chose love as a theme for this campaign and these perks are a few sincere, and somewhat twisted, ways of showing our love for your support. All contributors will be recognized in the play's program.

Every little bit helps!

More than anything you can also help us spread the word! Tell all your friends, family, co-workers, strangers that you meet on the street, about this exciting project. You can follow along with our progress:

Blog, An Unidentified Production http://twentysomethingtheatre.blogspot.ca/

or on Facebook https://www.facebook.com/twentysomethingtheatre

or Twitter  https://twitter.com/theatre_20

No matter what, we hope you'll check out the production in April!

From everyone involved in this World Premiere production of Us & Everything We Own, we would like to extend a very big thank you for all your support!!!

From everyone involved in this World Premiere production of Us & Everything We Own, we would like to extend a very big thank you for all your support!!!

story:
My name is Vickilyn Reynolds, writer of the one woman musical, "Hattie...What I Need You to Know!" It was written, developed and massaged out of a vision to recreate this often overlooked actress Hattie McDaniel. "Hattie..What I Need You to Know!" captures the essence of Hattie McDaniel's humble beginnings in Denver and her rise to stardom in Hollywood.

I have been on a journey for twelve years the first three were research in three different states, then the next five years I spent writing the book and music.

This project means the world to me, my brother Tony award winner Ron Richardson who  passed away in 1995, told me "Vickiyn you should potray the life of Hattie McDaniel.' Then one day on set my friend Larry Riley, who as well passed away not long after my brother, said "Vickilyn if no one approaches you with the idea, if nobody writes it for you, write it yourself but you do the life story of Hattie McDaniel.  So after much hesitation I did just that. We opened in Denver where we were nominated for the Denver Post Ovation award, then in New York where we won the Audelco Award and then a short run here in Los Angeles where we were nominated for an NAACP Award.

Please help me make this tribute show "Hattie...What I Need You to Know!" a celebration to this wonderful trailblazing queen and along with your donations it will be.  

OUR GOAL

To re-open  January11th, 2013 at Theatre Asylum in Los Angeles.

Raise funds for advertising and PR a minimum of $3500.00

 

 WITH YOUR PLEDGE

With your pledge we will be able to advertise and hire a Press Agent, that seemed to have been my short coming.

 I'd like to say thank you in advance for those who could donate and to those who would like to but can't.

 

Peace and blessings,

Vickilyn

story:
The Story 

Parly Cloudy People is a theater company in NYC that works with non-profits and education groups whose mission statements align with a play we want to produce. Our productions explore the human condition, complete with its flaws and the potential to grow and heal. We believe in fostering new talent, diverse casting, and creating theater as means to both educate and entertain.

We are thrilled to announce our next production, the first New York revival of Tigers Be Still, by Kim Rosenstock (writer on the New Girl). Tigers will run May 9-25 at the Drilling Company on 236 West 78 Street.

NY Times says 'A big cat is actually on the prowl in “Tigers Be Still,” an endearing new play by Kim Rosenstock, but nobody’s paying much attention to this alarming problem. A fiercer foe is the grief clawing at the hearts of all the characters, whose afflictions come in many stripes, from debilitating illness to a mother’s death to a father’s abandonment. The possibility of being eaten by a wild animal might be greeted with indifference, if not actually welcomed, by the benumbed, bewildered and bedridden characters in this quirk-addicted but heartfelt comedy.'

This production will serve as a fundraiser and awareness campaign for the Ackerman Institute for the Family, an independent, not-for-profit organization. Founded in 1960, Ackerman is one of the premier institutions for family therapy and one of the best-known and most highly regarded training facilities for family therapists in the United States. Ackerman's mission coincides with the themes of this wonderful play, and counselors and staff members will give talk backs after certain performances.

What We Need & What You Get

Here is what you can help us with:

Production Costs

  • Royalties, $1260
  • Costumes, $200
  • Lights, $100
  • Set, $800
  • Props, $100
  • Rehearsal Space, $1200
  • Theater Rental, $7500
  • Insurance, 500

What You Get

Your name could appear on our website and programs. You might attend private cockatil recpetions with the cast and crew, attend private rehearsals, and more! Plus you are supporting a great cause, the theater and Ackerman. All donations are tax deductible.

The Impact

You are supporting many artists in NYC who create theater to make a difference in the world. Our team includes:

  • Sarah Nedwek, Co-Founder, Actress
  • Phillip Chavira, Co-Founder, Producer
  • Pirronne Yousefzadeh, Director
  • Caite Hevner, Set Designer
  • Beth Goldenberg, Costume Designer
  • Mike Inwood, Lighting Designer
  • Emma Wilk, Sound Designer
  • Stephanie Thompson, Actress
  • Juan Castano, Actor
  • Drew Moore, Actor

You are also supporting Ackerman. Partial proceeds from the production will go directly to the Institute, funding training, clinical services, centers and special projects, and much more.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Like our Facebook Page.
  • Visit Partly Cloudy People website.
  • Share our mission statement with someone who could help us out.

Thank you very much!
