story:
Parallel Universe Theater Resources is premiering its large ensemble decadently spiritual verse play FREEFALL FROSTBITE at the historic Ellen Stewart Theater as part of the New York Fringe Festival in August, 2013.

Written by Michael Fixel (Salamander Stew, Fringe 2011), scored by Fixel and Broadway veteran musical director Marc Irwin, assistant musical director and piano conductor Adele Dinerstein, and directed and choreographed by Juliet Fixel, it is Shakespeare as if he had hung out with William S. Burroughs.  It has songs, but it's sure not Lerner and Lowe.

The mission of  Parallel Universe is to provide meaningful artistic opportunities for early career performers.  That's part of the reason we favor large-cast productions- that and the fact that we just love specatcle.  We are really looking forward to whirlpooling around the vast mystical space of the Ellen Stewart Theater on 4th Street on Manhattan's Lower East Side.

Large ensemble means relatively high costs.  We believe in featuring the skills of the performers over scenery and effects, and that keeps production costs low, but we still wind up spending plenty on big rehearsal halls, costumes, incidentals like programs, and invisibles like insurance.

We feel really privileged to have been selected by Fringe.  Only one of five applicants makes it to the stage.  Fringe does an excellent job of making it possible to produce a show in New York at moderate cost.  It's still New York, though.

Our goal is to raise about $300 for each of the thirty-three or so members of the troupe (it's hard to tell exactly how many- they keep moving).  Even if we are successful in this drive, we still have to sell alot of tickets, so please help spread the word. 

You can hear some of the score and read an excerpt from the play on our website. 

Juliet Fixel's realization of the prequel at Fringe in 2011, earned accolades such as this from nytheater.com:

"Salamander Stew is a refreshingly unique experience with a confident sense of itself, performed virtuosically by a talented and committed ensemble."

Freefall Frostbite is, if anything, a much more ambitious play.  Perhaps an important play.  Where it will go from here is anybody's guess.  With your help though it will have already succeeded in its most important goal, that of providing a significant opportunity to these dedicated young actors and techs and gifting them with an experience they will remember the rest of their lives and be proud to have on their resumes.

story:
Our Story

I am making a new dance with the extraordinary performer Natalie Green where we explore the dynamics of director and performer. The work has been elusive and enigmatic to make, a little edgy, and very much about how we negotiate this thing we do with our lives called performing. We are excited to share it with you. The work premieres at The Kitchen in NYC Feb 9-11, 2012 in a shared evening with choreographer Amanda Loulaki.


The Impact

We are hoping to expose the complicated but rewarding nature of dancing and dance making in performance. We hope that it will touch you.


What We Need & What You Get  

We need to raise funds to pay our collaborators, which include dramaturg Susan Mar Landau, sound designer Justin Luchter, lighting designer Joe Levasseur, and also to pay for costumes and a proper video documentation and editing of the work so that it can exist beyond the moment of performance. And thanks to the generosity of my fiscal sponsor - Brooklyn Arts Exchange - all contributions are tax deductible to the extent allowed by law!


Other Ways You Can Help

Tell your friends. I make work to touch audiences beyond dance, but also to speak to intelligent and inquisitive audiences within dance . Help me get my work out there into the larger world by sharing this fundraising initiative and by coming to the performance!

story:
Our Story

“A Map of the Ocean’s Floor” (formerly known as "A Jazz Sweet for Poets") is a new play by Jessica Lewis. Based in New York City in the late 1970s, at the end of the bohemia that had been created in the previous years by the Beat Generation. The play, set at the end of a social and artistic era discusses themes of disillusionment and the changing times, and how that was affecting the practices of musicians, writers, and artists, who had been involved with, or inspired by the Beat Generation. The play itself uses the multi-disciplinary approach of the Beat Generation by combining music, theater, spoken word, and movement to create a new work of theater that is experimental, while remaining heavily grounded in the traditions of realism, naturalism, and the collaborative works that came out of the Beat Generation itself. “A Map of the Ocean’s Floor” for Poets pays homage to the Beat Generation, while depicting the end of an era.


Jessica Lewis, writes a play heavily influenced by the music and poetry of the Beat Generation, by combining all of these genres to create a work that attempts to defy classical genres of theater. By combining jazz music, spoken word poetry, live theater, history, and dance, she tells the story of a young girl who looses her sense of "reality," while getting swept up in the romanticism and nostalgia of the end of Bohemia as it had previously been known.


Through this play we see how the music and words of the Beat Generation moved and inspired so many around it, but also how it enabled a whole generation after to get lost in a world of excess and unrealistic views of what it meant to be an artist.


A love of the music and the language of poetry, as an expression of what jazz musicians were doing with their music at the time was what the Beat Generation was attempting to do. “A Map of the Ocean’s Floor”, we see how those ideas and objectives got easily misconstrued by many who were in search of something "real," and of a "real artists life," and how this distance from reality has impacted youth from all generations since.

What We Need & What You Get

Since we are being sponsored by Andrew Jannetti and Dancers (andrewjannettianddancers.com) all donations are TAX DEDUCTIBLE! We need to raise a minimum of 4,000 dollars to pay for space, materials and to hopefully give some funding to the amazing artists collaborating on this project!


125 people x $20 - $2,500

50 people x $50 - $2,500

25 people x $100 - $2,500 


Thats kinda amazing how few people and how little you need to invest to help the arts grow in NYC and around the world...

Other Ways You Can Help

You can donate to Jessica Lewis personally through Andrew Jannetti and dancers by emailing jesslewis448@gmail.com, and connecting personally.

The play itself uses the multi-disciplinary approach of the Beat Generation by combining music, theater, spoken word, and movement to create a new work of theater that is experimental, while remaining heavily grounded in the traditions of realism, naturalism, and the collaborative works that came out of the Beat Generation itself. “A Map of the Ocean’s Floor” for Poets pays homage to the Beat Generation, while depicting the end of an era.

Jessica Lewis, writes a play heavily influenced by the music and poetry of the Beat Generation, by combining all of these genres to create a work that attempts to defy classical genres of theater. By combining jazz music, spoken word poetry, live theater, history, and dance, she tells the story of a young girl who looses her sense of "reality," while getting swept up in the romanticism and nostalgia of the end of Bohemia as it had previously been known.

Through this play we see how the music and words of the Beat Generation moved and inspired so many around it, but also how it enabled a whole generation after to get lost in a world of excess and unrealistic views of what it meant to be an artist.

A love of the music and the language of poetry, as an expression of what jazz musicians were doing with their music at the time was what the Beat Generation was attempting to do. “A Map of the Ocean’s Floor”, we see how those ideas and objectives got easily misconstrued by many who were in search of something "real," and of a "real artists life," and how this distance from reality has impacted youth from all generations since.


What We Need & What You Get
Since we are being sponsored by Andrew Jannetti and Dancers (andrewjannettianddancers.com) all donations are TAX DEDUCTIBLE! We need to raise a minimum of 4,000 dollars to pay for space, materials and to hopefully give some funding to the amazing artists collaborating on this project!


125 people x $20 - $2,500
50 people x $50 - $2,500
25 people x $100 - $2,500 

Thats kinda amazing how few people and how little you need to invest to help the arts grow in NYC and around the world...


Other Ways You Can Help
You can donate to Jessica Lewis personally through Andrew Jannetti and dancers by emailing jesslewis448@gmail.com, and connecting personally.

story:
Help us bring A Soldier's Play to the Schenectady stage

Classic Theater Guild, Inc is a not-for-profit theater company, bringing live, local theater in an intimate setting to the NY Capital District.  We've been around for 10 years, and have produced a wide variety of shows, from classic dramas to ground-breaking new works.
 
This year, our season includes the Pulitzer Prize winning drama,  A Soldier's Play, which we will be presenting at Proctors' Fenimore Gallery.  To help this show be the best it can be, we would like to raise $1000 for additional production costs.
 
The difficulty and expense of producing a quality show can be high, and we need your help to give our cast and crew the resources to put on an absolutely stellar production.
 

A Soldier's Play: A Riveting Mystery That Explores Serious Issues

By Charles H. Fuller Jr.

Production Scheduled for April 5 - April 14, 2013 at the landmark Proctors Theater, in the Fenimore Gallery, 432 State Street, Schenectady
Directed by Karen Christina Jones
  
 
Under the guise of a murder mystery, A Soldier's Play deals with the racism that permeated the South during the closing months of World War II. At a segregated camp in Louisiana, an angry, unpopular Black Sergeant is murdered. His regiment blames the Klan, the establishment blames the platoon. It is not until the first African American officer comes on the scene to unlock the secrets lurking under the surface.

Adapted into the 1984 Award winning film A Soldier's Story starring Denzel Washington.
 

Contributors Receive Free Tickets & Other Fantastic Perks!

The Classic Theater Guild, Inc, a 501(c)(3) not-for-profit charitable organization, completely staffed by volunteers. But just because we don't try to make money, doesn't mean we don't need money.  Sets, costumes, publicity, all of these things come with a cost, and public arts funding has dramatically declined in recent years.
 
We pledge to use 100% of your donations to support A Soldier's Play.  And your donation is not simply a wonderful gift to a worthy organization to support a great show - it is also a way to get some wonderful perks at all different levels!

$10 contribution - A thank-you in our program.

$35 contribution - One free ticket plus a thank you in our program

$70 contribution - Two free tickets, plus a thank you in our program

$100 contribution - Two free tickets, plus business-card size advertisement in our program

$500 contribution - Two free tickets, 1/4 page program advertisement, and two invitations to the Soldier's Playcast party

$1000 contribution - One season ticket to the CTG 2013-2014 season, full-page program ad, two invitations to the Soldier's Play cast party, and a listing as a major sponsor in our program 

Not enough perks for you?  Become our one and only Producing Sponsor!

$5000 contribution - Two season tickets to the CTG 2013-2014 season and Producing Sponsor crediting in all promotional materials or 10 free tickets to A Soldier's Play, full-page program ad, 10 invitations to the cast party, and Producing Sponsor crediting.  One offer only!

story:
About The Show

"No other offense has ever been visited with such severe penalties as seeking to help the oppressed." Those historic words, spoken by Clarence Darrow, ring true throughout our modern world.

The show takes place in a dystopian, near-future society, where the movement for equal rights has taken a severe step backward, and people's fundamental liberties have been further stripped away. The underground cabaret, where most of the action of the show occurs, is an oasis in a desert of intolerance - a place where people can freely be themselves. The story is dark and touching, with clever humor and burlesque elements throughout. It is our hope that the original score, inspired choreography and moving story will not only entertain, but incite people to action. It is time for change.

story:
Can You Keep A Secret? 

The story of PRIVATE SCHOOL follows six seniors at Mount Assembly High School  trying to survive their final trimester with their integrity, or at least their popularity, intact. 

Selma is involved in eleven clubs on campus. Eleven. Nobody even comes close to that. She used to date Marcus Thomas before he transferred to the nearby public school for financial reasons and started dating somebody else; not that she's bitter or anything. Now she doesn't have a date to the Daffodil Spring Semi-Formal... and someone must pay for this. 

Ester runs the school newspaper at Mount Assembly High School - or rather, it runs her. She is happy to be tripping over deadlines behind-the-scenes... that is, until she unexpectedly steps into the limelight. 

Jack tries to date Ester between her articles, to varied success. He's also the smartest kid in school, but don't tell anyone or it would totally ruin his affable reputation. Also, he only eats grilled cheeses. Strictly. It's one of the few things he takes seriously. 

Brandon is a tri-athlete with a smile that makes you forget what you were talking about. Life comes pretty easy for him, as "handsome athlete" trumps most categories in the social hierarchy of secondary education. This probably won't be an issue, though... Right?  

Zeke dyes his hair every week to match his emotions: it's usually black. But like, different shades of black. He might be in love, but he's kind of a loner so it's hard to tell what's going on with that kid. 

And then, there's Rachel: the one they've been talking about...  

'School' History & Faculty: 

PRIVATE SCHOOL is presented in a unique collaboration of young New York and Minnesota actors paired with students of the University of Minnesota / Guthrie Actor Training program. Originally commissioned by the Academy of Holy Angels in , the play received praise in its workshop presentation in New York City. This premiere production satirizes the absurdities of high school, and how closely it resembles adult and American life. It promotes integrity and perseverance in the face of rumors and adversity. PRIVATE SCHOOL will make you laugh, make you cringe, break your heart and make it up to you.

Dylan Lamb (Playwright / Director) is a recipient of the Chair's Award of Excellence in Dramatic Writing from New York University's Tisch School of the Arts. He is a current member of Fresh Ground Pepper's PlayGroup, has served as directing apprentice under Joe Dowling at the Guthrie Theater, and has written for Warner Brothers Television as part of its Creative Lab. Plays include: Alligator Summer (Abingdon Theater), There Is No Isabelle (Minnesota Fringe), Funeral Game (The Drilling Company), A Man of My Word (NYU Festival of New Works), & SER (SoHo Rep Walkerspace). The short film 'Game Night', for which he wrote the screenplay, was selected into the Manhattan Film Festival this June. Represented by Chelsea McKinnies at Creative Artists Agency. From Minneapolis, Minnesota; he lives in Crown Heights, New York.

The incredibly talented cast of young actors includes Keilly McQuail (NYU / Atlantic Theater School), Pegeen Lamb (U of M / Guthrie Actor Training), Amy Stockhaus (Illinois Wesleyan), Nick Lehane (Carengie Mellon), & Philip Behringer (Hamline University). 

Help Us Pay Our Tuition! 

In order to make this unique production come to life, we need your support. Your contributions will help cover and supply:

  • Transportation fees for out-of-town members
  • Venue fee for the U of M Rarig Thrust
  • Print & Digital Marketing
  • Costumes! Ain't cheap to look this good
  • Further development of new work by Company Bedford

Can't see the show? Donate the price of a ticket and it will help us immensely. CAN see the show? AMAZING! Buy tickets and post reviews HERE.

Tweet About #PrivateSchool! Share Our Event On Facebook! EVERY TYPE OF SUPPORT IS SUPPORT! 

Hope To See You In Class!

story:
The campaign: 

Hi!! My name is Alysha Higgins and I am a U.S. Fulbright scholar, studying and documenting dance of the Indian and African diaspora in the culturally rich and diverse Trinidad and Tobago. My work is to promote mutual understanding between international borders and create cultural exchange. I am organizing, in collaboration with the University of Trinidad and Tobago (UTT) to bring Rosangela Silvestre of Brazil, creator of the world-renowned Silvestre Technique, to Trinidad and Tobago to teach a four-day, intensive Silvestre Technique and Orixa dance movement workshop culminating in a performance of her ongoing choreographic work, Faces of Nature. The proposed dates of her stay are October 23rd to the 28th, 2013. The proposed workshops would be open to the public. The workshop and performance is proposed to take place at UTT’s dance room at the National Academy of Performing Arts (NAPA). The performance will take place at The Little Carib Theatre.

The Impact: 

I have been a student of Rosangela for the past year and truly believe in her work. She is an amazing, inspiring artist and teacher. Rosangela's work is a strong force in the cultural arts and international dance world, while at the same time, Trinidad is becoming a leader in the Caribbean dance community- with a legacy of dance icons like Beryl McBurnie and Pearl Primus, as well as a contemporary dance community of present including the Coco Dance Festival and the New Waves Institute that is skyrocketing Trinidad into the global dance arena. Because of this, I believe bringing Rosangela to Trinidad is a great opportunity to spark international ties and strengthen Trinidad’s role as a Caribbean mecca for contemporary and world dance. The Silvestre Technique, which is a fusion of modern techniques with energetic principles of the natural world, along with the dance expression of Orixa, is complementary to the strong Modern, African, and Indian dance cultures of Trinidad. Experiencing Orixa movement from the African diaspora in Brazil would be a one-of-a-kind experience for participants, providing them with a comparison to the Orisha religion practiced in Trinidad and studied by students in the country, and allowing them to expand their scope of what dance of the African diaspora means on a global scale. I guarantee that what Rosangela will offer the people of Trinidad will greatly inspire, enrich, and enhance their experience as dancers, artists, and people. 

The workshop will be a true exchange because there will be Orisha dance movement classes given by Trinidad and Tobago natives as well, as well as performances by Trinidad and Tobagonians, highlighting their specific Orisha dance and dance expressions. I believe that this building of ties in the international community is extremely powerful and healing for African diasporic communities in TnT!! 

The money will go towards:

1) Rosangela's round-trip plane ticket along with one drummer

2) Renting of the space of the Little Carib Theatre for the culminating performace

story:
For English Language: Scroll Down! 

NEDEN CLOWN?

Clown, an,gülümseme,güldürme ve mutlu etme odaklı bir performans türü.Dünyanın herhangi bir coğrafyasında kolaylıkla kabul edebileceğimiz,dünyasına girebileceğimiz naif,şiirsel bir iyileşme ve paylaşma sanatı.CWB, 22 yıldan beri bu yüzden dünyayı dolaşıyor,sınır tanımadan gösterilerine devam ediyor ,özellikle çocuk seyirciye ulaşmaya devam ediyor.


Uluslararası arenada 22 yıldır faaliyet gösteren bir sivil toplum kuruluşu olan CWB'nin Türkiye ayağını oluşturmak ve 3-9 Ağustos tarihleri arasında Diyarbakır,Mardin,Batman,Urfa hattındaki çadır kamplarda gösteriler düzenlemek için gereken ulaşım ve konaklama giderlerinin karşılanması amacıyla kampanyayı başlattık.

CWB'la Türkiyede bir etkinlik yapma fikri Kobanenin İŞİD tarafından işgalinden sonra Suruç'ta çadır kentlerin oluşmasıyla başladı.Bölgeye giden,gönüllü olarak çalışan,gösteriler ve etkinlikler düzenleyen dostlarımızdan aldığımız bilgiler bizi cesaretlendirdi ve özellikle travma sonrası saha çalışmalarında uzman iki Amerikalı eğitmen ve sanatçıyla iletişime geçerek onları Türkiyeye davet ettik.Kobane işgalinin sona ermesinden sonra Suruçtaki kamplarda geri dönüşler başlamış olsa da bölgede birçok çadır kent varlığını sürdürmekte. Türkiye'nin hareketli Orta Doğu coğrafyasının merkezinde olması birçok çadır kente ev sahipliği yapması,Orta Doğudaki komşu ülkelere CWB Amerika ve CWB Avrupa teşkilatlarına göre çok daha etkin ve hızlı hareket edebilecek olması bizi CWB Türkiye ayağını oluşturmak konusunda cesaretlendirdi.

PROJE

CWB Türkiye projesi üç etaptan oluşuyor.

Birinci Etap: CWB eğitmen ve sanatçıları Sarah Liane Foster ve Tim Cunnigham 25 Temmuz-3 Ağustos tarihleri arasında İstanbul'da sirk sanatçıları,müzisyen ve oyunculardan oluşan bir ekibe bir eğitim verecek ve bir gösteri ekibi oluşturulacak.

İkinci Etap:Oluşturulan ekip iki sanatçıyla birlikte bir hafta boyunca Diyarbakır,Urfa ve Mardin hattındaki çadır kentleri ve köyleri ziyaret ederek gösterimler yapacak.

Üçüncü Etap:Eğitmenler Türkiye'den gittikten sonra oluşan ekibin korunarak CWB Türkiye ayağını oluşturmak. Türkiye ve Orta Doğu'da travma bölgelerinde çocuklara gösteriler ve atölye çalışmaları düzenleyecek deneyimli bir ekibin oluşturulması.

WHY CLOWN?

Clowning is performance style that is geared towards being in the moment, smiling, laughter, and happiness. It is a naive and poetic art of healing and sharing, that can be easily adopted by people from any country, culture or background. This is why CWB has been touring the world for 22 years, carrying on its performances across borders, and reaching particularly young audiences.


THE PROJECT


The idea for cooperating with CWB-USA  in Turkey began to develop alongside of the forming of refugee camps in Suruç after Kobanî’s occupation by ISIL. Inspired by the observations of our friends who have gone to the region, volunteered and organized performances and events, we made connections with and invited to Turkey, two artists/instructors from the CWB- USA who particularly specialize in post-trauma field work. After the liberation of Kobanî, part of the population in camps are leaving Suruç, however the region still holds many camp sites.



CWB Turkey project includes three phases.

Phase one: Artists/instructors Sarah Liane Foster and Tim Cunnigham from CWB USA  are to teach a class in Istanbul to a group consisting of circus performers, musicians and actors, followed by forming a performance troupe with these artists. 

Phase two: This performance troupe and its two instructors will tour the refugee camps for a week, through Diyarbakır, Urfa and Mardin, giving 2-4 performances at each camp.  

Phase three: After the departure of the two instructors from Turkey, the said performance troupe is to found the Turkey branch of CWB. A team of experienced artists is to be formed for the purpose of organizing shows and events for the children living in regions exposed to trauma.

Now we need your support for the logistics of phase one and phase two.

Thank you so much...

NEDEN CLOWN?Clown, an,gülümseme,güldürme ve mutlu etme odaklı bir performans türü.Dünyanın herhangi bir coğrafyasında kolaylıkla kabul edebileceğimiz,dünyasına girebileceğimiz naif,şiirsel bir iyileşme ve paylaşma sanatı.CWB, 22 yıldan beri bu yüzden dünyayı dolaşıyor,sınır tanımadan gösterilerine devam ediyor ,özellikle çocuk seyirciye ulaşmaya devam ediyor.Uluslararası arenada 22 yıldır faaliyet gösteren bir sivil toplum kuruluşu olan CWB'nin Türkiye ayağını oluşturmak ve 3-9 Ağustos tarihleri arasında Diyarbakır,Mardin,Batman,Urfa hattındaki çadır kamplarda gösteriler düzenlemek için gereken ulaşım ve konaklama giderlerinin karşılanması amacıyla kampanyayı başlattık.CWB'la  Türkiyede bir etkinlik yapma fikri Kobanenin İŞİD tarafından işgalinden sonra Suruç'ta çadır kentlerin oluşmasıyla başladı.Bölgeye giden,gönüllü olarak çalışan,gösteriler ve etkinlikler düzenleyen dostlarımızdan aldığımız bilgiler bizi cesaretlendirdi ve özellikle travma sonrası saha çalışmalarında uzman iki Amerikalı eğitmen ve sanatçıyla iletişime geçerek onları Türkiyeye davet ettik.Kobane işgalinin sona ermesinden sonra Suruçtaki kamplarda geri dönüşler başlamış olsa da bölgede birçok çadır kent varlığını  sürdürmekte.     Türkiye'nin hareketli Orta Doğu coğrafyasının merkezinde olması birçok çadır kente ev sahipliği yapması,Orta Doğudaki komşu ülkelere CWB Amerika ve CWB Avrupa teşkilatlarına göre çok daha etkin ve hızlı hareket edebilecek olması bizi CWB Türkiye ayağını oluşturmak konusunda cesaretlendirdi.PROJECWB Türkiye  projesi üç etaptan oluşuyor.Birinci Etap: CWB eğitmen ve sanatçıları  Sarah Liane Foster ve Tim Cunnigham 25 Temmuz-3 Ağustos tarihleri arasında İstanbul'da sirk sanatçıları,müzisyen ve oyunculardan oluşan bir ekibe bir eğitim verecek ve bir gösteri ekibi oluşturulacak.İkinci Etap:Oluşturulan ekip iki sanatçıyla birlikte bir hafta boyunca Diyarbakır,Urfa ve Mardin hattındaki çadır kentleri ve köyleri ziyaret ederek gösterimler yapacak.Üçüncü Etap:Eğitmenler Türkiye'den gittikten sonra oluşan ekibin korunarak CWB Türkiye ayağını oluşturmak. Türkiye ve Orta Doğu'da travma bölgelerinde çocuklara gösteriler ve atölye çalışmaları  düzenleyecek deneyimli bir ekibin oluşturulması.WHY CLOWN?Clowning is performance style that is geared towards being in the moment, smiling, laughter, and happiness. It is a naive and poetic art of healing and sharing, that can be easily adopted by people from any country, culture or background. This is why CWB has been touring the world for 22 years, carrying on its performances across borders, and reaching particularly young audiences.THE PROJECT

The idea for cooperating
with CWB-USA  in Turkey began to develop alongside of the forming of refugee camps
in Suruç after Kobanî’s occupation by ISIL. Inspired by the observations of our
friends who have gone to the region, volunteered and organized performances and
events, we made connections with and invited to Turkey, two artists/instructors
from the CWB- USA who particularly specialize in post-trauma field work. After the
liberation of Kobanî, part of the population in camps are leaving Suruç,
however the region still holds many camp sites.


CWB Turkey project includes three phases.Phase one: Artists/instructors Sarah Liane Foster and Tim Cunnigham from CWB USA  are to teach a class in Istanbul to a group consisting of circus performers, musicians and actors, followed by forming a performance troupe with these artists. Phase two: This performance troupe and its two instructors will tour the refugee camps for a week, through Diyarbakır, Urfa and Mardin, giving 2-4 performances at each camp.  Phase three: After the departure of the two instructors from Turkey, the said performance troupe is to found the Turkey branch of CWB. A team of experienced artists is to be formed for the purpose of organizing shows and events for the children living in regions exposed to trauma.Now we need your support for the logistics of phase one and phase two.Thank you so much...

story:
The Play

A lonely criminal forensics enthusiast stumbles across a serial killer in his own neighborhood.  With the help of his dog, they set out to study the man, but get a little too close. It's kind of a cross between Rear Window and The Dog Whisperer.

Written and performed by Michael Evans Lopez and directed by Maria Pasquarelli, this is the inaugural theatrical presentation from Production Co., Fist The Mountain. We're very excited to bring it to the 2015 Hollywood Fringe Festival.

    What We Need

    In order to make this play a reality, we need $2,500.  What?  $2,500?  Seriously? 

    Yes, and here's what we need to pay for:

    • Registration for the Hollywood Fringe 2015
    • Rental fees and insurance for Six Performances at a stellar venue - The Elephant Studio - in the heart of the Fringe
    • A Stage Manager to make the show run without a hitch!
    • Marketing for the show, including flyers, and adverts in the Fringe Guide and on the Fringe website
    • Props and costumes
    • Rental fees for rehearsal space because parts of the show are not appropriate for the kitties to see

    Risks & Challenges

    We are independent artists who are trying to cover our expenses for this production so that we don't have to pay out of pocket in order to make our art happen.  Please help us make this show a reality!

    Other Ways You Can Help

    No donation is too big or too small, but if things are super tight (and trust us, we completely understand), you can help out by:

    • Spreading the word and getting your friends and family to contribute
    • Liking us on Facebook https://www.facebook.com/fistthemountain
    • Following us on twitter @FistTheMountain
    • Coming out to see our show in June and bringing your friends!

    And that's all there is to it.

story:
What is it?

The Rainbow Connection is a part of the 2015 Cohen New Works Festival, sponsored by Broadway Bank (Member FDIC), “we’re here for good.” This new piece is a Theatre for Young Audiences play that stresses the importance of cultivating and maintaining a bountiful imagination. It has been devised by a team of thirty undergraduate students (currently attending the University of Texas at Austin), the head of the Theatre Studies program at the University of Texas at Austin Joan Lazarus, graduate of the San Francisco Conservatory of Music Matthew Lyons, professional musicians, Sensory Friendly Performance Advisor leader Deb Alexander, and child-star-in-the-making Emmie Dodson!


Play Synopsis:

During the course of this play we follow a young man who has lost his “Rainbow Connection”, or the connection to his imagination, due to the death of his abuela; the curator of his creativity. As David attempts to rekindle his imaginative spark by rereading an old fairytale told to him by his Grandmother, we see the story-book come to life on stage. Fairies, foxes, armadillos, porcupines, aliens, witches, knights, queens, and dragons storm out of their respective stories to aid David in reestablishing his Rainbow Connection.


Why do we need funding?

Sensory Friendly Performance:

We need to create a safe space for our sensory friendly audience to feel welcome in. This is a space that they can go to when they feel the need to leave or feel uncomfortable during the performance. This space will contain comfortable seating, activities that connect to the play, as well as a live feed of the performance going on.

We will also need to hire an ASL Interpreter for the audience members that are part of the deaf community.

Non-Traditional Theatre Space:

We will be performing in Anna Hiss gym located close to East Dean Keeton street and Speedway. Anna Hiss Gymnasium was created in 1931 and houses an active environment for students to be proactive in maintaining their mental and physical health. We will be utilizing this space for our production. However, since it is a non-traditional theatre space we will be using part of the proceeds to fund the use of risers (for seating) and theatrical lighting; to better envelop, you the audience, into the world of our play.

Musicians:

Under the musical direction of Matthew Lyons, a team of talented musicians plan on having original music composed for the show, act as foley artists, and perform live during each performance. For their efforts, we would like to compensate each musician. The musicians are valued members to our production and we would like to let them know how appreciated they are.  

Community Engagement:

We would like to start an ongoing conversation with our audience and we need the resources to do that. Before we plan on having displays, talkbacks, and reflections, we need the resources to help us research for talkbacks and reflection, and supplies to create the displays.


Why is this important?

The team of Rainbow Connection believes imagination comes in all shapes and sizes. It's never too old to be creative and explore ideas, and it's important for children to understand that imagination never leaves you and should be embraced. This project gives the opportunity for everyone who thinks and learns differently to experience a night of release and fun.


What's in it for you?

You’re supporting a project that’s teaching strong creative lessons to children and people of all ages. In addition, you’re supporting the chance for students to grow and experience in a field that they have big passion for.


How can you help?

Anything helps! We have several rewards for you if you donate a certain amount. If you are unable to donate please feel free to share our fundraiser around on social media. 


Performance Dates: 

April 13 @ 7:30pm
April 15 @ 7:00pm
April 16 @ 8:00pm
April 17 @ 5:30pm (Sensory Friendly Performance) 
All performances are at Anna Hiss Gym at The University of Texas at Austin. 
Reservation System for Tickets will be available soon! We will update everyone when that happens! 

Thanks and see you at the show! 

                     -The Rainbow Connection Cast & Crew

story:
So this...

I wasn't sure I was ever going to produce again. Life. But circumstances have allowed me this incredible 2nd-go-round with a play that is nearest and dearest to my heart. (Yes; I have a heart.)

House of Several Stories (buy your copy today! - SamuelFrench.com) is doing a quick stint at a NYC theatre festival. Like all-things-theatre, that takes money.

What We Need & What You Get

Now, prior to this go-go, I've been creative in this endeavor (*previous,  creative funding will only be revealed in my tell-all autobiography coming not-so-very soon to an e-bookstore near you). And I really thought I had this production in the bag financially. Enter: unexpected costs/events. 

Sound familiar? (If you've ever been a part of a production, or any creative endeavor--yes!) 

And if you've ever been a part of a production, or any creative endeavor, you know that blood, sweat and tears don't feed the chickens. And these unexpected chickens are hungry!

The Team

I've been fortunate to have enlisted a stellar group of people. Actors who I want to keep in my backpack and pull out at any given second of the day. They're glorious gladiators. 

In staying compliant with codes and insurance, extra costs creep up. So this emergency fund will help keep this fast-moving train in motion.
Risks & Challenges

There is no risk on your part for supporting this production. All risk has been taken on by cast & crew (challenges accepted valiantly).

IF you've ever seen HOSS, read HOSS, been a PART of HOSS, and want to help out--I thank you from the bottom of my heart.

If you've ever seen, read, or been a part of HOSS, and hated it? You're probably not reading this anyway.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't feel this is a cause behind which you can stand, I totally respect your decision. All I ask is that you go out some time this week and support someone else's art. (I vote for something local/homegrown/original). I love you all. Back to rehearsals. Back to the hungry chickens.

story:
After RKO's inaugural run of The Rocky Horror Show knocked the pants off Victoria audiences in 2014, Kelly Hudson, Griffin Lea, Sarah Murphy, and Candace Woodland (co-founders of RKO), have jumped at the opportunity to remount the show. We are thrilled to start a local, annual Rocky Horror tradition!

This coming October, we're tackling this sexy monster of a show one more time – only this year, we're making it bigger, brighter, and better. We've added two more performances (for a total of ten!), and we're sculpting the magic that we created last year into a more intricate, more intoxicating, and more impressive show.

Putting on a show of this magnitude takes a lot of work, and a lot of funding. The performance rights to the show cost nearly $10,000 and our theatre rental is $8500. Other costs include costuming, set design and construction, equipment rental, rehearsal space rental, marketing, liquor licensing, and much, much more.

Last year, we were amazed by the generosity of our community, who helped us raise $5000 in order to unleash our first production of The Rocky Horror Show. We are extremely proud to say that every penny of profit went towards paying the actors, technical crew, and creative team that worked so hard on the 2014 show.

We are asking for your help to cover some of the extra costs of expanding our show for the fall of 2015. Our ultimate goals are to provide meaningful opportunities for local artists, and to produce a new, sexier version of The Rocky Horror Show that can become a feature of local Halloween tradition for years to come! 

Every little bit counts. Whether you're able to contribute $10 for a shout out on our Facebook page, or $100 dollars to receive TWO tickets to our show (a value of almost $70!), we are incredibly grateful for your support!

A HUGE thank you to Melissa McNiece for creating our promo video, and to Silva Erglis for taking our promo photos!

story:
I. THE THING ITSELF

Artaud Artaud is the culmination of its author's graduate studies at Columbia. Presented as part of a festival of plays by the Columbia MFA Class of 2015, Artaud Artaud will be performed April 17-18, 2015 at the Ford Studio of the Pershing Square Signature Center in Midtown Manhattan.

For the playwright and his trusty team, Artaud Artaud represents the accumulation of three years' worth of study with teachers and mentors like Charles Mee, Kelly Stuart, Lynn Nottage, Anthony Weigh, and David Henry Hwang (among others), as well as numerous collaborations and small-scale projects on Columbia's stages. This project is a labor of love, a crazy shot in the dark, and (with any luck) a thrilling ride that we hope audiences will join us on for the length of its short run.

I-A. What's It About [?]

Well.

Antonin Artaud is Famous (ish). He's written Books (a few). He's changed The Face of Theatre (mostly). Recently, though, he hasn't been quite himself. Join Monsieur Artaud, along with His Double, His Hapless Doctors, and a Madcap Chorus of characters real and imagined, on a cruel expedition into the darkrooms of the mortal mind. Help him seek truth, shatter illusions, become God, enjoy Chekhov (or die trying), and find a cure for the worst disease of all: being an artist.

I-A. No, But What's It Really About [?]

Artaud was the man behind The Theatre of Cruelty (Théâtre de la Cruauté), a new form of performance that was meant to beat audiences out of their comfort zones. Unsatisfied with all mundane art, Artaud spent much of his life between sanity and psychosis until he was committed to a sanatorium in Rodez, France in the 1940s, where he railed against God and Man. The play explores (or, well, hopes to explore) the bleak-and-blurry borderline between art and life, using the thorny career of Artaud as a springboard to plumb the depths of self-love, self-loathing, and self in general.

Mining Artaud's work for brazen images and big ideas, Artaud Artaud is not a historical document so much as a wild, weird riff on what it means to Be An Artist (or, at least, to want to be one).


II. THE PITCH (aka $$$*, Why?)

To mount this production, Columbia University School of the Arts has generously provided some funding, as well as space for rehearsal and performance. The purpose of this campaign is, in fact, not to raise money to build more or buy more, but to raise funds with which to pay the many talented individuals who are giving their blood, sweat, and tears (well, time and creativity) to this process.

We believe strongly that the hard-earned time of our fellow artists is worth something. From those on the stage to those managing it to those putting hats on heads and props in hand, there are a ton of people in the mix helping this team get this play on its feet. Your donation will help us reimburse those people for their hard work. 

*pronounced: moolah


III. THE PEOPLE (aka Who's Askin')

Written by Matthew Minnicino, Directed by Julia Sears, and Produced by Elizabeth Goodman, with Production Stage Management by Jenny Ainsworth*. Dramaturgy by Adrienne Sowers, Sound Design and Original Composition by Joey Shaw, Costumes by Annie Simon, Lights by Jennifer Reiser, Set by Christopher Cancel-Pomales, Music Direction by Julia Anrather, Movement by Sarah Stites, and Graphic Design by Nik Aliye.

featuring performances by Matthew Bovee, Sean Devare, Paul Eddy, Karen Eilbacher, Patrick Harvey, Rebecca Hirota*, Michael John Improta, Victoria Nassif, Jessica Vera*, and Emma Walton

*appearing courtesy of the Actors' Equity Association


IV. THE SHOW (aka Come See It)

After donating (thank you!), the Big Next Step is to come see the show.

Artaud Artaud gets a limited run at The Signature Theatre on the following dates.

FRIDAY, APRIL 17th at 3:00pm

FRIDAY, APRIL 17th at 8:00pm

SATURDAY, APRIL 18th at 2:30pm

Tickets will be made available through Columbia Stages' website.

THE SHOW (aka Come See It)After donating (thank you!), the Big Next Step is to come see the show.Artaud Artaud gets a limited run at The Signature Theatre on the following dates.FRIDAY, APRIL 17th at 3:00pmFRIDAY, APRIL 17th at 8:00pmSATURDAY, APRIL 18th at 2:30pmTickets will be made available through Columbia Stages' website.

story:
TWO Original and Amazing Shows.  TWO hours of original live performances.  1 VERY LOW ticket price.

AOJ: Fact or Fiction 

A show 6 years in the making-literally!   Very dear to our hearts, and based off a true story, comes a show that gives you an inside look at the cut-throat mentality of the Los Angeles Theatre Scene.  As the play opens, Scott and Sam are having a grand old time, when Scott announces that he is starting a theatre company.  The wild success of his first two-shows lead him down a dark path.   The prideful always tend to fall.  In a real coming-of-age story off true life, Scott must confess and deal with  Sexual addiction, backstabbing and deceit, and even enter hibernation to one-day re-emerge on top. Does he succeed?   Only time will tell. The facts presented in the story are undisputed, the controversy this is sure to to spark some among some and hot debates and topics with others.  The show is different every-time you see it as Audience suggestion will dictate how each scene of facts is presented through an improv-style format, intertwined with Dialogue of Facts.   


3... 2.. 1. ON FIRE!

3... 2.. 1. ON FIRE! is our signature, bread and butter event. A high energy, high-octane hybrid Improv and Burlesque extravaganza.   Our female and male burlesque dancers are ready to spark your imagination and desires, while our improv troupe is ready to ignite your laughter.  Who ever dreamed that these two will play out in such a way that they will always go together as peanut butter and jelly? We did; and you would not believe how good it tastes!   This particular version of 3... 2.. 1. ON FIRE while be 30-45 minutes, and is meant to give you a taste of our full length shows, which is our signature show for the collective, performing every 2nd and 4th Friday at TU Studios in North Hollywood..  


What Your Love-Donation will Represent

We are hoping to raise $1500 in hopes that we can bring two projects we are very passionate about to the Hollywood Fringe, Here is where the money will be allocated:

  • $250 will be for our Fringe application fee.
  • $1200 will be going to our theatre rental for the Fringe Festival at our two locations: The Asylum & Studio-Stage.
  • $50 will go to a special event night we are hosting for all of our donors.


Can't Spread the Love Today?

Please know even just $1 will go a long way towards reaching our goal, we would be grateful for even that!  We know some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • Help us with our fundraising partnership with Audiences Unlimited! We have several upcoming dates where you can attend (for free) a live taping of a hit TV show, and by you coming, we get paid from them!  No money of yours is required.  Let us know if you can join us!
  • Help us spread the love by getting the word out about the campaign - maybe you know someone we don't that can donate!

Help us spread the love by getting the word out about the campaign - maybe you know someone we don't that can donate!

story:
The London Short Play Festival is back for its second year and this year we have four brand new short plays and a fantastic new venue!

The festival offers the opportunity for new and aspiring  playwrights to have their writing performed professionally in London. 

This will be the first time the four selected plays are performed in front of a live audience and we have a bunch of talented actors and directors involved, helping them come alive.

The festival will run on the 16th, 17th and 18th of July 2015 at The Edric Theatre in Southwark, London. It is very easy to find and is a short walk from Southwark station. Other near by tubes include Borough, Elephant and Castle, and Waterloo.


Why do we need your help?

We have already secured our venue, playwrights, directors and cast which means that the major aspects of the festival has been taken care of. Now we just need to raise some additional funds for the essential marketing materials. This will allow us to spread the word about the festival and its importance . Anything we raise above the costs for marketing materials will go towards the cast and crew to ensure they get what they deserve in return for their hard work. 

Our chosen plays:

We were absolutely inundated with short plays this year, receiving an astonishing amount of very engaging, creative and well varied scripts! Eventually, after much debate, we decided on the four plays that will be showcased in the festival this year. The four plays chosen are:

- 'The Heir' written by Jasmine Brown. Directed by Brigitte Adela.

-'The Way To A Mans Heart' written by David Weir. Directed by Maahin Akhlaque.

-'Blast From The Past' written and directed by Anna-Lisa Maree.

-'Fallen Apple' written by Bethan Highgate-Betts. Directed by Zoe Fidel.


Why should you support our festival?

The London Short Play Festival was created to give new opportunities to artists and playwrights. We are passionate about giving talented people an opportunity to work in a supportive environment to develop and explore their craft whilst also getting the chance to perform in front of a live audience. The festival is none profit and any money made is put back into the running of the festival. We hope that these new stories will brighten up the London theatre scene and give YOU the most exciting night out in July. 

We have some great perks in return for your support, don't forget to check them out! With your kind generosity we can make this festival reach new heights!


For further updates, information and all things creative, feel free to check us out on our official website and social media sites.

Official website:

http://www.londonshortplayfestival.com/about-us.html

Facebook page:

https://www.facebook.com/TheLondonShortPlayFestival

Twitter page: 

https://twitter.com/Short_Play_Fest



psst!! If you want a reminder we did some crowdfunding last year as well. Here's the link if you want to refresh your mind: https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/270366062/...

story:
About CEMA dance & Rachel Hagan

CEMA dance is a project-based dance company founded by choreographer and dancer, Rachel Hagan, in December 2013 with FOUR MAIN FOCUSES:

Collaboration. Exploration. Movement. Artists.
Artistic Director, Rachel Hagan, trained at New York University's Tisch School of the Arts following her pre-professional training at Pittsburgh Ballet Theatre. Since founding CEMA, Rachel's work has been performed in New York at Dance NOW NYC's Raw Festival, NYU's Skirball Center for the Performing Arts, Judson Memorial Church, Gowanus Loft, the Center for Performance Research, Gowanus Art + Production, Ailey Citigroup, Triskelion Arts, and at Tisch's Fifth Floor Theater.
CEMA reached a major milestone in October 2014 in creating their first evening-length work and is excited to be reaching another major milestone with our first tour!

Our Expenses & Your Perks

Your contributions help us to create performances that open dialogue and allow us to connect with the New Orleans art community. You will help to provide working artists with a new opportunity to perform and to expose their work and teaching to a new audience!

What we need:

  • Flight and local travel expenses
  • Food Expenses
  • Housing Accomodations
  • Rehearsal and Performance Space Rentals
  • Lighting design and equipment
  • Costuming
  • Event Insurance
  • Artist Fees for dancers and collaborators
  • Film and Video Documentation
  • Marketing
We're saying thank you for your support with everything from social media shout outs, exclusive content, and tickets to the show! You're support fosters a strong environment for young, working artists and is greatly appreciated!

Our Experience

With the New Orleans tour, CEMA dance, will have successfully self-produced 3 evenings of work in under 2 years in addition to having been presented in several other venues throughout the New York Metro area. We have learned a lot along the way and have the experience to use contributions efficiently and to the benefit of the artists involved.

Risks & Challenges

Our biggest risk is a financial one. It's very important to CEMA to continue to connect with new communities, new artists, and new ideas. Our first tour is a way to expose new audiences to our work and to also learn from new experiences and collaborations. Your generous contributions help us do so successfully!

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share our campaign! One of the most important ways we will reach our goal is by getting the word out. 
  • Come see our show! We'd love to meet you, hear about your artistic endeavors, and share our work! Check out what we've been working on!
  • Connect with us! We want to get to know you. Keep up wish CEMA's preparation for performances and share your work with us too.
Facebook
Instagram

story:
Short Summary

Belgrade English Language Theatre is a youth theatre based in Belgrade, Serbia. Now in it's 7th year BelTheatre now has over 80 members aged from 7 to 19 years of age. As part of our commitment to our young people's artistic, educational and personal development we have organised a visit for 11 of our young members to visit the Theatre Royal in Bath's Egg Youth theatre in order to spend time together with their members sharing their experiences, opinions and experiences through a series of creative workshops.

What We Need & What You Get

We have been working very hard over the last three months to raise the money required for this exciting opportunity. Through a number of generous actions donations from a wide range of people we have raised to date almost 3000 pounds towards the 3500 pounds required to make this trip a reality.

In the coming weeks, until our departure on the 23rd of May, we will be doing everything we can to raise the final 500 pounds and this is where any help you can offer would be gratefully appreciated.

The money raised will go straight to paying for our accommodation in Bath, which in itself totals over 1800 pounds. If we are lucky enough exceed our goal we will put the money towards arranging another excursion or two for the group while they are in the UK. 

    The Impact

    For young people living anywhere in the world, one of the greatest opportunities they can be offered for learning and development is travel and the chance to meet and interact with people from other cultures.

    For many different reasons many young people will never be given the opportunity to compare there own understandings of the world with others in a meaningful way, and we wish to change that for a handful of young people from Belgrade, Serbia.

    This project is the fourth time that BelTheatre has organised such a trip (following trips to Croatia, Italy and the Czech Republic) and on each occasion we would not have been able to do so without the generosity and fundraising efforts of members and friends.

    Organising a trip to the UK is extra complicated and expensive due to the fact that each young person must secure a visa, which in itself costs 90 pounds (with no guarantee of it being awarded). But we are determined that despite the financial and  bureaucratic challenges we will make this opportunity a reality.

      Risks & Challenges

      The most challenging aspect of this project is undoubtedly the bureaucracy involved with the visa system. Unlike all other European countries, the UK and Ireland still require people from Serbia to go through a humiliating and stressful procedure in order to enter the UK, even if these people are below the age of 18 and involved in a creative/educational programme. 

      BelTheatre is a very active but relatively small organisation with only one full-time member of staff supported by 3 other dedicated part-timers. We are proud of our track record of opening up educational and creative opportunities to local young people and doing so without making the costs of such initiatives prohibitive.

      We continue to do this because we see the benefit that such activities have on young people's lives (both our own members and those we visit). 

      Other Ways You Can Help

      Even if you cannot support this project financially, we would ask you to share this information to as wide a group of people as you can , because believe us when we tell you, every pound raised makes a huge difference to our efforts and will encourage us to continue our efforts both now and in the future.

story:
We reached our goal!

Thanks to your incredible support we reached our goal in just 2 days, and all of our stretch goals. What an amazing community - thank you for your support.

We're opening a studio

We're opening Victoria's first dedicated improv studio, Paper Street Studio at 1109 Fort St. 

It's a place for us to teach improv classes, to bring in celebrity improvisers from out of town, and to hold intimate shows. Plus, it'll be home to our theatre company, Paper Street Theatre, now in our fourth season.

Our dream is to support and grow the improv community in Victoria.

We need your help

Now, we need your help to buy the things that make it a studio:

  • $2000 for new, fire resistant curtains
  • $2500 for lighting and sound equipment
  • $1700 for new chairs
  • $1000 for signage
  • $800 for custom made bar/box office

All of the money raised will go towards purchasing these items for the studio. These items will help turn this space into a vibrant learning and performance venue.

Stretch Goals

At $9,000 - Increased Capacity - REACHED!
We will replace the back door with a proper fire exit door to try to increase our capacity. 

At $10,000 - Free Show - REACHED! 
Paper Street Theatre is hosting a huge free show at the Victoria Event Centre on June 30th. 

At $12,000 - Paper Street Scholarship - REACHED!
We will create an annual scholarship for one young improviser to take all of Paper Street's classes.

The Dream

This is just the beginning. Dave's been teaching classes in Victoria for 6 years, we've been running Paper Street Theatre for 4 years. We're committed to Victoria, and we're excited about the future. 

Your help now will help us build a strong foundation for Paper Street Studio. 

Spread the Word

Our studio is still new, and we need your help to spread the word: 

  • Share this campaign on Facebook and Twitter
  • Tell your friends about the studio
  • Take a class!

And come by and visit Dave in the studio, we'd love to show it to you.

story:
*UPDATE* 7.20.15

News flash: We have some incredible backers!! In just 11 days, we're already 75% to our fundraising goal! Thank you all for your help! Check our latest update under the "Updates" tab to learn how funds raised in excess of our goal will be used.

We've added a trailer containing some rehearsal footage with only mini-mini spoilers (we promise) and there's some early puppet design sketches in our latest update.

Again, thank you all so much! Please continue to spread the word about the show and we hope to see you at the performance!


What is MATERIALIZE?

MATERIALIZE is a full puppet production having it's world premiere this August at the Maryland Ensemble Theatre in Frederick, MD.

Who are we? We are a team of 14 artists putting together an original show that delves into our human need to figure out who we really are and understand the masks we wear to hide ourselves.

This show originated in the need to create a theatre piece that responded to current social events in a universal way. Through conversations and collecting stories both personal and public, the piece has become an exploration on themes of invisibility, identity, dehumanization and objectification.  These collected stories will be adapted into a series of puppet scenes into a more simplified, visual language that speaks to universal human emotions and behaviors.

What's most exciting for us is to see what audiences will take away from this show, viewers can project their own ​experience​ onto what's ​happen​ing onstage. Our hope is through these pieces, audiences will recognize their own hopes, fears, and ultimately see that the story unfolding onstage is their own.​



Show Synopsis:

What masks do you wear? Do you feel at home in your skin or do others affect how you feel about yourself? Materialize is an original piece presented as a collection of scenes told through puppetry. Inspired by and created from real-life stories, Materialize explores how we grapple with identity, invisibility, objectification, dehumanization, and realization. Let your mask slide... you might see your true self appear.

What We Need & What You Get

Your donation will:

  • Pay for costume, lighting, puppet, and set supplies.

  • Pay for media and promotional materials: posters, fliers, and advertisements to spread the word about "MATERIALIZE."

  • Help compensate our ensemble of artists.


In return, we've got some awesome perks for you:

    • "Strings:" $10 to $49 - Your name in our program and a facebook shout-out
    • "Marionette:" $50 to $99 - All "Strings" plus a MATERIALIZE poster signed by the cast
    • "Shadow:" $100 to $249 - All "Strings" perks plus 2 tickets to MATERIALIZE* and an original self-puppet sketch based on you (!) by director Vanessa Strickland
    • "Mask:" $250 or more - All "Strings" perks plus 2 drink vouchers, 2 tickets to MATERIALIZE* and an original, custom-made mask designed by director Vanessa Strickland.
    • "Bunraku:" $500 or more - All "Strings" perks, plus plus 2 drink vouchers, 2 tickets to MATERIALIZE* and a 90-minute puppet workshop hosted at the MET or within 50 miles of the theatre (up to 10 participants).

      *There are 6 performances between Aug 14-23, 2015

The Impact

How will your contributions make a difference?  This is the very FIRST all-puppet production produced at the MET. By donating, you'll be:

  • Funding a world-premiere of an original production
  • Expanding our repertoire for creating thought-provoking works
  • Empowering our artists by providing compensation for their creativity and labor
  • Fostering the creation of new, compelling, theatre
  • Increasing the visibility of up-and-coming theatre professionals
  • Creating a work of art

In return, we offer an engaging, visually and emotionally rich show featuring a cast and crew of professional artists recognized for their talent and teamwork.

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't spare anything fiscally, but want to help out? Great! Here's how you can lend us a hand:

  • Share our IndieGogo campaign by using the "Share" tools below, or Copy + Paste our link: http://igg.me/at/MATERIALIZE to help us get the word out about our campaign!
  • Come check us out! Attend our performance of MATERIALIZE this August 14-23rd, 2015 at the MET: https://marylandensemble.thundertix.com/events/69907

See what else Maryland Ensemble Theatre is up to:

- On facebook: https://www.facebook.com/MarylandEnsemble

- On twitter @MDEnsemble

- Our site: marylandensemble.org

- YouTube: youtube.com/user/marylandensemble
story_txt:
*UPDATE* 7.20.15
News flash: We have some incredible backers!! In just 11 days, we're already 75% to our fundraising goal! Thank you all for your help! Check our latest update under the "Updates" tab to learn how funds raised in excess of our goal will be used.We've added a trailer containing some rehearsal footage with only mini-mini spoilers (we promise) and there's some early puppet design sketches in our latest update.Again, thank you all so much! Please continue to spread the word about the show and we hope to see you at the performance!What is MATERIALIZE?
MATERIALIZE is a full puppet production having it's world premiere this August at the Maryland Ensemble Theatre in Frederick, MD.
Who are we? We are a team of 14 artists putting together an 
original show that delves into our human need to figure out who we 
really are and understand the masks we wear to hide ourselves.
This show originated in the need to create a theatre piece that 
responded to current social events in a universal way. Through 
conversations and collecting stories both personal and public, the piece
 has become an exploration on themes of invisibility, identity, 
dehumanization and objectification.  These collected stories will be 
adapted into a series of puppet scenes into a more simplified, visual 
language that speaks to universal human emotions and behaviors.
What's most exciting for us is to see what audiences will take
 away from this show, viewers can project their own ​experience​ onto 
what's ​happen​ing onstage. Our hope is through these pieces, audiences 
will recognize their own hopes, fears, and ultimately see that the story
 unfolding onstage is their own.​

   Show Synopsis:

What masks do you wear? Do you feel at home in your 
skin or do others affect how you feel about yourself? Materialize is an 
original piece presented as a collection of scenes told through 
puppetry. Inspired by and created from real-life stories, Materialize 
explores how we grapple with identity, invisibility, objectification, 
dehumanization, and realization. Let your mask slide... you might see 
your true self appear.
What We Need & What You Get



Your donation will:









Pay for costume, lighting, puppet, and set supplies.


















Pay for media and promotional materials: posters, fliers, and advertisements to spread the word about "MATERIALIZE."


































Help compensate our ensemble of artists.






In return, we've got some awesome perks for you:


"Strings:" $10 to $49 - Your name in our program and a facebook shout-out


"Marionette:" $50 to $99 - All "Strings" plus a MATERIALIZE poster signed by the cast


"Shadow:" $100 to $249 - All "Strings" perks plus 2 tickets to MATERIALIZE* and an original self-puppet sketch based on you (!) by director Vanessa Strickland


"Mask:" $250 or more - All "Strings" perks plus 2 drink vouchers, 2 tickets to MATERIALIZE* and an original, custom-made mask designed by director Vanessa Strickland.


"Bunraku:" $500 or more - All "Strings" perks, plus plus 2 drink vouchers, 2 tickets to MATERIALIZE* and a 90-minute puppet workshop hosted at the MET or within 50 miles of the theatre (up to 10 participants).*There are 6 performances between Aug 14-23, 2015




The Impact 

How will your contributions make a difference?  This is the very FIRST all-puppet production produced at the MET. By donating, you'll be:

Funding a world-premiere of an original production
Expanding our repertoire for creating thought-provoking works
Empowering our artists by providing compensation for their creativity and labor
Fostering the creation of new, compelling, theatre
Increasing the visibility of up-and-coming theatre professionals
Creating a work of art

In return, we offer an engaging, visually and emotionally rich show featuring a cast and crew of professional artists recognized for their talent and teamwork.
  Other Ways You Can Help 
Can't spare anything fiscally, but want to help out? Great! Here's how you can lend us a hand:

Share our IndieGogo campaign by using the "Share" tools below, or Copy + Paste our link: http://igg.me/at/MATERIALIZE to help us get the word out about our campaign!

Come check us out! Attend our performance of MATERIALIZE this August 14-23rd, 2015 at the MET: https://marylandensemble.thundertix.com/events/69907


See what else Maryland Ensemble Theatre is up to:
- On facebook: https://www.facebook.com/MarylandEnsemble
- On twitter @MDEnsemble
- Our site: marylandensemble.org
- YouTube: youtube.com/user/marylandensemble

story:
Summary of Gianni Schicchi

Puccini's comedic One Act Opera is filled with forbidden romance, greed and all around hilarious romp.  When the Donati family's patriarch dies, his entire family swarms like vultures to collect on his will.  Upon arriving, they discover that he most likely left his entire fortune to a monastery.  This forces the family to reach out to Gianni Schicchi and beg his help to impersonate Buoso Donati so he can change the will.  High-jinks ensue in this clever, fun and upbeat one act that will be performed by all Northwestern students.

What We Need to Get the Show Up and Running!

  • Every amount donated to this production will contribute to each aspect of performance from costumes, sets, lighting and possibly a string quartet.
  • As a completely student run production, every donation helps promote independent student opera at Northwestern!  A new and exciting frontier at the Bienen School of Music.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you cannot donate we ask that you share this link with all of your friends and family to get us closer to our goal!  All publicity is good publicity!  Indiegogo share tools make it easy to pass along the word.

And that's all there is to it!

Thank you!

-The Cast & Crew of Gianni Schicchi

story:
Bittersweet Arts Co. 

About us

Bittersweet Arts Co. is a collective of multi-talented artists whose unique ambitions and spirits are brought together through their love of experimentation and creative expression. 

Alex Fortune (Playwright) is a playwright and company member of Bittersweet Arts Co. Alex's play "the hat-walk" was recently featured in Horizon Theatre's New South Young Playwrights Festival and in Good Zoo at Bittersweet Arts Co. Originally from Whately, Massachusetts and a recent graduate of Columbia College Chicago, Alex is interested in human expansion, the nature of conversation, and doors.

Anthony L. Gervais (Director) is an director, writer, and actor, who recently relocated to Chicago. He is originally from St. Petersburg, Florida, where he first discovered his passion for the arts. He is thrilled to be a part of this developmental process, and to collaborate with such wonderful artists on new material. Previous directing credits include Someone Who'll Watch Over Me and Vesuvius, as well as The Girl Down the Hall and The Joy of Life, which he also wrote. Anthony is a proud graduate of The Boston Conservatory. 

Alexis Allotta (Actor) is a Columbia College Chicago graduate, proud company member of Bittersweet Arts Co., “Nikki Black” in Tony N Tina’s Wedding at Chicago Theatre Works and an overall lover of all things covered in cheese. She couldn’t be more ecstatic to be apart of the debut of Alex “Words Guy” Fortune’s Forsythian Dwellers Club.

Dylan Barlowe (Actor) is a recent graduate from Columbia College Chicago (BA in Acting). He is also a proud member of Bittersweet Arts Co. You may have recently seen him in BAC's productions of Good Zoo and The Spookening, Dramatists Guilds' Banned Together: A Censorship Cabaret or The Runaways Lab festival Doing Drugs And Dying In Space. He plans to use theatre and other arts as a universal language to connect different cultures nationally as well as internationally.

David Stobbe (Actor) is a year out of college and has been working on shows across Chicago and developing his ideas through the Bittersweet. Currently, he can be seen in a durational performance at the MCA in Chicago. He was recently seen as Rosencrantz in Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are Dead At Metropolis Performing Arts Centre, at Stage Left theater's Leap-Fest, and Porchlight MT's New Faces Sing 1969. He's grateful for have a group of weirdos to be weird with.

Henry Weisel (Actor) Henry Weisel is an actor, writer, and visual artist hailing from the southern Vermont area. He is a passionate and dedicated member of the Bittersweet Arts Company, and has used his time in this ensemble to explore playwriting and more experimental themes of theatre inspired by Dadaism and the Absurd.

Forsythian Dweller's Club

About the play

 

Join The Club!

Where we could use your help -

This is our first full length production, and we could use a little help. We are producing Forsythian Dweller's Club on a minimal budget. Most of our costs come from practical needs, such as setting and lighting, as well as printing posters and programs.

Your contribution will be directly supporting the creation of a new play, bringing audiences a weekend of innovative theatre in an intimate setting.

What You Get!

We are offering a variety of perks, including admission to a performance and a personalized, handwritten thank you note. In the spirit of the show, we have secret perks available at the highest level. Want to know more? Donate today, or come check us out!

What Else Can I Do?

Can't make a donation! No problem! There are other ways to help!

  • Share this page with your family, friends, and on facebook!
  • Come see us! Forsythian Dweller's Club runs December 14-17 at the Bittersweet Clubhouse!

story:
“Women are defective by nature.”

- Aristotle; the “Father of Western philosophy,” and one of feminism’s biggest headaches

 

up your aesthetic is a piece of nontraditional theater that engages with the stories of the mythic Amazon warriors and reclaims them through ritualized retelling. Like so many of our contemporaries, we are exhausted by the male domination of the Western theater canon and its antiquated Ancient Greek roots (thanks, Aristotle). This show was born of our need to take a piece of that history, inject it with modern rage and grief, and share that effect with our audiences. The title, up your aesthetic, cheekily encapsulates this dual vision by amalgamating Valerie Solanas’ radical feminist play Up Your Ass and Aristotle’s original treatise on aesthetics, Poetics.

up your aesthetic began as a Senior Capstone project at Wesleyan University, and became a passion project. When the original run of the show finished last April, we knew that closing night could not mark its final performance. Anyone who saw it can attest: this piece needs to be performed again. A little over a year later, the company is reuniting to tour the piece around the Northeast and present it at Capital Fringe in Washington DC, and we are asking for your help to make it possible.

Tour Dates:

  • Brandon, VT // July 8
  • Cambridge, NY // July 9-10
  • Philadelphia, PA // July 13-14
  • Washington, DC// July 22-29 (as part of Capital Fringe)

The up your aesthetic team is:

  • Jess Cummings, Constance Des Marais, Katherine Paterson, Cheyanne Williams, Ensemble
  • Nola Werlinich, Production Designer
  • Chloe Briskin, Stage Manager
  • Megumi Lee, Producer/Production Manager
  • Torii Johnson, Graphic Design/Marketing
  • Maia Nelles-Sager, Videography/Marketing

 

Budget Breakdown

Through up your aesthetic, we are striving to make theater that is critical and engaging for our audiences. This work is not possible without support from our audiences and communities. Every dollar donated will be stretched to the fullest to provide audiences with well produced, thoughtful, and evocative theater.

Your donation will go towards:

  • artist stipends to aid in the financial burden of touring
  • fees that are required for participating in Capital Fringe 2018
  • getting the word out there through our marketing campaign
  • costumes to clothe us, a set for us to play on, props for us to engage with, and lights so you can see our smiling faces
  • transportation for us and our production elements
  • a space to rehearse our show

Future

We are hoping that Capital Fringe and our other performances in the Northeast this summer will serve as stepping stones for further development and presentation of the piece. As the climate of our country changes, as well as our own experiences, grow and change, we find the need to continue to delve deeper into this material and develop these narratives that feel relevant today more than ever. We also aim to present this piece to different audiences in different cities across the country in hopes to develop a pointed yet accessible piece of theater.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you saw up your aesthetic in its previous incarnations, share this campaign on social media!

Come see us perform on tour!

Follow us on social media for more details about showtimes and ticket sales!

story:
Hey There!

My name is Carolyn and I want to become an OULA Fitness Instructor!  I attended AMDA (American Musical Dramatics Academy) where I learned Ballet, Jazz and Tap!  The reason I choose OULA is because it focuses not on just cardio, but building strength in muscles and your loving heart.
I've taken Zumba, Cardio Latin, and various fitness dance classes, but this program is different.  I feel connected to it and feel I would be a fantastic leader for anyone to get there "sexy" on and their sweat out!

What I'm Requesting

$500

Truthfully, I need $300 dollars to be certified, but Indie Go Go said I can only do $500 as a minimum. (wah wah waaaah) I don't need all of that!  

 To make it fair and reasonable I'm donating the rest to Christy Hughes Kairos Fund!  This helps our Alma Mater- St. Monica Catholic High School.  To sum it up it also helps families pay for their kids to go to a wonderful experience called "KAIROS".  LIVE THE FOURTH (wink wink)

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't donate, that's fine.  Please share with others if you believe in my request. 


Thank you for reading!

Lots of Love,

Carolyn

story:
Why Donate?

Each donation goes directly into the Funhouse III budget and is spit right back out at ya in the form of experimental live theatre. Your contribution allows the us to provide you, the audience, with a high-quality theatrical experience unlike any other, while also providing a safe environment for theatre artists from all backgrounds to experiment and dismantle traditional notions of what theatre can be.

The more money we raise, the higher quality costumes, makeup, sets, props, and overall experience we can provide. By supporting Funhouse, you are supporting art, artists, creativity, innovation, and iconoclasm. Also, you get a cool t-shirt!

 

Where Your Donation Goes:

Space: It costs a whole heck of a lot of money to rent out a theatre for a weekend, not to mention rehearsal space. That rehearsal space really adds up.
Stipends: Call us entitled millennials, but we think artists deserve to be paid for their work. 
Costumes/Hair/Makeup: Our costume/hair/makeup designer is named Erika and she is an actual witch whose primary power is doing incredible things with limited resources, which means that if we're able to expand her resources HOLY MOLY IMAGINE THE POSSIBILITIES.
Sets/Props: We want this show to look good for you. You deserve a good-looking show. Let us give you that.
Future Funhouses: We operate on a non-profit business model, which means that all donations and ticket proceeds not used for Funhouse III will be used for Funhouse IV, V, VI, and BEYOND!! We have a lot of spreadsheets and graphs we can show you to illustrate Funhouse's upward trajectory throughout the first three shows, if you're interested. Let us know. We'll send you the documents.

 

Risks & Challenges

We get it. Theatre is a dying art form. Why go see a live show when you could binge-watch the new season of Narcos from the comfort of your couch? BECAUSE LIFE IS ABOUT EXPERIENCES, THAT'S WHY. And because this isn't just some boring Edward Albee play (full disclosure: we love Edward Albee, but you get the point). We guarantee you're going to walk away from Funhouse feeling different. In a good way. Like when you tried schnapps for the first time. But without the puke. There actually might be some puke, but it will be on-stage. And it will be fake puke. You will not come into contact with any actual puke. Let's see Narcos make you feel like THAT.

 

Other Ways to Help

You are more than a wallet to us. Here are some other ways you can help us out:

  • Come see the show! Funhouse III runs April 26-28 at the Slate Theater in Seattle.
  • Follow us on Facebook, and Instagram, and YouTube.
  • Tell people about us! Share this page with anyone who would be interested!

story:
I'm Alison Ruth, the director and producer of FÉMINAAL. This play, and Nina Morrison's writing in general, opened my eyes to a brave new world of drama: a feminist theater that is bold, daring, and hilarious. Nina's theater rejects the notion that we must "hold the mirror up to nature" and embraces a non-patriarchal landscape of women in power. 

 

Her work is also hilarious, entertaining, and super funsy. 

What We Need

It is expensive to put on a production! Your generous support will help fund:

  • Technical fees
  • Rental costs
  • Artist compensation
  • Scenic and visual construction
  • Costume design
  • Promotion and Marketing
  • Lighting and Sound 

Why this play now?

FÉMINAAL brings us the entrance of a powerful new voice to the Minneapolis theater scene. The play amplifies women's voices in an entertaining and illuminating manner.  A production of FÉMINAAL is a timely necessity for artists and audiences in the Twin Cities. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share this campaign with your friends! Spreading the word is very helpful! Thank you!
