story:
GREAT KILLS In A Nutshell

Great Kills is an original play by Tom Diriwachter running March 26th to April 12th, 2015 in New York City (tickets available here).  Reflecting the big-time aspirations of small-timers in Staten Island, this darkly comic play tells the tale of a get-rich-quick scheme gone awry, and has as its themes, family, addiction, mental health, and the dissolution of the working class.  

The production will be directed by Jonathan Weber and stars Joe Pantoliano, Peter Welch, and Robert Homeyer.  It is being produced by Obie Award and Pulitzer Prize winning Theater for the New City, and brought to you by PRIME Stage to Screen- a newly formed theatrical company, whose mission is to bring new American plays to the stage, as well as high quality, independent screen adaptations of these plays to the screen soon after.  Bearing the play's theme of working class dissolution in mind, another major aspect of PRIME'S mission is to bring its productions to audiences for a price the working class can afford- something that is often missing in the American Theater today.


Why Support GREAT KILLS

As Great Kills marks PRIME'S first production, it is essential we raise appropriate capital for its success.  We've already been successful at attracting the Emmy Award winning actor Joe Pantoliano (The Sopranos, Memento, The Matrix) to be in our very first production (no small feat even for a veteran theater company).  Now we need your support to meet the our maiden production's financial needs.  

 While we are grateful to Theater for the New City for producing Great Kills, there is still a significant expense, including set design, marketing, promotion, support staff, and artists' salaries, that falls to the production team.  Your contribution shows your appreciation, helps to lessen the burden, and assures that there will be more stories from PRIME Stage to Screen in the future.

Starting something from scratch is always the most challenging undertaking in the arts, but when launched successfully, it's also the most rewarding.  Your support will make you an integral part of this brand new undertaking, and will also make you part of something that you'll be able to look back on five or ten years from now and say "I helped make that happen!"


Our MULTIPLES OF TEN Campaign

The goal for our Great Kills' funding campaign is extremely simple, and yet, extremely ambitious.  We seek to raise $10,000 in 10 days, through contributions of $10, $100, and $1000.  Not only that, we are starting this campaign 10 days before our official opening date on March 28th (with previews on the 26th & 27th).  In other words this campaign will close on the very night we open!  

At the heart of our campaign is the kind of support that almost anyone can afford, which is why we think we can pull this off despite the short window.  

With this in mind our primary goal is to attract 1,000 donors to give just $10 each (1,000 X $10=$10,000).  This way, like PRIME'S ticket prices, no ones' pocketbook is over burdened.  Also, by reaching out to 1,000 donors at $10, as opposed to 10 donors at $1,000, we connect with a much larger contingent of supporters- something we feel is crucial to building a community based theatrical company.  

Of course if you can afford to give more please don't hesitate to click the $100 or $1,000 buttons, as all new ventures can use the help of deep pocketed angels.  But if all you can do is $10, GREAT, because that's all we're really looking from any of you- All 1,000 OF YOU THAT IS!!! 

Our contributor categories are as follows:

"Friend"

$10 Contribution

We call this "friend," because it's like hitting up a friend for ten bucks.  Like we said this contribution is at the heart of our fundraising campaign, because... where would we be without our friends.  Be a friend, and we'll thank you with a shout out in the playbill, and on our Facebook page.

"Contributor"

$100 Contribution

You can make a real difference with a hundred dollar contribution.  This might sound like a lot, but you get a lot in return.  As a contributor, you'll get the above plus two reserved seating tickets to the show ($40 value), and a one-sheet (poster), signed by the cast, director, and playwright.

"Patron"

$1000 Contribution

Be a patron of the arts for a grand.  As a patron, you'll be fitted in the style you deserve.  Patrons receive a playbill/Facebook "Patron Thank You," reserved seating tickets for your group (up to eight), a framed one-sheet (poster), signed by the cast, director, and playwright, and an invitation to the cast party, where you'll have your picture taken with the cast and crew.

However, if we don't reach our funding goal of $10,000, your contributions will still be an enormous help.  By taking at least some of the burden off our shoulders, your funds will free us to make this inaugural production the success we know it can be, and ensure a future for our company. 


Other Ways YOU Can Help Us


We know not everyone can afford the $10 donation.  But please don't worry, as there are other ways you can help. 

First and foremost come to see Great Kills during its New York run (tickets available here).  That's the reason we're doing this in the first place, for our audience, and nothing would make us happier than to see you sitting out there!

Another way to help would be to tell all your friends about the show.  We're hoping to sell out as many dates as possible, so if you could spread the word that there's a chance to see the legendary Joey Pants in a small intimate theater for only $20, please don't hesitate to do so!

Lastly, please share our indiegogo campaign to your friends, either through email or on social media (please like our facebook page).  We live in an age of the Viral sensation, and if you could help us spread the word about Great Kills and everything else we're trying to do at PRIME it would be an enormous boost!

As Umberto Eco said: "To survive, you must tell stories."  Self-reflection is at the heart of our humanity.  It is how we remember the past, consider the present, and move toward the future.  The artist assumes this challenge for society, examining life, and presenting it for your entertainment.  The independent artist gives voice to personal and variant stories that might not otherwise be heard.  This is a burden that comes with great effort, and personal sacrifice.  Those involved in Great Kills will see no profit for their efforts, instead, they are motivated by passion, and find their satisfaction in telling this story.    

This is why we founded PRIME Stage to Screen, and why we hope you'll find it necessary to support us in anyway you can.

story:
What is Fragments?

Fragments is a play in development, written by Geraldine Inoa, about three African American mental patients in a psychiatric ward. Each character reveals the anguish and devastation that brought them to the hospital. The stories they share are
desperate attempts to reclaim their existence and cope with their suffering. The characters question the value of psychiatric care and engage in discussions that provide insight into the lives of those who suffer from mental illness.

The play was first conceived as a one act in 2013, during Geraldine's studies at NYU's Gallatin School of Individualized Study. Since then it has been produced as a full length play at the inaugural New Works festival at HUB-BUB in South Carolina. This reading marks a return to New York City for Fragments after the expansion of the piece.

What We Need & What You Get

The goal of this campaign is to raise $500 for the reading. 40 to 50 percent of this goal will go directly towards the performance space of the reading. The rest of the funds raised will go towards rehearsal space, stipends for cast and crew, printing of programs and materials, as well as other production costs that may come up.

Any donations will be greatly appreciated, rewards for generosity will include special items from the cast and crew, a writing request from the playwright, and guaranteed seats at the reading.

Why This Project?

Theatre is a medium that is not afraid to explore issues people may not understand or want to ask questions about. Fragments embraces this spirit wholeheartedly and tackles these subjects head on in a creative medium. Such theatre contains stories that needs to be told in order for us to grow. In addition, the artists involved are doing this out of a true passion for their craft and not for financial gain, so your support helps to bring their passions to life.

story:
The Who and the Why Of it All:

Hi. We're Goodly Rotten Apple Productions. Our production company aims to take the talents of all the different artists we know of all mediums and utilize their talents to create a work of art. As we are most familiar with the theatre, our first project is a play. We are thrilled to be reviving the play The Water Children by Wendy MacLeod in NYC this fall. While this play was written in 1997, it is very timely today as it deals with the hot button issue of abortion. We even have permission from the playwright to update the references and set it in 2012, so it will be even more relevant to anyone who comes to see it (like you?)! This is an important piece of theatre, and we need your help to get it up.

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $15,000 to cover the cost of costumes, lights, set, sound, advertising, cast and crew salaries and rehearsal and performance space for our 16 performance run in NYC. Currently, Mary is funding this show from her day job paycheck and she has covered a lot, but can't cover it all. The more money we raise, the better production values we can have and the more likely it will be that this important work can sell out and perhaps get extended for a longer run Off-Broadway. In order to be prepared to deal with this potential success, we need the funds to back it up. So we're turning to our strongest supporters to ask for contributions. In exchange, we're offering several perks at different levels of giving. Your contribution will help us create a brilliant production that can help remind people that art does indeed have the power to change the world and further to help support your local theatre artists here in NYC. Thank you so very much for all you do.

Where Will Your Money Go?

Here is our estimated budget of where your contributions will go.

EXPENSES:                                         

Rehearsal Space Rental             1500

Theatre  Rental                        6300

Playwright’s Royalties                1200

Insurance                                175

Director                                    266

Stage Manager                         266

Set/Lighting Designer                532

Publicist                                   600

Actors                                      2128

Production Crew                        266

Scenery/Lighting                       500

Costume Rental/Purchase          500

Props Rental/Purchase               250

Advertisement/Publicity              1000

Mailing                                     500

Postcard Production                   200

Newspaper/Magazine Ads           200

Posters/Flyers Production           250

Programs                                 875

Other Expenses                        300

TOTAL EXPENSES:                      17808


The Impact

Any amount is helpful and you can contribute at any level.  Anything beyond our goal will go toward extending the run and moving the show to a better contract.

Ideally, we'd love to sell the show out, get extended and bumped up to a bigger union contract and pay our cast and crew more as well as allow as many people as possible to see this important play this election season.

We are cutting costs whereever we can without sacrificing the production values. We've covered about 5K so far, but we still need your help. Please consider contributing whatever you can. Any amount is helpful. We would love it if you would consider contributing to the production and the future of this company. Thank you so very much for all you do!

Both John and Mary have successfully produced theatre in San Francisco in the past. Help us be successful in NYC too!

Other Ways You Can Help

We know times are tough and sometimes a financial contribution just isn't possible. That doesn't mean you can't be a part of this production and in helping us make a difference in the world through art. Here are some other ways you can contribute:

    • Use the Indiegogo sharing tools and tell your friends and family about this campaign and the show.
    • Retweet this on Twitter and help us go viral!
    • Post on Facebook.
    • Tell us about ways to cut costs.
    • Offer your bar/performance space for a fundraising party.
    • Invite your producer friends to come who might want to move the show to a bigger venue/contract.
    • Like us on Facebook.
    • If you're a reporter, writer, blogger, write about the show and tell your readership to come see it!
    • Come to the show!

Use the Indiegogo sharing tools and tell your friends and family about this campaign and the show.
Retweet this on Twitter and help us go viral!

story:
Hi All,

My name is Alexander Larkin, Actor, Director and Producer in the Long Island area.  I've been working with the best and brightest on the Island for years, and along the way I've come across some pretty fantastic material.  Some of the most intriguing has come from the mind of Peter Josyph, a man who has proven to be a prodigy at breaking down human interactions into the musicality of theater.  Now I have the opportunity to present two outstanding one act plays by this gifted playwright, and I'm looking for your help to do it.

We need to raise $1000 dollars to pay actors, get set pieces and ensure that our production is of only the highest caliber.  We are currently accepting donations to work towards this goal.  Theater of this sort is difficult at the best of times, but with all of the ongoing economic hardship in the area it has become even more difficult.  Anything that you can do to help keep independent theater alive is deeply appreciated.

As a contributor you will have an opportunity to see and to be part of some truly unique pieces.  Both of our plays "The Last Colored Lightbulb in Louisiana," and "Of Course December" are fantastical journies into the whimsical and dark spaces of the human mind.  They are impressionistic pieces that capture both the feeling and nuance of their characters without the crutch of conventional narrative structure.

If you join us you will be part of a challenge to a conventional theater world trapped in the past.  You will be part of an exciting new vanguard exploring the possibilities to which new theater may one day aspire.  Please join us, and help to see that our actors, director and crew get some small compensation for all their hard work and diligence.  Thank you for your attention, and I certainly hope you will join us and become part of our team.

 

Until we meet, in the theater, or on the street,

Alex Larkin  

 

 

 The Rose Theater 

 1320 Lincoln Ave

Holbrook, NY 11741

 

 Show Dates: May 3rd to 31st

Wednesdays and Fridays at 8pm and Sundays at 7pm

story:
What it was like...

good rid/dance performances burst into flames in New York City in 2002 as a collaborative trans-disciplinary performance collective, dedicated to challenging ideas about gender, sexuality, the body, desire, and consumption.  

With Artistic Director Hilary Maia Grubb at the helm, good rid/dance performances brought together virtuosos from myriad media -- including dance, theater, music, spoken word, film, video -- in order to construct meaning through performance, and to nurture the talents of LGBTQ artists.

In 2006, good rid/dance performances self-produced an evening-length experimental dance-theater piece, Number Ten Dream, based on poet and playwright Alyssa Kerec Harley's spoken word opera. This acclaimed performance extravaganza was generously supported by donations from friends, family, fellow artists, and folks like you!!



What happened...

Following Number Ten Dream, Hilary put her performance career on hold to pursue a medical degree, after heeding the call to be of service to underserved, urban patient populations, including homeless populations, severely mentally ill populations, and LGBTQ populations. She subsequently relocated to the place of her birth, San Francisco, and is currently a resident physician in the Department of Psychiatry at at the University of California, San Francisco.

However, the path to this life of service was steep and rocky: in medical school, Hilary found herself in the midst of a conservative, conformist, hierarchical culture, and lost touch with her creative spark. The artists of good rid/dance performances went their separate ways, and this vibrant queer performance collective lost its spark.

What it is like now...

Hilary will be turning 40 (!!!) this Pride Sunday, June 29, and has ben inspired to bring good rid/dance performances back to life on the Left Coast! We will be kicking off the season with a mixed gender, queer dragstravaganza on Sunday, July 6 at El Rio in San Francisco, CA!

We would love your support to help bring this event to life!

Your generous contributions will support:

  • the brilliantly talented artists who are performing, including: 
Adore Delano

            photo by Mathu Andersen


Honey Mahogany


Halle O’Peridol and the DSM-5


...and many more fabulously talented local artists!

  • the use of the queer community space El Rio in San Francisco, CA
  • technical suport, including sound engineer, lighting superhero, and DJ
  • nourishment and libations, including The MELT grilled cheese food truck
  • promotional materials

Thank you so much for reading our story!

With your help, we can bring good rid/dance performances back to life, and in the process, celebrate Hilary's 40th birthday with a bang!
story_txt:
What it was like...good rid/dance performances burst into flames in New York City in 2002 as a collaborative trans-disciplinary performance collective, dedicated to challenging ideas about gender, sexuality, the body, desire, and consumption.  With Artistic Director Hilary Maia Grubb at the helm, good rid/dance performances brought together virtuosos from myriad media -- including dance, theater, music, spoken word, film, video -- in order to construct meaning through performance, and to nurture the talents of LGBTQ artists.In 2006, good rid/dance performances self-produced an evening-length experimental dance-theater piece, Number Ten Dream, based on poet and playwright Alyssa Kerec Harley's spoken word opera. This acclaimed performance extravaganza was generously supported by donations from friends, family, fellow artists, and folks like you!!What happened...Following Number Ten Dream, Hilary put her performance career on hold to pursue a medical degree, after heeding the call to be of service to underserved, urban patient populations, including homeless populations, severely mentally ill populations, and LGBTQ populations. She subsequently relocated to the place of her birth, San Francisco, and is currently a resident physician in the Department of Psychiatry at at the University of California, San Francisco.However, the path to this life of service was steep and rocky: in medical school, Hilary found herself in the midst of a conservative, conformist, hierarchical culture, and lost touch with her creative spark. The artists of good rid/dance performances went their separate ways, and this vibrant queer performance collective lost its spark.What it is like now...Hilary will be turning 40 (!!!) this Pride Sunday, June 29, and has ben inspired to bring good rid/dance performances back to life on the Left Coast! We will be kicking off the season with a mixed gender, queer dragstravaganza on Sunday, July 6 at El Rio in San Francisco, CA!We would love your support to help bring this event to life!Your generous contributions will support:the brilliantly talented artists who are performing, including: Adore Delano            photo by Mathu AndersenHoney MahoganyHalle O’Peridol and the
DSM-5



...and many more fabulously talented local artists!



the use of the queer community space El Rio in San Francisco, CA
technical suport, including sound engineer, lighting superhero, and DJ
nourishment and libations, including The MELT grilled cheese food truck
promotional materials

Thank you so much for reading our story!
With your help, we can bring good rid/dance performances back to life, and in the process, celebrate Hilary's 40th birthday with a bang!

story:
Six years ago, I wrote a farcical tale called "Denial, Time to Face the Musical" about a black girl who literally thinks she's white. The musical comedy had a sold-out 3 week showcase at Theater for the New City in NY. Later, it won best Production of a Stage Reading at the Planet Connections Festivity.

Now, with some fresh material and a new title, I'm ready to bring "Mirror, Mirror" to the West Coast! This year, I'm producing a stage reading of "Mirror, Mirror" at the Hollywood Fringe, an annual theatre festival in Los Angeles. And I need YOUR help!

I'm raising support to cover the costs of the reading. The Fringe registration fee is $250. My preferred performance space, Actors Company, costs $275 per performance (I'd like to do 3), plus $150 for insurance. There is also the cost of rehearsal, production staff (director, musical director, stage manager), and of course--the actors!

I believe "Mirror, Mirror" has an important message of self acceptance that you don't find in most musicals. It also gives women and actors of color a chance to challenge negative stereotypes and tell a new kind of story.

I hope you'll team up with me to make this show a reality--I can't do it without you!!

Thank you in advance for your support!

November Christine

story:
Short Summary

We are a diverse group of students from Arizona State University School of Dance. Our goal is to expand our various studies by attending Juste Debout, an international streetdance festival in Paris, France, from March 4 through March 10. This festival will help us in our future career paths and allow us to experience a multicultural event attended by dancers from all over the world. Melissa Britt, a Clinical Professor at ASU, is conducting research on the topic of Urban Movement on a global scale. Our experience at Juste Debout will help feed her research through looking at our experiences and interactions at the festival. Our trip to Juste Debout, besides acting as a means to conduct research, will also help enrich our individual growth as we transition from the University to the professional field. While attending Juste Debout we will be taking a series of classes and participating in the urban movement culture in France. Our goal is to gain an understanding of values and practices from urban movement communities all over the world and how they relate to our own communities. Our wish is to bring our newfound awareness and understanding back to not only ASU but the pre-existing movement culture in Arizona in order to enhance our developing movement community with this global experience.

What We Need and What You Get

There are a lot of costs when traveling to a foreign country but your contributions will be put towards our class fees. It’s $500 for class registration and if we reach our goal, these funds would cover that cost. Taking class is an important aspect of the trip because we will be connecting with members of various dance communities, learning from highly respected individuals, and experiencing the aesthetics of different cultures as they relate to urban movement.

If you contribute, you will receive one of our various perks when the group comes back. These perks include:

  • A personalized postcard from France
  • For studios, either a one or two hour master class that can be taught in various styles and would reflect what we learned in France.
  • A personalized video of your dancer of choice or a video showing the group’s experience at Juste Debout.

These will be delivered when we get back from our trip, in order to provide our contributors with perks that reflect our experience and growth in Paris.

Other Ways to Help

If you can’t contribute or you want to help get the word out, feel free to post this on any of your social media pages. Any help in promoting our project would be greatly appreciated.

If you have any questions regarding the project, our perks, or us, email us at justedeboutbound@yahoo.com

story:
An Appalachian Christmas Carol

You think you know the classic Dickens’ A Christmas Carol. But what if the story was set in SE Ohio and old Eb Scrooge owned the local mine? What if Bob Cratchit organized the mine workers, and Fezziwig’s holiday party took place at historic Stuart’s Opera House with local favorites Rattletrap Stringband playing live onstage?

Brick Monkey Theater Ensemble (BMTE), Southeast Ohio’s professional theater company, is proud to announce the world premiere of An Appalachian Christmas Carol and the inauguration of a local Holiday Tradition. The production of this new – and newly relevant to our region – adaptation of the Charles Dickens’ Christmas classic will run Thursday through Sunday, December 13 - 16, 2012 at Stuart’s Opera House in Nelsonville, Ohio.

This production is the culmination of two years of development and research that has included extensive input from community storytellers, historians, and musicians. Spinning the traditional ghost story and tale of redemption, An Appalachian Christmas Carol honors Southeast Ohio’s rich coal mining and labor union heritage, while simultaneously celebrating the spirit of the season.  This is a joyful story of redemption, rooted in rural storytelling and intertwined with regional traditional music.

BMTE is proud to be supported by the Ohio Arts Council, the Athens Foundation, the Athens County Convention and Visitors Bureau, the O’Bleness Foundation, the Bernard and Judy Cornwell Foundation, and Kleinpenny Rentals.

David Haugen as Eb Scrooge

Brian Evans as Jake Marley

Janice Paxson Evans as Mrs. Cratchit

lorraine wochan as Mrs. Fezziwig

Tom Quinn as Mr. Fezziwig

Tom Fiocchi as Bob Cratchit

Casiha Felt as Belinda Cratchit

Kat Bramley as Ida Mae

Jared Davis as Young Scrooge

Walker Evans as Tiny Tim

Nora Sullivan as Betty

Miki Brooks as Relief Worker 1

Bob Garbo as Relief Worker 2

Matthew McElroy and Tim Peacock, musicians

 

Why Your Donation Matters

The Monkeys want to see the Nelsonville Public Square filled with visitors every Christmas. They’ll be coming to see the production of An Appalachian Christmas Carol, eating a Cratchit family Christmas dinner, buying gifts on the Square, staying in local hotels, ice skating at the North Pole Rink, riding the North Pole Express, connecting with groups like Little Cities of Black Diamonds, and telling their friends to visit Nelsonville for a family holiday event they can’t find anywhere else. But we need your help to make this vision a reality.

Brick Monkey History

Our mission is to challenge, engage and inspire the residents of our community with explosive and thought-provoking theater. As Southeast Ohio’s Professional Theater Company, we develop and produce new theater works, as well as contemporary and classic plays. With a commitment to collaboration and a desire to integrate our art into the fabric of our region, we strive to explore, confront and affirm what it means to be alive.

story:
About 'The Asylum' and Who We Are

Professor Eldritch's Asylum for Uncanny and Extraordinary Women is the brain child of: 

Abby Lis-Perlis, Artistic Director of Devious Maid Productions and Ayne Terceira, Artistic Director of Uncumber Theatrics and Consulting Artist with Devious Maid Productions. Ayne and Abby are co-directing and producing Eldritch's Asylum

Together with their all-female ensemble of actresses, and a team of film-makers, artists, writers and tech-savy extraordinaires, they will create an immersive theater experience that focuses on the narratives of compelling, unique and complex women, plucked from the pages of history, and brought to life inside Eldritch's Asylum. 

Eldritch's Asylum will take up residence in vacant Pittsburgh home, a worn-out space made new through art. The show will run March-April 2015. Audience members will be guided through the house in small groups, getting to know the women residents and unraveling the mysterious origins of each of them and of Eldritch's Asylum itself. Is it a prison? Is it a safe-house? All the answers lie within...

With this production Devious Maid aims to:

  • Create vibrant and dimensional roles for women, too rarely seen in art and media.
  • Show the beauty and value of a disused space, by transforming it through art.
  • Immerse audiences in a intimate experience that not only entertains but makes them think.
  • As it's inaugural production, Devious Maid wants to show the local and global theater community what they are capable of contributing to the Pittsburgh theater scene.

This production is a labor of love and we need your help to make it happen...

What We Need (Budget Breakdown)

This project is not for profit, so every cent you donate will go right into our production. We need at least seven thousand dollars to pay for basic expenses, and the farther we go over that goal, the more beautiful and engaging Eldritch's Asylum will be. Here is a break-down of where your contribution will go:

The Basic Needs:

$3,000 for Rehearsal and Performance Space

$1,125 for Set, Props and Construction Expenses

$1,125 for Eight period-specific Costumes

$1,125 for Stipends for our talented cast and crew

$625 for Event and Rehearsal Insurance

These are the minimum expenses to bring our ambitious and enormous project to life. If we are fortunate enough to surpass our initial goal, every dollar over will go towards:

  • Creating an even more detailed world through higher quality sets, props and costumes.
  • Investing more back into our talented cast and crew in appreciation for their endless time and energy.
  •  Investing in the future of Eldritch's Asylum (i.e. producing a professional film of the piece, seeking an extended or second run of the show so more audience members can experience our world.)
The Perks:
Remember, if you donate, you have to option of purchasing some pretty awesome "perks," crafted by our team and made with love for you. We have everything from a Letter from the Professor Eldritch ($15) to  FIVE VIP-pass to our show and a private post-show  talk-back with cocktails and light munchies for you and your guests ($1,000).
If we reach $10,000 we will explode with being filled with gratitude and then as a Stretch Perk the cast and crew will record a music video of any song, voted for by contributors on our website, and dedicate it to all of you. Any. Song. Ever.
Other Ways You Can Help

Literally every penny helps, but if you can't contribute we understand, and there are other ways that you can help us, too:

  • Tell everyone you know about our project by connecting with us on: Facebook and Twitter and sharing our content and our website www.deviousmaid.org
  • Share our IndieGoGo campaign as well by clicking the Indiegogo Share button.
We thank you from the bottom of our hearts for you time and support!!!

story:
We are Tango 21 Dance Theater. We use the language of Argentine tango to tell compelling and contemporary stories through live theatrical performances. Since our founding in 2014, we have produced and toured two original works, El Tango Cafe and Cambalache: A Holiday Story.

Both told long-form stories using dancers, actors and musicians. They were distinctive and expressive productions that transformed audiences and company members alike. These projects were well planned, executed on time and on or ahead of budget– producing high caliber original theater. We are proud of the talent and resourcefulness of our founders as well as the dedication of our company members!

We are now rehearsing our next show, Feathers: A Tango Journey.

It's a story of love… loss… migration… and finding a path home.

It’s our story and your story.

The creative vision and plans for this show are on a larger scale than our previous projects. The premiere (August 19, 2016!) is fast approaching and we need your support to bring it to life!

Here is a nifty pie chart showing how our budget will be used to produce the new show.

We have a funding gap of $7K and your donation will support our production costs: theater rental, lighting designer, audio engineer, props, sets and costumes. We are a scrappy and resourceful organization and each dollar you donate will be stretched as far as possible to produce a great show!

Don’t forget to check out the great perks at the various donation levels; you can show your Tango 21 Dance Theater pride and immerse yourself in our tango community!

Help us spread the word! Share via word of mouth and social media about this campaign and the new show (see the links on this page to share)!
With your help, we will continue to make an impact on the world by sharing our original stories that connect diverse communities through the language of Argentine tango.

Your support is the wind beneath our wings.

Thank you!

Tango 21 Dance Theater

Please join us for Feathers: A Tango Journey. Show dates on August 19, 20, and 21 in Chicago. For ticket information visit www.tango21.com or www.facebook.com/tango21dancetheater

Tango 21 Dance Theater is a sponsored project of Fractured Atlas, a non-profit arts service organization. Contributions for the charitable purposes of Tango 21 Dance Theater must be made payable to Fractured Atlas only and are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law.

story:
Her Legacy Must Live On.

She was a dancer of international renown, who brought a compelling new form of expression to the world stage.

Once called “an ambassador with hips,” Jean Cocteau said of her: ‘If we writers could say with our pens what Katherine Dunham says with her legs, our writings would be forbidden.'

Katherine Dunham (1909-2006) is revered as one of the great pillars of American dance history.  Her world-renowned modern dance company exposed audiences to the cultures of the African Diaspora during the 1930s - 1960s and her schools brought dance training and education to a variety of populations sharing her passion and commitment to dance as a medium of cultural communication. 


International Dunham Technique Seminar

Since 1984, dancers and artists dedicated to Katherine Dunham’s vision have hosted an annual seminar, a space for training, fellowship, and celebration of her legacy.  Held in St. Louis – East St. Louis area, seminar participants, instructors, and musicians have come from Senegal, Ghana, Argentina, Barbados, Brazil, Cuba, Haiti, Europe, and all over the United States.  Over the years, participants have experienced teachings from Katherine Dunham and her legendary dance company members—they continue to learn from master certified dance and Dunham Technique instructors.

The 2012 Dunham Technique Seminar is July 28 – August 5, and will include classes in Dunham Technique, Dunham Repertoire, Dunham Pedagogy and Philosophy, Pilates, Dunham Technique Rhythms, and Afro-Caribbean dance.  The Seminar also includes a youth track that includes dance and theater classes for youth 6-18 years old.  In addition to classes, Seminar participants will experience performances, the community-based Harambee Celebration, and the Annual Dunham Gala.

 

Help Us Bring Her Legacy To Youth Today

The Katherine Dunham Center for the Arts and Humanities is the official host of the Dunham Technique Seminar and currently needs additional funds to cover the costs of the Seminar, and bring Miss Dunham’s legacy to youth from East St. Louis and other impoverished communities.

 

What You Receive for Your Donation

$50 Donation:

Listed as a donor on the Katherine Dunham Center for the Arts and Humanities website and will become a member of the Friends of Katherine Dunham.

$100 Donation:

Listed as a donor on the KDCAH website, become a member of Friends of Katherine Dunham, and receive a postcard from local East St. Louis artist Larry Spencer’s “Mousepaintings” collection.

$250 Donation:

Listed as a donor on the KDCAH website, become a member of Friends of Katherine Dunham, and receive a t-shirt or tote bag from a previous Dunham Technique Seminar.

story:
Exactly one year ago, I was diagnosed with Major Depressive Disorder. For years I have been dealing with this illness, and had no idea. I never considered the idea of therapy, and it cost me. It cost me friendships, relationships, and opportunities. All around me, I see others like me. Others who show the same signs of turmoil and internal agony that plagued my life. I also see the people who shame them into avoiding the fact that they have a VERY TREATABLE ILLNESS.

I know I can't fix this problem alone, but with your help we can definitely help many others to know that they don't have to suffer in silence and they can be helped. I have crafted the message. I need your help to spread it.

One amazing aspect of entertainment, is the power to help others overcome their personal struggles, by sharing the struggles of another. In my new show "Wendell Tucker Hates the World", I share my struggles, insights and weaknesses to be that example. The message is a simple one: Depression is not a White thing, or a Woman thing, or a show of weakness. It is an illness, it can be treated, and it can be overcome. 

My goal is to raise $25,000 for a National Tour of "Wendell Tucker Hates the World" and to film the accompanying DVD "The Face of Depression". We want to encourage others to share their story, and help bring to light how people from different backgrounds took control of their life. 

To show my dedication to this very important endeavor, I am embarking on a 40 day fast beginning midnight, July 29, 2012 and ending midnight September 7, 2012. For these 40 days I will abstain from all solid and processed food, living only on water and 1 8oz glass of juice per day. My hope is to inspire others to sacrifice for the betterment of our communities, through my own sacrifice. I will be posting daily updates of my progress and my experiences during this time. I sincerely hope you will join the cause and help me shine a light on MDD.

With Love and Faith,

Wendell Tucker

**** Hunger Aims YouTube Channel**** 

****OFFICIAL SCRIPT SAMPLE FROM "WENDELL TUCKER HATES THE WORLD***

 

Script Sample From Wendell Tucker Hates the World

story:
SUMMARY

Hi! The Requisite Movers (TRM) was formed, in 2010, by us, Lela Aisha Jones of FlyGround and Deneane Richburg of Brownbody.  Our founding mission is to develop, promote, and present artistic research and dialogue provoking projects by women choreographers of African descent. 

We launched Wellspring: Artistic Dialogue and Critical Feedback Intensives in 2012 as TRM’s artistic and professional development program that focuses on the process of making dances.  We will select 4 Philadelphia-based Black female choreographers who will be able to create very new work in an intimate, critical, and supportive setting.  We will select artists whose work is grounded in a variety of areas such as  Diasporan physicalities, social issues, theatre, and literature. We have been working hard with Mentoring Artists Marjani Forté and Nia Love of Love/Forté, our mentor, Dr. Kariamu Welsh of Kariamu & Company, and other local established artists. These mentoring artists will visit the chosen choreographers and provide feedback on their process.  

This project supports four women choreographers of African descent as they develop their work through TRM's Wellspring: Artistic Dialogue and Critical Feedback Intensives in the spring of 2014 and into the presentation of their work in the fall of 2014. This campaign supports these artists throughout the process of making and presenting their work. 

Photo of Oiya Lowe by Johanna Austin Art.

WHAT WE NEED

Our goal is $6,500, which will cover the following:

  • Administrative Fees (We now have an Admin & Project Assistant, Leila Anglin and a Development Consultant, Rachael Glashan!)

  • Rehearsal, Workshop, + Performance Venues

  • Choreographer Stipends

  • Mentoring Artists Travel + Fees

  • Marketing + Print Materials

  • Documentary Videographer + Photographer

Photo of Dina-Verley Christophe by Johanna Austin Art.

IMPACT

Through TRM’s Wellspring + Performances:

  • Black women of African Descent will have more access, visibility, and experience in their efforts to create and produce quality choreographic projects on the Philadelphia downtown dance scene and in the national landscape.

  • Varied movement voices that are crucial to the cultural vibrancy of our U.S. communities will be cultivated and fertilized through artist mentorship and choreographer exchange.

  • Participating choreographers and performers will be able to receive relevant, honest, and critical feedback that will strengthen their work by honoring their cultural foundations and contextualizing their choreographic vision in broader contemporary artistic spaces.

Wellspring session photographed by MOJO Life capture.

OTHER WAYS TO SHOW SUPPORT

We understand that there are hundreds of Indiegogo + Kickstarter campaigns out and about and that we can’t donate to them all. Sharing this campaign through your social media platforms will help us reach new friends and our goal.

story:
Soutenez une création originale !

Le Théâtre de la trotteuse, une jeune compagnie de théâtre dont la démarche artistique est de favoriser le métissage entre le théâtre et d'autres formes d'arts de la scène, présentera sa troisième création en chantier  du 8 au 18 juin 2017 dans le cadre du Festival FRINGE de Montréal.

À quoi servira l'argent ?

En tant que jeune compagnie, nous ne bénéficions d'aucun financement public de la part des différents Conseils des arts. Jusqu’à ce jour, le Théâtre de la Trotteuse a su mener un chantier de recherche et création au cours des deux dernières années afin de développer un langage scénique original où le théâtre se nourrit des arts du cirques, du mouvement et de la danse. Le contexte de sous-financement des divers conseils des arts a mené la compagnie à épuiser ses ressources pour financer le reste du projet et d’assurer un minimum aux artistes impliqués. En effet, malgré le fait que le projet ait été recommandé à deux reprises par le jury du Conseil des arts du Canada et une fois au CALQ, les fonds étaient toujours à sec, faisant en sorte que nous n'avons jamais pu obtenir de soutien.

S’il est vrai que nous avons toujours mené nos projets, beau temps, mauvais temps, nous faisons appel à votre soutien afin de combler le manque financier qui s’est creusé en raison de la situation précédemment décrite. S’il est vrai que nous comptons sur une équipe artistique dévouée (nous avons tous accepté de présenter le spectacle en partage de recette, compte tenu de nos moyens) qui croient au spectacle, nous avons besoin d’un soutien afin de développer les outils nécessaires pour faire voir le fruit de notre travail.

Nous avons donc besoin de votre aide afin de poursuivre la création de ce spectacle en lequel nous croyons fermement. Chaque don, aussi minime soit-il, aidera le Théâtre de la trotteuse à achever le spectacle qui donne vie à l'histoire improbable, si cruelle soit-elle,  qui se tisse entre deux êtres que la vie a mené à vivre dans la rue.

Votre contribution nous servira à financer le matériel création (scénographie, costumes, etc.) et les représentations au FRINGE (coup d'inscription et production). Cela nous permettra d'éviter un éventuel déficit qui pourrait nuire à la poursuite de la création du spectacle. Bref, cela nous permettra de ne pas diminuer la qualité de notre spectacle !

 

Genèse du projet

La volonté de développer un projet de création qui prend racine dans la réalité de l’itinérance et de la prostitution vient du fait que nous l’observons, sans la vivre, au quotidien et qu’elle nous fait rêver autant qu’elle peut nous horrifier. Une journée, un être en haillon expose au passant qui l’ignore le plus beau sourire du monde, raconte les histoires les plus fabuleuses aux rares personnes qui ne craignent pas de l’écouter et, le soir venu, partage sa manne avec ses semblables. Le lendemain, ce même être humain en haillon, fracasse sans raison la vitrine d’un commerce sous le regard médusé des passants avant de se faire maîtriser par des policiers, voir abattu comme nous le rappelle la mort d’Alain Magloire dans les rues de Montréal.

Dans les quartiers de Québec et de Montréal où nous habitons, nous sommes confrontés à ce genre de situations, aussi dérangeantes que fascinantes. Dans ce monde où le paraître et la retenue ne sont pas la norme, le réel est doux jusqu’au moment où la maladie revient. Les réactions sont vives et explosives, dictées davantage par l’instinct du corps alors que la réalité prend le large. Des réactions qui sont guidées par un état de crise, où l’état de conscience est parfois altéré par différentes pathologies qui, elles, sont exacerbées par la rudesse de la vie. Puis, entre deux creux de vagues, tout redevient possible : l’espoir, la solidarité, l’amour même. De certaines situation peut se dégager une solidarité improbable, une solidarité qui nait du hasard ; l’itinérance. Deux personnes qui, tout à coup, se rencontrent, ne se seraient probablement jamais parlé si ce n’était qu’à ce moment là, elles ont eu besoin l’un de l’autre, et n’ont pas laissé l’occasion filer. Ce moment où l’un et l’autre sont devenus complémentaires, à causes de la vie qui érafle et grafigne. C’est afin d’explorer le ballant entre ces moments de crises et de douceur que nous exploitons les possibilités que l'acrobatie et la danse peuvent amener au théâtre.

C’est avec un sentiment d’urgence, tinté de respect pour cette réalité que nous voulons dépeindre cette microsociété par le biais du théâtre gestuel, sans paroles, ou presque.

N'hésitez pas à partager notre campagne de financement sur Facebook ou toute autre plateforme.

story:
KING LEAR is often regarded as Shakespeare’s greatest work, the masterpiece among masterpieces. It is a domestic tragedy examining the breakdown of family relationships on a huge canvas, yet drawn with a very intimate brush.

KING LEAR runs from April 14th to 26th, 2015 for 12 performances ONLY.

The King Lear project will provide a professional classical theatre experience that does not currently exist in North Bay and area. It is a vital, artistic initiative needed in an area where there are no municipal grants for artists.  Yet everywhere one cuts the earth it seems to bleed a new sports arena. As a result, eight community partners are helping make KING LEAR happen: Trinity Arts (Trinity United Church), White Water Gallery, Canadore College, North Bay Literacy Council, Near North School Board/Nipissing-Parry Sound Catholic Separate Board, Retired Teachers Association of Ontario and the Gathering Place.

Patrons are being offered a bountiful theatrical experience but much lower than the cost of larger festivals in Southern Ontario.  KING LEAR brings Shakespeare’s profound thinking on life to a young audience and helps connect the importance of reading. Please go to the Gallery for extra videos and images including an interview with David Fox. Also check out our new website: www.kinglearproject.com

story:
Short Summary

The Athens Children’s Ballet performs “Persephone: The Secret of the Seasons”! By raising funds we will be able to give the children and young dancers the chance to perform on stage at the amazing Pallas theatre, in the centre of Athens, on the 26th and 27th of November 2016!

The main goal of ACB is to give the opportunity to talented young ballet dancers to perform in a professional ballet under the guidance of experienced teachers as well as to give them a life transforming experience! This year we are especially thankful and grateful that our choreographer is Erico Montes, the first ballet dancer of the Royal Ballet of London. Erico has created just for us an original choreography in a new ballet called “Persephone: The Secret of the Seasons”. In order to continue our goals we ask for your support! Furthermore your contribution will give the opportunity to the young dancers to attend a summer course abroad and to further blossom!

A few words about ACB:

The Athens Children’s Ballet is a non-profit organization founded in 2013 amid the difficulties of the Greek economy.  We were willing to take the risk, however, as we believe that Art has a healing power and is the noblest reaction in times of crisis.

We aspire to motivate our youngsters and encourage them to set high goals, to be creative and to enrich their artistic expression. The group was formed by auditioning 300 young dancers (9 to 22 years old), from all over Greece; those selected are rigorously trained and well-prepared by highly skilled professionals and are ready to participate in a classic repertoire ballet performance.

“Snow White” (2013), “Cinderella” (2014) and “Beauty and the Beast” (2015) are the three productions we have already created and which have been attended by more than 5.000 spectators.

Your support is critical in fulfilling our objectives.....EVERY amount helps!

We are grateful for your support!

Why support ACB:

  • ACB gives the opportunity and enables young ballet dancers to unfold their talent and technique and thus to develop their skills
  • ACB is associated with the values of creativity, development, equal opportunities and establishes high standards in education
  • ACB gathers dancers from all over Greece and unites them in a common goal, to create a highly regarded performance while enhancing the team spirit
  • Dance is a means of expressing oneself and a great way to learn about discipline
  • More than 5,000 people have attended our performances and experienced the wonderful world of ballet

 

Thanks to your support last year we were able to:

  • Produce with great success last year’s performance “Beauty and the Beast”!
  • Give two scholarships to talented dancers in order to participate in summer courses abroad
  •  Perform for charities such as SOS Children’s Village.

Please share our message with your social networks!

 

To learn more about ACB, please visit our Facebook page:

https://web.facebook.com/athenschildrenballet/

story:
Short Summary

The Seedling Project grew (get it, plants?!?) out of the idea that theater needs to be more accessible to the public at large, as well as a desire to create work that challenges us as artists. We've decided to take a risk unlike anything we've seen in Atlanta: produce five fully mounted productions in one year that are free to our audiences, and to keep scientific records of what we learn along the way.  It's like your high school science lab where you planted beans, if the beans were free plays, and you actually wrote stuff down in your composition notebook.

What We Need & What You Get

Each one of the Seedling Members has agreed to donate $100 towards each production (Which gives us $800 per show), but we expect each production to cost us between $1500 to $2000. We need to raise $5000 to fill in that gap so that we can offer free admission to shows that are worth seeing. The dollars you give go to venues, sets, costumes, props, advertising, and rights. If we exceed our fundraising goals, we will also be able to compensate the artists who have donated their time to our projects.

In gratitude for your donations, we have a range of perks from plants signed by the company members to Limited Edition Seedling Project trucker hats, to our soon to be famous autographs.

The Impact

The long and the short of it is that your money is buying tickets for people who can't afford them. You are taking away one of the largest impediments to people accessing art. 
You are also contributing to a truly unique science experiment. What discoveries could Galileo made without the Medici Family? You are our Medici Family. (Hopefully with fewer political murders).

Risks & Challenges

There are lots of reasons this could crash and burn.

We are going into this financially handicapped. $800 is simply not enough money to put on a show (in some cases, it doesn't even cover the cost of licensing the play). Fortunately, the generous Atlanta theatre community has been incredibly supportive of us thus far, and so some amazing commodities like venues and costumes have already been donated for some of our shows, so we are off to a good start.

But, even with free tickets, it can be hard to get people in the seats. We have to find a way to speak to our community. We can say confidently after our inaugural project of "Serial Killers", that we have this capability. We packed the back room at Manuel's Tavern for 4 weeks running with 5 bizarre 10 minute serial plays. It was a trial by fire, but it has already given us so much knowledge about what the people of Atlanta want to see, and we are ready to use that information to create a sell out season.

So yes, this all may go up in flames, but we think that is exactly where good art is made. It's only with great risk we can reap great reward.

Other Ways You Can Help

We are starving artists. We get it if you can't financially contribute. Truly, the best way you can help us is by attending our productions and talking with us about what you liked, what you didn't like, and what you want to see more of. That is the kind of data we need to fulfill the scientific aspect of our mission.

Also, if you are in possession of a venue, costumes, cool props, lighting instruments or any other theatrical devices that you'd like to share we would be exceptionally grateful! Or maybe you have a few pesky community service hours to do- come volunteer as an usher or come work the box office, and we will attest that you are a contributing member of society.

You can also share our story and our campaign with others! Share this link, like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter; Social Media is our friend! And so are you. Help a friend out!
story_txt:
Short Summary The Seedling Project grew (get it, plants?!?) out of the idea that theater needs to be more accessible to the public at large, as well as a desire to create work that challenges us as artists. We've decided to take a risk unlike anything we've seen in Atlanta: produce five fully mounted productions in one year that are free to our audiences, and to keep scientific records of what we learn along the way.  It's like your high school science lab where you planted beans, if the beans were free plays, and you actually wrote stuff down in your composition notebook.   What We Need & What You Get Each one of the Seedling Members has agreed to donate $100 towards each production (Which gives us $800 per show), but we expect each production to cost us between $1500 to $2000. We need to raise $5000 to fill in that gap so that we can offer free admission to shows that are worth seeing. The dollars you give go to venues, sets, costumes, props, advertising, and rights. If we exceed our fundraising goals, we will also be able to compensate the artists who have donated their time to our projects.
In gratitude for your donations, we have a range of perks from plants signed by the company members to Limited Edition Seedling Project trucker hats, to our soon to be famous autographs.
    The Impact

The long and the short of it is that your money is buying tickets for people who can't afford them. You are taking away one of the largest impediments to people accessing art. You are also contributing to a truly unique science experiment. What discoveries could Galileo made without the Medici Family? You are our Medici Family. (Hopefully with fewer political murders).


Risks & Challenges There are lots of reasons this could crash and burn.
We are going into this financially handicapped. $800 is simply not enough money to put on a show (in some cases, it doesn't even cover the cost of licensing the play). Fortunately, the generous Atlanta theatre community has been incredibly supportive of us thus far, and so some amazing commodities like venues and costumes have already been donated for some of our shows, so we are off to a good start.
But, even with free tickets, it can be hard to get people in the seats. We have to find a way to speak to our community. We can say confidently after our inaugural project of "Serial Killers", that we have this capability. We packed the back room at Manuel's Tavern for 4 weeks running with 5 bizarre 10 minute serial plays. It was a trial by fire, but it has already given us so much knowledge about what the people of Atlanta want to see, and we are ready to use that information to create a sell out season.
So yes, this all may go up in flames, but we think that is exactly where good art is made. It's only with great risk we can reap great reward.
    Other Ways You Can Help We are starving artists. We get it if you can't financially contribute. Truly, the best way you can help us is by attending our productions and talking with us about what you liked, what you didn't like, and what you want to see more of. That is the kind of data we need to fulfill the scientific aspect of our mission.
Also, if you are in possession of a venue, costumes, cool props, lighting instruments or any other theatrical devices that you'd like to share we would be exceptionally grateful! Or maybe you have a few pesky community service hours to do- come volunteer as an usher or come work the box office, and we will attest that you are a contributing member of society.
You can also share our story and our campaign with others! Share this link, like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter; Social Media is our friend! And so are you. Help a friend out!

story:
Why Antigone?

My name is Abraham Benson-Goldberg, and I am directing a site-responsive outdoor movement-informed, 4-person adaptation of Antigone because I love this play. Simple as that. For the political intrigue and metaphor; for the emotional (non)catharsis of watching everything go horribly, horribly wrong.

Although on the surface this is an outdoor production, with minimal production design and "value," this is a production that believes in paying actors a decent wage, and paying off what it owes (rehearsal spaces, printing costs, etc). Your help helps us, even more importantly, create a piece of free theatre for our audience--no tickets, and no ticket prices.

What We Need & What You Get

We are a working group of five: one director and four amazing actors. Noa, Shalhevet, and the (two) Tomers have gone above and beyond to create something from nothing, and tell this incredibly relevant tale of political shortsightedness and folly; which is also a tale of female approaches to the wielding of power in the public realm.

I'm asking for $1500, because I believe in paying my actors, and in paying them a fair wage for their labours. As each dollar is roughly 3.85 shekel, and I pay my actors in shekels, you can rest assured knowing that every dollar you donate is really making headway. Our largest cost is, of course, reimbursing actors for their time and travels (roughly 750-1000 shekel each). After this, your monies will go to paying for our rehearsal spaces; costuming and make-up; design and printing fees.

Our perks include copies of our working script; handwritten thank you post-cards from all of us; a skype conversation with one or more of us; and much, much more.

The Impact

This play is a chance for us to do several things. Firstly, to show the kids of this neighborhood that theatre can be done anywhere, any time. Second, to put on an amazing type of theatrical experience that normally isn't available to us, especially in Jerusalem. Finally, we get to tell a story about politics and politicking in the capital city of Israel!

For Noa, this play is a return to acting after half-a-year of maternity leave. For Shalhevet, this play is an incredible theatrical challenge. For Tomer Einav, this play is an opportunity to embrace a different style of play. Tomer Jacovchak is looking at this play as a chance to interrogate the ancients. And for me, it's an opportunity to yawp barbarically at Jerusalem.

Risks & Challenges

I have previously directed two other site-specific outdoor productions for little or no budget. SONG of SONGS for Camp Ramah in Wisconsin, and the ILIAD for Lovers & Madmen at Northwestern University. I am a champion of directing outdoors for little to no money. But this time, let's try having cash!

There are, to be honest, very few risks: we have the cast, we have the text, we have the blocking. We do go up very shortly, and that is always challenging; and as outdoor performers we do have the specter of hecklers or having the police called upon us. Our approach to both has been thus far to be friendly and open about our process with our neighbors to the park and playground, and so far, we only have fans!

Other Ways You Can Help

Just because you can't contribute financially doesn't mean you can't help! Any share you can make, anyone you feel like telling that "they're doing an outdoors movement-y production of Antigone in the heart of Jerusalem," that's doing so much.

Get the word out, pay some actors, be the artistic change you want to see in the world.

story:
Prepare for a beast, at least a category four. Hurricane Jimmy, a steamy present-day musical noir is approaching!!

 

About The Musical

Set amongst an antebellum estate undergoing renovations deep within a Gulf Coast Bayou, Hurricane Jimmy is a steamy present-day musical noir, influenced by the Southern Gothic plays of Tenessee Williams and James M. Cain's Double Indemnity. We witness the tragic resurrection of entanglements between the wrong guy and a married femme fatale. Side by side, they know it will be impossible to stop themselves from an adulterous affair that will surely end in disaster. Told in stylistic detail with a deeply energetic score, Hurricane Jimmy begs us to reconcile with our pasts, while confronting our futures.    

Hurricane Jimmy is a new musical featuring Book and Lyrics written by Lawrence Alexander and Music written by William Linster. 

This project is being produced by John Bracken and Alana Roberts, Executive Producers, and Emilee Wermenchuk, Producer and Video Curator. 

About The Project

We are working to design, implement, and secure a strong digital presence for Hurricane Jimmy through the creation of an official website, social media platforms, and a live-streamed musical event. Our live-stream event will feature a reading of Hurricane Jimmy followed by a talkback with members of the Creative Team and Producers.  

What We Need and What You Get

Like all good musicals, it takes financial backing from people like you to bring this show to fruition. 

  • We have a fundraising goal of $3000 to make Hurricane Jimmy into the musical we know it can be. Most importantly, this money will allow us to pay our artists. It will also ensure that we can cover all of the fees that we incur from the technology needed to design and implement the musical's digital presence. 
  • This goal also gives us the opportunity to reward donors like you with some pretty unique opportunities! While we accept donations of any amount, we've created six recommended donation increments, each with unique perks. Highlights include official Hurricane Jimmy Merchandise, early access to promotional music videos, access to the official Hurricane Jimmy Cast Recording, and even your name featured as a Supporter or Investor on the Live Steam Event. 
  • Please know that any remaining funds we do not use on the project will not benefit the Producers. Rather, these funds will go directly to Safe Horizons, a shelter for people fleeing domestic abuse situations as well as youth facing housing insecurity in the New York City area, as a donation on behalf of Hurricane Jimmy. 

    Other Ways You Can Help

    Be sure to like and follow us on Facebook at Hurricane Jimmy Musical

    Over the next few weeks, we will be launching Offical Social Media Pages for Hurricane Jimmy across a variety of platforms including Instagram, YouTube, and TikTok. 

    #HurricaneJimmyMusical #TheWreckageFromTheStorm

story:
About The Agency

The Agency Theatre Collective is a non-profit theater company whose mission is to produce new and under-produced plays in Chicago. Since 2011, we have produced five world premieres, including the acclaimed I Wish To Apologize To The People of Illinois and the Jeff nominated Truth in Context. Our most recent production of Chagrin Falls by Mia McCullough was called “… intelligent, probing and compassionate” by Kerry Reid of the Chicago Tribune.

About The Play

Skin for Skin depicts the biblical Job as a Muslim-American contractor in Baghdad who is suspected of aiding Al-Qaeda. He is imprisoned in an Abu Ghraib-type 'black site' and subjected to 'enhanced interrogation' as supervised by an American psychologist. The play explores the unintended consequences of torture in the name of God, country and money. Skin for Skin, originally read at Chicago Dramatists, features choreography from members of Chicago Danztheatre Ensemble and Actors Gymnasium.

About The Playwright

Paul Pasulka is a Chicago playwright and a clinical psychologist in private practice and on faculty at Northwestern University School of Medicine. His plays have been produced and read throughout Chicago and in New York. La Maestra, the story of Renaissance painter Artemisia Gentileschi, received a staged reading with dance, movement and song at Chicago DanzTheatre Ensemble in June 2016 and is scheduled for production in its 2017-18 season. Gruoch, or Lady Macbeth was produced by Death and Pretzels in 2015. When the Levee Breaks was produced as part of The Best of the 10's at Chicago Dramatists and Second City Theatre and was selected as a finalist and for publication at Secret Theatre in New York. Dark Angels was performed at the American Theatre Company (ATC) and Roberto Clemente High School in ATC's Bridge Program. He has worked with Adventure Stage Theatre in assisting middle school students in writing plays for Young Playwrights for Change.

He presented "Neuropsychology, Creativity, and Storytelling" at the Steel Pen Creative Writers' Conference in 2015.

He has presented autobiographical stories throughout Chicago, including at Rhinofest and with the GenNarrations Project of The Goodman Theatre, and was invited to read at The International Storytelling Festival in San Miguel Allende, Mexico in 2014.

What We Need & What You Get

Producing a play of any size is a major undertaking. Your contribution will help in offsetting those costs and allow us to bring the granular realism from the page to stage. Specifically, your donation will help us pay for: theater rental, costumes, set construction, lighting equipment, sound equipment, marketing costs, and paying our artists and crew. 

Not only is your donation tax-deductible, we also have a few perks to say Thank You for your contrinition. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We are sincerely grateful for any donation you can make to support our project. In addition to a donation, you can also help by sharing this campaign with your friends, family and co-workers. Also, we hope you'll come see our show!

story:
Jean E. Taylor

and friends 

(Alex, Andres, Carmen, Elizabeth, Eric, 

Josh, Leslie, Liz, Mark, Pam, Ryan, and Ve)

present

The Basement Plays

A Serious Suite of Foolish Pieces

thebasementplays.com


We need your help to get out of the basement and into the theater!!


Three plays, True Hazards of Childhood, Pants and Skirts, and Elsinore or Bust!, have been developed over the past five years in a process that combines community-based investigative workshops with rehearsal-based improvised research. The Basement Plays have a do-it-yourself, rough-hewn aesthetic paired with sophisticated and surprising theatrical moments. In January 2016, all three plays will premiere in rotating repertory at the Barrow Group. Although the three plays are distinct in storyline, they share the following beliefs:

  • An element of danger often initiates a discovery of new resources
  • Deeply personal motivation is often hidden in seemingly objective analysis
  • Play is the greatest form of research -Einstein


Why Indiegogo?

Without generous givers throughout the past five years, we would not be where we are today. We are so close to attaining our goal of transforming these plays from experimental workshops into fully produced shows that we can share with the world. We only need a little more financial backing to push us the rest of the way. We are seeking to raise $5000 in 5 weeks! Will you consider helping us make this dream a reality?


We've been creating these stories in basements and conference rooms, hair salons(!) and living rooms, and now we want to share these plays with a larger audience. Bringing these plays to The Barrow Group stage provides the opportunity for more people to experience the story and in turn, to contribute to creating more community-based work like The Basement Plays. At the core of all three plays is the belief that embracing the ridiculous and the less-than-perfect is a sure way to celebrate humanity. 

As one audience member said, "I think you have discovered the antidote to existential angst."



Where will the funds go?

The People [$2500-$2800]: we need to compensate our talented cast and crew for all their years of hard work (we are talking literal blood, sweat, and tears, folks. trust me, it's talent worth compensating!)


The Objects [$500-$750]: we need specific props and costumes to best share these stories with you (this cast is indeed at a complete and utter loss without their proper hats!)


The Transport [$1200-$1500]: we need to get everything TO the theater so we can actually put on a show for you (it would be awkward if YOU showed up and the CAST did not!)


The Display [$400]: we need lights to illuminate us and a stage to stand on, of course (you've heard of "no shirt, no shoes, no service?" well similarly: no lights, no stage, no show!) 




For tickets, show dates, and more information visit thebasementplays.com!


**Please also share this campaign with your friends and family via an email or social media. The more buzz we can create the closer to the stage we will be!**





The Basement Plays is a sponsored artist with The Performance Zone Inc (dba The Field), a not-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the performing arts community. Contributions to The Field earmarked for The Basement Plays are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 906 New York, NY 10038, phone: 212-691-6969 or for our national charities registration. A copy of our latest financial report may be obtained from The Field or from the Office of Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.

story:
Short Summary

From November 5th-14th, we are presenting my two act play, Devotion at Mad Lab Theater in Columbus, Ohio.  It is set in the early 1990s in New York City, where a young, female visual artist shares her loft with her current boyfriend, a videographer, and, initially, with her ex-boyfriend, an actor. The actor wants to reignite their relationship, but he is thwarted by his own previous misbehavior as well as the new boyfriend’s zealous interference. The play examines the pressures of making art and maintaining basic relationships under the high pressure conditions of life in New York, and it is about the demands that makes and the sacrifices it requires. In the end, it is the woman who gets the first break, but at a cost to all of the characters.  You’ll wonder: what does devotion mean?  And to whom or what? 

If the idea of supporting world premiere new work is exciting to you, you like the idea of adding substantively to the local theater scene, or you just like the concept of the play, please support us financially.  We’ve got lots of incentives for you at all levels and are grateful for any contribution you can make. 

Thank you. Please DONATE and bring your friends to see the show!

What We Need & What You Get

We know you will love the perks and hope you can find one that matches your passion for new theater!

The down payment for the theater has been paid and they take a portion of ticket sales revenue. The rehearsal space has been donated by the producer. This leaves the items listed below to cover in order to produce the show and to ensure an audience. 

Creative personnel  $2,500

Scenic elements  $1,500

Publicity and Advertising  $2,000

Total needed  $6,000

The Impact

We feel it is important for someone in the community to do original plays, because it offers a venue for those who are interested in seeing new, unique work, and allows actors to stretch in roles unfamiliar to them. Original work, especially original work performed where it is written, speaks to its particular time and place, as all art inevitably does. So original plays come from a common context with their audiences. They are the plays that can most disrupt and transform perceptions precisely because they offer unknown texts, visions that are not pre-digested or mediated by anyone else. It is the experience of play going in its rawest form. 

We also hope to nurture a repertory company with a steady ensemble of paid actors, directors, and writers that we work with on a regular basis. Our goal is not only to produce as many world premieres as possible but to run all of them as long as possible and to show them to as many people as possible. It is essential to have the talent available to accomplish this, which means paying fair wages to artists who contribute to the success of A&B Theatricals. It is ultimately the performance of a show that not only makes it a financial success but also completes the play in the way it was intended.

Risks & Challenges

How do we guarantee an audience? That's where you come in! Your support leads to passionate people in theater seats. Funds raised will allow A&B to promote Devotion and subsequent productions to broaden our reach in the community.

How does A&B grow from here? There is an unmet demand for unique work in Columbus. Using this crowdfunding platform and traditional marketing will maximize exposure to our mission. In addition, we know that you, our supporters, will grow A&B exponentially by sharing your ideas, auditioning for shows, offering services, and shouting from the rooftops.

Other Ways You Can Help

Pass this on! You are connected to hundreds of passionate friends and family that we want to know!
story_txt:
Short Summary 
From November 5th-14th, we
are presenting my two act play, Devotion
at Mad Lab Theater in Columbus, Ohio.  It
is set in the early 1990s in New York City, where a young,
female visual artist shares her loft with her current boyfriend, a
videographer, and, initially, with her ex-boyfriend, an actor. The actor wants
to reignite their relationship, but he is thwarted by his own previous
misbehavior as well as the new boyfriend’s zealous interference. The play
examines the pressures of making art and maintaining basic relationships under
the high pressure conditions of life in New York, and it is about the demands
that makes and the sacrifices it requires. In the end, it is the woman who gets
the first break, but at a cost to all of the characters.  You’ll wonder: what does devotion mean?  And to whom or what? 
If the idea of supporting world
premiere new work is exciting to you, you like the idea of adding substantively
to the local theater scene, or you just like the concept of the play, please
support us financially.  We’ve got lots
of incentives for you at all levels and are grateful for any contribution you
can make.  
Thank you. Please DONATE and bring your friends to see the
show!   What We Need & What You Get 
We know you will love the perks and hope you can find one that matches your passion for new theater!
The down payment for the theater has been paid and they take a portion of ticket sales revenue. The rehearsal space has been donated by the producer. This leaves the items listed below to cover in order to produce the show and to ensure an audience. 
Creative personnel  $2,500
Scenic elements  $1,500
Publicity and Advertising  $2,000
Total needed  $6,000
  The Impact 
We feel it is important for someone
in the community to do original plays, because it offers a venue for those who
are interested in seeing new, unique work, and allows actors to stretch in
roles unfamiliar to them. Original work, especially original work performed where it is written, speaks to its particular time and place, as all art
inevitably does. So original plays come from a common context with their
audiences. They are the plays that can most disrupt and transform perceptions
precisely because they offer unknown texts, visions that are not pre-digested
or mediated by anyone else. It is the experience of play going in its rawest
form. 
We also hope to nurture a
repertory company with a steady ensemble of paid actors, directors, and writers
that we work with on a regular basis. Our goal is not only to produce as many
world premieres as possible but to run all of them as long as possible and to
show them to as many people as possible. It is essential to have the talent
available to accomplish this, which means paying fair wages to artists who
contribute to the success of A&B Theatricals. It is ultimately the performance
of a show that not only makes it a financial success but also completes the
play in the way it was intended.   Risks & Challenges How do we guarantee an audience? That's where you come in! Your support leads to passionate people in theater seats. Funds raised will allow A&B to promote Devotion and subsequent productions to broaden our reach in the community.
How does A&B grow from here? There is an unmet demand for unique work in Columbus. Using this crowdfunding platform and traditional marketing will maximize exposure to our mission. In addition, we know that you, our supporters, will grow A&B exponentially by sharing your ideas, auditioning for shows, offering services, and shouting from the rooftops.
    Other Ways You Can Help Pass this on! You are connected to hundreds of passionate friends and family that we want to know!

story:
Short Summary

"Summer of Stories" is produced by hereandnow theatre company in association with the Rosenthal Theater at Inner City Arts.  Since 1989, hereandnow theatre company has been committed to the idea that "Everybody has a story to tell,"  and this summer we will be presenting a series of eight plays, two of which be fully staged, over a  two-week period.  "Summer of Stories" brings together over 50 artists - actors, writers, and directors to bring these pieces to life.

 What We Need & What You Get

To make this festival a success, we need to raise $6,000 for rehearsal and theater rental, marketing, and production costs (equipment, lighting, sound, video, etc.).  With your contribution, we would like to raise more than $6,000 so that we can compensate all of the artists involved with more than just the Equity minimum in the hopes of starting a trend of paying artists an actual living wage for their talents and their time.
