To make this festival a success, we need to raise $6,000 for rehearsal and theater rental, marketing, and production costs (equipment, lighting, sound, video, etc.).  With your contribution, we would like to raise more than $6,000 so that we can compensate all of the artists involved with more than just the Equity minimum in the hopes of starting a trend of paying artists an actual living wage for their talents and their time.

story:
What is this?

Hi, I’m Ry!  You may have seen me behind the scenes, in a staged reading, dancing onstage as a gnome, reading my writing into a mike, waiting in the lobby of City MD, checking your coat, selling you theatre tickets, walking your neighbor's dog, finishing your left overs, or perhaps in a tiger suit running through a park fountain.

This play, Interabang, is a project that has been in and out of incubation for almost six years now - it started as a five minute project and has expanded into what will be a full-length, genre-hopping, original play going up as part of Ars Nova’s ANT (All New Talent) Festival for one night only on June 13th at 7:00 P.M @ Ars Nova Theater (511 W 54th St, New York, NY 10019). Ars Nova and ANT Fest has presented work from countless artists, providing a home for work that might be seen as too weird or multi-genre for other NYC theaters. They've even been profiled in The New Yorker for their unique brand of curation.

The Team:

creator/performer: Ry Szelong

director: Bryn Herdrich

assistant director / stage manager / media designer: Jaye Hunt

dramaturg: Kaela Mei-Shing Garvin

co-producer: Cassidy Dawn Graves

costume designer: Elonna Bettini

scenic designer: Raphael Mishler

sound designer: Renee Yeong

cast: Amanda Centeno, Becca Q. Co, Erica Huang, Sandra W. Lee, Trevor Liu, Paul Ketchum, Arianne Recto

Some backstory: growing up, I became obsessed with a supposedly true story I was told over and over again about a cowardly ancestor and a subsequent familial curse...what it has led to is Interabang: A pseudo-autobiographical, coming of age, fragmented family drama that grapples with the conflicts that arise from the dissonance between the cultures we claim for ourselves and those we inherit from our past. It follows Ry, his parents, his ancestors, his siblings, his dog, and their backyard water demon as they grapple with shame, queerness, and Asian-American identity and how those cultures manifest in their mixed-race family’s lineage... in a carefully curated suburban chaos that overtakes a solo-show gone wrong.

At its core, this is a deeply personal testament of hapa-ness, identity, and legacy that aims to centers stories that are other-ed, ambiguous, or unnameable, while also questioning and challenging this power of artistry. 

We are proud and blessed to have a cast of such talented Asian-American actors that span across generational and disciplinary boundaries, each bringing their own individual, authentic experiences to the table.  It is truly a beautiful thing of visibility and collaboration, and I am excited for it to be onstage.

Up until this point, excerpts of the play have been read at Nuyorican Poets Cafe and INTAR Theatre's Steep Salon, a scene was presented with Undiscovered Countries at Bizarre Bar, a horror-inspired spinoff was put up with Insomnium Theatre Company, and a workshop production was presented last summer at Dixon Place's HOT! Festival - and NOW, all the pieces will come crashing together with a full cast and a design and production team in a fully realized production.

What do you need from me?

  • I have a lot of amazing collaborators on this piece, and I wish that I could compensate them fully for their time and energy. Your donations will help us achieve even a fraction of that goal!
  • Our brilliant and talented design team needs funding to be able to work their magic! Your money helps them give our actors clothes to wear, set pieces to stand on, and props to use. 
  • Rehearsing in New York is expensive! We'll use some of your donations to find rehearsal space, print scripts, and buy tape.

If you're unable to financially contribute, you can help us out by sharing our campaign on social media! You can also share our facebook event or buy tickets online.

story:
'Juniper Tree' is the first installment of a new collaborative theatre project featuring an innovative fusion of puppetry and mask performance. Co-producers and designers Andrew Murdock and Sean Devare are New York-based artists who love stories both strange and fantastical. 

We seek to bring unique and visually compelling theatrical experiences to diverse audiences using fairy tales and folk stories as inspiration.

We are now developing an adaptation of the Grimms’ fairy tale The Juniper Tree using specially engineered life-size marionettes and original character masks that hold the stage together simultaneously. Our team so far includes director Sarah Plotkin; stage manager Corinne Hastings; performers Jessica Annunziata, Monica Lerch and Leah Ogawa; and musicians Dominic Boyle and Maya Lazaro. Each collaborator’s skills and ideas are invaluable to our highly fluid and democratic process. 

The piece will officially debut at Dixon Place this September as a part of their annual Puppet Blok series. With this project we believe we can bring new energy and exposure to the ancient traditions of puppet and mask theatre.


What We Need

Producing theatre is always an uphill battle in New York City. We hope to raise at least $3,000 to cover our production costs like rehearsal and performance space rentals. We also want to compensate our cast and crew for their time and talents. We will be able to incorporate additional design elements to tell the story more holistically.

The more funds we raise, the higher the quality of our production. While our budget is modest in comparison to most shows in New York, we aim to achieve a sustainable practice in developing work that underscores the beauty, versatility and simplicity of theatre.

Reaching anything beyond our goal will also help us develop this project past Juniper Tree alone. With our dedicated team of interdisciplinary artists, we are ready to adapt any fairy tale or folk story using our unique creative process.


Other Ways You Can Help

If money is an obstacle, we encourage you to spread the word about our campaign! Simply sharing our link and helping us connect with puppetry enthusiasts goes a long way.

Thank you so much!

story:
Soul Troubadour: a one-man presentation by Kevin Sandbloom
incorporating song, story, spoken-word & sound effects.

This is a project that I've been working on for about 2 years on and off. 
I had a few false starts but had the basic idea and premise in mind for 
a unique show that I could build using the elements in the above description.
I've been working with a loop pedal for a few years now and I wanted to see
it be used for its full potential. In this play I use it for background, song beds
and to build dynamics during the songs and spoken word sections. No one that
I know of has done anything quite like this. Weave live looping, spoken
word/monologues and songs together in this particular way. 

The show is much different logistically than my regular shows because
it requires a theatre space (or something with that focused audience element)
and booking those spaces is different than a regular show because many of them
require a deposit of some kind. Anywhere from $100 to $500. This isn't ALWAYS
the case but 70% of the time it is. I'm also playing a few different instruments in
this show, keyboard, guitar, percussion and it needs a lot of set up. Cartage is also
necessary for the equipment involved. I woulld also like to add a visual component
to the show - either slides, video or backdrops.

Where does the funding come in? Well, beyond the deposits required to secure
spaces, my main hurdle is letting people know about the show. It takes a serious
marketing push to really get folks to know what this show really is and what it's
about but you can't really know until you see it. 

What the show is is a 90 minute scripted play. It's partially autobiographical but
it's also topical. Much of the political and social awareness that was a part of my
early songwriting is brought to the fore. I'm talking about social issues and getting
dialogues started in order to raise awareness, promote positivity and change. I'm
also telling a few stories about life on the road and life as a married musician.

What I would like to do is get this play in front of a wider audience and eventually
book it into larger capacity theaters as the show gains awareness.

The show needs promotional tools. 

-posters

-a CD of songs from the show

-a professional promotional trailer

-Tshirts

As well as logistical tools.

-venue deposits

-travel expenses

One of the exciting things about this campaign is that I will be staging the show
in Kansas City during the run of the campaign. Backers and all interested will be
able to witness the show and be a part of the live taping of the show at a really
beautiful venue called Dream Studios. You will be able to follow the set-up and
see the culmination of the effort involved and the response of those present will
give everyone a sense of the specialness of this presentation.

I want to bring this show to YOUR city. I want everyone to be able to experience
it. From the feedback I've received so far, it's really something that deserves to
be seen. With your help, I can make that happen.

Thank you,
Kevin Sandbloom

 

Please use the great IndieGoGo share tools.

story:
The once in a lifetime opportunity to study with Crystal Pite and Pol Heyvaert, and Theatre Replacement’s Maiko Bae Yamamoto and James Long at the New Aesthetics Performance Intensive.

I've been dancing for my whole life.  I've danced and toured with companies, made work for film and stage and constantly pushed myself to explore new frontiers in dance in order to understand the mysterious and powerful ritual of performance, to connect the often indecipherable form of contemproary dance to a larger context in hopes of illuminating its transformative power.

At the urging of of some colleagues, I threw my name in the hat to be considered for one of the 20 spots in the New Aesthetics performance intensive, a summer retreat in Vancouver B.C. where established artists to receive time, space, and mentorship from some of the best people in the fields of dance and theatre (including one of my all time favorites, Crystal Pite).  To my surprise, I was not only accepted but offered a full scholarship to attend. 

I'm grateful and elated for this opportunity but still facing the financail challenge of attending.  I have to take time away from teaching and consulting (the things that pay my bills).  I have to cover travel to and from Vancouver as well as pay for housing there, which is turning out to be quite expensive. 

I'm reaching out to you to consider sponsoring my trip to Vancouver.  This is somewhat different from support I have asked for in the past.  It is quite personal. I'm asking for your investment in my development as an artist, your confidence that this will further propel my work and the enrich the teaching and sharing I can do in the dance communities I'm a part of-- in Seattle, Portland, and elsewhere, working with begining to professional dancers, with able-bodied folks as well as those living with neuro-degenerative diseases.

In return, I will bring you along, so to speak.  I will send postcards from the program, post reflections and writing online, and share the documentation of my time there.
 
I have spent weeks contemplating how to make this work and just before submitting a new credit card applicaiton, I stopped and asked myself, is there another way?  When you are working as an artist, you never get an an influx of cash that helps you pay back your debt and it is rare to get a professional development grant. You have to believe in your work and ask for support.
 
With hope and great humility, I thank you for your time and for consideration either way.
 
Warmly,
 
Shannon
 
PS - if by some chance you have a lead on housing in Vancouver, please get in touch.

story:
The Project

My project is supported by the Arts Council England, City College Brighton, Hove Museum and Format Display, Burgess Hill.

I want to tell the story of the young Hawaiian princess Ka'iulani who lived in Hove in 1892. She came here to further her education and boarded with a governess called Phebe Rooke. Ka'iulani would have gone on to become queen of Hawai'i but for the annexation of her country by the United States. Ka'iulani, who is little known in the UK, was talented and beautiful. She was proud of her dual Scottish and Kanaka Maoli ancestry, and became a Victorian royal who could both surf - she was reputed to be quite skilled in wave riding - and play croquet. She both ate poi and raw fish and attended elegant afternoon teas. She died tragically young, at the age of 23, and never married.


I want the film to be very much rooted in the streets of Hove where she lived and must have spent her time. Although we know that she surfed in her native Hawai'i, I think it is unlikely that she surfed here. I feel sure she must have stood on Hove seafront in the British drizzle and looked longingly out at the waves and beyond to her beloved country. I believe she was happy here although it was a very turbulent time for Hawai'i and her family and she must have felt very anxious at times.



The project includes:

1. A short film - a creative interpretation of the life of the Hawaiian princess Ka'iulani and her time in Hove. I will use a mixture of animation and live action, archive photos and maps. The film will also contain a hula sequence set in Brunswick Gardens.

2. A series of hula workshops and a performance of a dance dedicated to the princess. Hula is a sacred and intrinsic part of Hawaiian culture and we are hoping to be "gifted" a dance by a senior kumu, or dance teacher.  During the dance workshops this hula will be "gifted" onwards to some dance students (of a similar age to the princess) in Brighton and Hove. This will lead to a dance performance next May, thus in a way, "gifting" the princess back to the city.

3. An installation at Hove museum summer 2014 showing the film as well as display panels about hula, Ka'iulani, her significance to Hawai'i and to the history of surfing. We will also document the "gifting" process.
And we will be running workshops in the education room there, including dance and lei making. Hope to see you there!




The Team

This is a bigger project than I have done before and I will be helped by quite a few people including:

Jennifer Maile Kaku - choreographer, dancer and adviser on Hawaiian culture.

Jim Lee - Consultant director, technical adviser.

Karin Mori - An artist from Hawai'i, based in Brighton, Karin will create some of the artwork. (www.karinmori.co.uk)

Sarah Stricket - Animator (http://vimeo.com/sasskid)

Mark Wilson - Writer. Mark will help me write the script, focusing particularly on the relationship between Ka'iualni and her landlady Phebe Rooke. (www.markwilsonplays.co.uk)

Dave Batchelor, Printer (www.formatdisplay.co.uk)

Alan Couldrey - Campaign advisor


The Funding

I have some funding from the Arts Council and I am lucky to have some "in kind" support from Hove museum and from City College, Brighton where I work. My partner, Dave Batchelor who runs a large format digital print company will print the display panels for the exhibition. However, this is a big project and will involve a lot of time and skills. Some of it I can do myself, some I will need to pull in other people. The animated sections will be quite complex and will of course, take lots and and lots lots of time. I also want to create a website for the project on which we will have a kind of "Victorian Google Map" showing the route around Hove that the princess would have walked.

I am very grateful for all the support and advice I have received from friends and colleagues here and contacts in Hawai'i. There seems to be a lot of goodwill towards the princess. I hope I can create something that does her justice and conveys something of her spirit.

Your money will help me do this.

I want to make the best the best film I possibly can, as well as help some young dancers gain new skills and learn about hula, a sacred and special part of Hawaiian culture.

Your money will help me do this.

Once made, I need to make sure that the film gets seen at festivals and has a life beyond my book shelf.

I want to put together a really good exhibition that will get people talking about the princess.

Your money will help me do this.

Mahalo no kokua

Jane
story_txt:
The Project My project is supported by the Arts Council England, City College Brighton, Hove Museum and Format Display, Burgess Hill.I want to tell the story of the young Hawaiian princess Ka'iulani who lived in Hove in 1892. She came here to further her education and boarded with a governess called Phebe Rooke. Ka'iulani would have gone on to become queen of Hawai'i but for the annexation of her country by the United States. Ka'iulani, who is little known in the UK, was talented and beautiful. She was proud of her dual Scottish and Kanaka Maoli ancestry, and became a Victorian royal who could both surf - she was reputed to be quite skilled in wave riding - and play croquet. She both ate poi and raw fish and attended elegant afternoon teas. She died tragically young, at the age of 23, and never married.
I want the film to be very much rooted in the streets of Hove where she lived and must have spent her time. Although we know that she surfed in her native Hawai'i, I think it is unlikely that she surfed here. I feel sure she must have stood on Hove seafront in the British drizzle and looked longingly out at the waves and beyond to her beloved country. I believe she was happy here although it was a very turbulent time for Hawai'i and her family and she must have felt very anxious at times.



The project includes:1. A short film - a creative interpretation of the life of the Hawaiian princess Ka'iulani and her time in Hove. I will use a mixture of animation and live action, archive photos and maps. The film will also contain a hula sequence set in Brunswick Gardens.2. A series of hula workshops and a performance of a dance dedicated to the princess. Hula is a sacred and intrinsic part of Hawaiian culture and we are hoping to be "gifted" a dance by a senior kumu, or dance teacher.  During the dance workshops this hula will be "gifted" onwards to some dance students (of a similar age to the princess) in Brighton and Hove. This will lead to a dance performance next May, thus in a way, "gifting" the princess back to the city. 3. An installation at Hove museum summer 2014 showing the film as well as display panels about hula, Ka'iulani, her significance to Hawai'i and to the history of surfing. We will also document the "gifting" process.And we will be running workshops in the education room there, including dance and lei making. Hope to see you there!
The TeamThis is a bigger project than I have done before and I will be helped by quite a few people including:
Jennifer Maile Kaku - choreographer, dancer and adviser on Hawaiian culture.
Jim Lee - Consultant director, technical adviser.
Karin Mori - An artist from Hawai'i, based in Brighton, Karin will create some of the artwork. (www.karinmori.co.uk)
Sarah Stricket - Animator (http://vimeo.com/sasskid)
Mark Wilson - Writer. Mark will help me write the script, focusing particularly on the relationship between Ka'iualni and her landlady Phebe Rooke. (www.markwilsonplays.co.uk)
Dave Batchelor, Printer (www.formatdisplay.co.uk)
Alan Couldrey - Campaign advisor

The Funding
I have some funding from the Arts Council and I am lucky to have some "in kind" support from Hove museum and from City College, Brighton where I work. My partner, Dave Batchelor who runs a large format digital print company will print the display panels for the exhibition. However, this is a big project and will involve a lot of time and skills. Some of it I can do myself, some I will need to pull in other people. The animated sections will be quite complex and will of course, take lots and and lots lots of time. I also want to create a website for the project on which we will have a kind of "Victorian Google Map" showing the route around Hove that the princess would have walked.
I am very grateful for all the support and advice I have received from friends and colleagues here and contacts in Hawai'i. There seems to be a lot of goodwill towards the princess. I hope I can create something that does her justice and conveys something of her spirit.
Your money will help me do this.
I want to make the best the best film I possibly can, as well as help some young dancers gain new skills and learn about hula, a sacred and special part of Hawaiian culture. 
Your money will help me do this.
Once made, I need to make sure that the film gets seen at festivals and has a life beyond my book shelf.
I want to put together a really good exhibition that will get people talking about the princess. 
Your money will help me do this.
Mahalo no kokua


Jane

story:
Project Summary

Mother, Mother  is a journalistic theater piece about contemporary parenthood, based on interviews with a diverse group of mothers.  Mother, Mother examines the issues of gender equity, economic disparity, and cultural pressure that disproportionately impact many of today's mothers.  We are collecting interviews in a variety of locations throughout the United States, as well as in Sweden.  Through examining the daily lives of mothers in these very different cultures, we ask: "Whose responsibility is it to respond to the changing needs of mothers and families?"

This piece is being developed by a group of theater artists who are also currently mothers to young children. Part of our process has been to examine the specific challenges of creating family forward workplace flexibility in the theater. One outcome of this project will be a comprehensive body of research on improving conditions for parents who work in the theater.

Who we are: 

Mother, Mother is directed and written by PETE co-founder Kate Sanderson Holly, who has created over ten full-length original, ensemble-devised theatre productions, and specializes in Contemporary Performance practice.  She has teamed up with Sojourn Theatre's Hannah Treuhaft, who brings to the project an expertise in combining artistic innovation with theater for social change and community dialogue.  Other key collaborators include Catherine Ming T'ien Duffly (Assistant Professor of Theater at Reed College); and ensemble members Aiyana Cunningham, Sofia Dubrawsky, and Nikki Weaver (Co-Founder of Portland Playhouse).  Mother, Mother is produced by PETE (www.petensemble.org) , in collaboration with Sojourn Theatre (http://www.sojourntheatre.com).  

Where we are now: 

We are currently at the end of our first year of research and development.  In this time, we have held workshops with groups of mothers to facilitate conversation and generate key ideas, we have conducted interviews with dozens of mothers from a variety of locations, and we have built an extensive body of research from non-fiction sources, including media representation and statistical data.  We are now in the process of transforming this content into a compelling live theatrical event. We are still at the beginning stages of our rehearsal process, but we will be marking the end of this first phase of development with a work-in-progress showing for the public on March 22nd and 23rd, 2014. 

In the next phase of work, we will expand our research to include interviews with mothers from throughout the United States, as well as in Sweden.  We will craft this content into a full production of the piece, scheduled to premiere in 2015.  

Why we need you:  

We were very fortunate to receive support from a learning exchange grant through the Network of Ensemble Theaters.  This grant helped us to launch the project, but does not completely cover the costs of our work-in-progress showing.  Your contribution will allow us to compensate the artists for their time and childcare expenses.  In addition, your support will enable us to carry the project forward into our next stage of development, where we move toward a full production.  This is the most vital time for you to contribute to the project, as meeting our goal will ensure that we can continue this work.  

What are you helping us to do?  

Mother, Mother is facilitating meaningful public discourse around the most pressing issues facing today's mothers and families.  The mother stories we have collected so far point to some significant gaps in public policy, infrastructural support, and cultural change when it comes to ensuring a sustainable future for families.  These stories highlight and complement the statistical data that so many social scientists and political advocacy groups have compiled:  

-The wage gap disproportionately impacts mothers: Mothers earn 60 cents for every dollar a father makes, while women without children earn 94 cents for every dollar childless men are paid.

-Motherhood is the leading indicator of poverty in old age

-Single motherhood is the leading indicator of poverty at any age

-The United States is one of only 4 countries in the world that does not guarantee paid maternity leave to its mothers.  The outcomes of this can be seen in many of the stories we have collected, from the single mom who ended up in a homeless shelter with her newborn, to the mom who lost her place in a prestigious Phd program.  

We believe this is a conversation that everybody should be participating in, and the stories we are sharing get to the heart of these issues in ways that will both entertain and educate you.  

What We Need & What You Get

At this time, we need $5000 to get through our work-in-progress showing and launch the next phase of development.  Your money will go to:  

-Artist compensation.  We are all theater professionals who have been working in this field for a decade or more.  Adequate compensation is a fundamental part of sustaining high-quality performance.  

-Child care costs.  As mothers to young children, it can be very expensive just to make time to work.  An ongoing goal of this process is to raise enough funding to partially cover the cost of the child care that is making this show possible.  

-Boost into the future.  The financial support that launched this project will be gone by the end of March, but our project is far from finished.  Help us keep moving it forward!  

Perks:  

As an investor in this piece, you should get some of the returns!  We offer some great perks, and because we are a 501 (c) 3, all of your donations are tax deductible (minus the market value of the perk that you choose).  

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are not able to contribute financially, we could still use your help!  Please share our campaign with your personal networks, particularly anybody who you know that cares about the issues facing today's mothers, or just loves great live performance.

story:
NEW GOAL: $4,600

What's Going On?

Dustin Wills, Kate Tarker, Daniel Schlosberg, and Chris Bannow are working on a new show WITH SONGS! called AWFUL EVENT! or The Assassination of Abraham Lincoln as Interpreted by the Unseen Internal Organs of His Wife. 

AWFUL EVENT! uses the internal physiological life of Mary Todd Lincoln to explore nineteenth century politics, fashion, medicine, social mores, and theatre; as well as the greatest of subjects: Love, loss, and life. Many more details about what we're trying to make can be found way down below!

This show is being presented as part of Ars Nova's ANTFest on June 24th. We will also be in residency with New York Theatre Workshop at Adelphi University in early June to workshop the show.

Tickets to the ONE-NIGHT-ONLY event can be found here: http://arsnovanyc.com/antfest/june-24

Ars Nova ANTFest is an annual festival of All New Talent designed to showcase new, hybrid theater work from NYC's most adventurous emerging artists. 

What do we need?

We are raising funds to pay people. The members of this team will be dedicating a considerable amount of time to mounting this project, and they are great in number: The creators, the performers, the designers, and the technicians. 3/4 of the money raised here goes directly to the artists, and the other 1/4 goes to production elements such as costumes, props, and scenic elements.

But the fundraising we do here does so much more than simply help us mount a single evenings performance. We plan for this project to have a life beyond the Ars Nova ANTFest - and this showing marks a crucial point in the development process: the point where an audience gets to first encounter the show. From there we would continue to tinker with the show and find additional opportunities for workshop and production. So anything given to the project at this stage helps us in the long run!


Who is on the team?

DUSTIN WILLS (Creator/Director) is an NYC-based director originally from Texas. Recent projects: The Foundry Theatre’s O, Earth; Lorca’s Once Five Years Pass at Williamstown Theatre Festival; Yale Baroque Opera’s Xerse. He is a two-time recipient of the Princess Grace Award for Theatre, a Drama League and Boris Sagal directing fellow, former artistic director of the Yale Summer Cabaret and for a couple of years gave rogue tours of the Vatican. MFA Yale School of Drama.

KATE TARKER (Creator/Playwright) wrote THUNDERBODIES, An Almanac for Farmers and Lovers in Mexico (2015 Kilroys List) and Laura and the Sea (finalist, L. Arnold Weissberger award). Developed by The Lark, the Playwrights’ Center and The O’Neill National Playwrights Conference. Recipient of a Jerome Fellowship, MacDowell Colony Fellowship,Tofte Lake Center residency and the Kennedy Center’s National Science Playwriting Award. Ars Nova Play Group. Under Commission by The Wilma. M.F.A. Yale.

DANIEL SCHLOSBERG (Creator/Composer) compositions have been performed by the Dover Quartet, Nashville Symphony Orchestra, Buffalo Philharmonic, Lorelei Ensemble, Amphion Quartet and Aspen Contemporary Ensemble and featured at Carnegie Hall, Williamstown Theatre Festival, and Royal Albert Hall. Daniel received a 2014 Charles Ives Scholarship from the American Academy of Arts and Letters and two ASCAP Morton Gould Young Composer Awards. Daniel continues to perform around the world and he co-founded the composer-performer ensemble Invisible Anatomy.

CHRIS BANNOW (Creator/Performer) appeared in the Williamstown, Broadway and West End productions of The Elephant Man. Films include #Screamers and Not Fade Away. BFA Boston University, MFA Yale School of Drama.

ADDITIONAL TEAM MEMBERS:

Adina Verson

Ato Blankson-Wood

Birgit Huppuch

Jamilyn Manning-White

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Come see the show!
  • Tell your friends
  • Like posts associated with AWFUL EVENT! on social media
  • Share this funding link on your social media pages
  • Send people to our website: http://arsnovanyc.com/antfest/june-24


More details about AWFUL EVENT! or The Assassination of Abraham Lincoln as Interpreted by the Unseen Internal Organs of His Wife

Eleven systems make up the human body – skeletal, respiratory, muscular, integumentary, endocrine, nervous, reproductive, digestive, cardiovascular, immune, and excretory – each directly related to another, all functioning as a whole. In a single second these systems perform countless tasks based on stimuli received from the outside world. This body becomes the stage on which a number of events play out: the microcosmic actions of the body’s unseen organs during of a moment of trauma, a private story of love and loss, the public assassination of the President, and an exploration of post-Civil War America including its harsh social practices, theatrical and musical traditions, complex race politics, and bizarre medical practice. 

How does the totality of one person’s life, with all of their experiences, converge in a singular moment of trauma or rebellion? Can we enhance our practice of looking at history by investigating how the body reacted to it? 

Taking inspiration from Meyerhold’s Montage of Attractions, Brecht’s Lehrstückes, and early 19th century American traditions of medicine shows, vaudeville, and circus, the evening takes a variety of shapes and offers a way to read our own humanity by experiencing the totality of another human’s physiological experience of history.

story:
What is Different Choices?

Different Choices is a small theater company in Kansas City, MO dedicated to always presenting theatre in a new way, whether it be a new work or a new interpretation of an older work. Started by Bob Linebarger and Denver Little in 2012, Different Choices have put on two productions so far: "The Bottom of Everything", an original play written by Denver Little, in 2012 and "Danny and the Deep Blue Sea" in 2014, usually presented as a heavy drama, but interpreted more as a romantic dark comedy under the direction of Bob Linebarger. 

Matt and Ben

Now, Different Choices is BACK with another production in mind. This one is a wonderfully hilarious play called Matt and Ben. Written by Mindy Kaling (Kelly from "The Office", "The Mindy Project") and Brenda Withers, this play is about a young Matt Damon and Ben Affleck writing their Academy Award winning script of Good Will Hunting, but approaches it as if the script literally just fell from the sky. 

Why Matt and Ben?

Matt and Ben is a play close to the hearts of Bob and Denver, for many reasons. One, it is a play about two long-time friends creating art together, and the successes and failures that come with. Bob and Denver have known each other for longer than they can remember, so they feel this play represents a good portrait of their lives and their long-time friendship. Also, Bob and Denver did high school forensics together and presented a 10 minute cutting of Matt and Ben, and ended up getting 16th at a national forensics competition. So producing the full production of this play is a "bucket-list" choice and what a better time to cross it off our bucket lists while we are still young!

What is the Different Choice?

Our different choice is not necessarily in the interpretation of this play, but more in the production of it. In forensics, Denver and I collaborated to put together many pieces. For Matt and Ben, we are going to approach it just like one of those pieces, and play almost every part in the production process. This means we are going to be producing, directing, acting and designing this play together. If there was a tagline to what we are doing, it would be: "Just two guys puttin' on a show". We at Different Choices enjoy and support those who produce their own work, and we want to play a part in making producing look simpler. Not easier, as producing will always be a difficult and tedious task, but if producing can be made simpler, maybe more artists will feel more confident in producing. There are so many great artists in KC and Different Choices wants to see all of them working!!

How Will Your Donation Help?

Although Different Choices operates on a "no-budget theater" mindset, there are things we have to pay for that are outside of our ability to pay for ourselves. For example, the venue cost to produce at The Buffalo Room for a two-week run is $1500. Also, the rights to this play are around $700. We also want to pay for the few people we do bring in to help, including a stage manager. So your donation will not only help us put on this great production, but is essential to the life of this production. 

Anything Else?

Yes, actually! Every show we produce from this show forward will donate part of the proceeds made to a charity that fits the show. The charity we chose for Matt and Ben is WATER.ORG. We chose water.org because it is the main charity Matt Damon and Ben Affleck advocate for, and after reading everything that water.org does for the world, providing water to those far less fortunate than us in Kansas City, we are ecstatic to donate to such a great cause. For more information on water.org, visit their website at the link below:
http://water.org/about/
Show dates for Matt and Ben: June 29th to July 11th at The Buffalo Room
Thank you all for your support and cheers to KC theater!!

Every show we produce from this show forward will donate part of the proceeds made to a charity that fits the show. The charity we chose for Matt and Ben is WATER.ORG. We chose water.org because it is the main charity Matt Damon and Ben Affleck advocate for, and after reading everything that water.org does for the world, providing water to those far less fortunate than us in Kansas City, we are ecstatic to donate to such a great cause. For more information on water.org, visit their website at the link below:
http://water.org/about/
Show dates for Matt and Ben: June 29th to July 11th at The Buffalo RoomThank you all for your support and cheers to KC theater!!

story:
ABOUT THE PLAY AND THE TEAM 

Down the Road by Lee Blessing is a crime drama about a crime writing couple, a serial killer and how far they will go to write a book. 

Husband and wife, Dan and Iris Henniman travel to an isolated town with only a couple gas stations, McDonalds, a motel and a prison. They have been hired to write an account on William Reach's crimes, specifically nineteen women he has murdered. Throughout the play we learn that there may have been more than the nineteen victims. As Iris tries to get into Reach's head more and more, she soon ponders the ethics of what she and Dan are doing and wonders are they, in fact, glorifying a serial killer? Is there even a way to resolve this twisted controversy?  

The play is Gretchen Hannah Burke and Claire Buckley's senior project. They are each students in the Theatre and Performance program at SUNY Purchase College. 

Down the Road will be presented in the Humanities Theatre in the Durst Humanities Building at SUNY Purchase College on February 18th - 20th. 

CAST: 

Iris Henniman: Claire Buckley 

Dan Henniman: Jeffrey Weisz 

William Reach: Nicholas Tyler Corbin 

PRODUCTION TEAM: 

Director/Producer: Gretchen Hannah Burke 

Stage Manager/Assistant Director: Ethan Steers

Scenic Designer: Lacey Ballard: 

Lighting Designer: Sophie Porter-Hyatt 

Costume Designer: Claire Buckley 

Sound Design: Kevin Downing

Dramaturg: Will Johnson 

Promo video shot and edited by: Matt Seger

Poster Design: Chris Patti 

WHY WE NEED MONEY 

We are college students on a budget. Although SUNY Purchase's School of the Arts provides us with the venue and some set pieces, it is our job to get costumes, other props and print posters and programs. 

What our budget covers:

The licensing rights from Dramatist Playwrights Service 

Inexpensive costumes 

Certain props and a couple of set pieces 

Lighting equipment

Printing money for Down the Road posters and programs 

WHAT YOU GET

On the right side of the screen, we have listed different perks for each contribution amount. Some are based around the genre of the show: crime drama...

WHY OUR SHOW MATTERS

Down the Road was published in 1991 and first produced at San Diego's La Jolla Playhouse. It was then presented by the Actors Theatre of Louisville. A couple years later, the infamous Signature Theater Company in Manhattan, New York produced it in a festival of Lee Blessing's works. The New York Times claimed, "This full house of Blessing confirms the diversity of his play writing  and his ability to take a subject of public interest and turn it into provocative drama." The fascination of serial killers has been an ongoing topic, especially in the late 80s, early 90s. Productions about crime can often jump to the obvious and make it creepy, stripping it of any actual depth. Blessing challenges that usual issue by writing about Dan and Iris questioning the ethics of what they are doing. They begin to realize that glorifying a serial killer is nothing more than popular entertainment in the media. 

RISKS AND CHALLENGES 

This is more of a risk for us than it is for you. We need to ensure that we respect the playwright's work and convey it in the best possible way. With good costumes, proper lighting equipment, a striking set, and intriguing sound design, we truly believe we can bring this show to life in the way that it deserves. Whether or not we make our goal, the show will go on, but with your help we can surpass any financial road blocks and go on to create a compelling production!

story:
Hello, my name is Victoria Bourne and I am the artistic director of the Bristol based production company And Then We Danced. We aim to inspire people of all backgrounds to experience and participate in music, whether engaging them with live performances of original music theatre or providing them with access to workshops, choirs and individual tuition.

Our campaign is to raise funds to help us take our show 'Rouse Ye Women' to the Edinburgh Fringe Festival in 2013. We have already been successfully offered a performance slot and are fully registered for the fringe as part of C venues in C venue Aquila on the Royal Mile. Performing from the 1-17th August at 7.50pm.

C venues

Roman Eagle Lodge 

Johnston Terrace/Royal Mile

EH1 2PW

 We need your help getting there by supporting our campaign to raise funds for production expenses.

Rouse Ye Women’ tells the story of the chain-making women from the Black Country once known as the ʻwhite slaves of Englandʼ. Small chains - known as 'hand-hammered' or 'country-work' chains - were often hand-worked by women or children in small cramped forges in outbuildings next to their homes. An example of the 'sweated trade', the work was hot, physically demanding and very poorly paid. In 1910, after a ten week strike, the women won a landmark victory that established the first minimum wage in this country.

Our interpretation of this dramatic story is an enthralling and surprising piece of music theatre and takes its name from the principle song - ʻRouse ye Womenʼ. The story is being told through a mix of music, movement and lyrics with female singers simultaneously playing metallic percussion to create an appropriate sonic landscape for the story. 

What We Need & What You Get

Each performer is paying for his/her own travel, food and lodging expenses, and as a group, the performers are committed to a wide variety of fundraising activities in an effort to secure the necessary financial support. 

Donations will go to renting the theater space, costumes, set design, shipping of set, press and marketing (Flyers and posters).

Additionally you can see our "perks" listed to the side in consideration for your generous support. Perks include signed postcards, tickets to our show and you have the opportunity to come and see the company rehearsing at our Bristol based headquarters.

If we don't reach our entire goal the funds will contribute in a smaller part to each of the items listed above. 

The Impact

Your donations will help us:
- To draw attention to a highly significant and inspiring historic event by using the power and appeal of music and dance to inform, educate and inspire.   
- To develop the skills of individuals and a distinctive theatrical style for the collective group/production company - 'And Then We Danced'. 
- To develop and perform an innovative, stimulating and original piece of music theatre.
- To maximise community engagement within an artistic and dramatic production.

Company Track Record

We have a successful track record of performing original theatre and music including at the Tete a Tete Opera Festival 2012 in London, Thornbury Arts Festival 2013 and the Black Country Living Museum in the Midlands 2012. We won the University of Bristol’s Vice Chancellor’s award in 2012.

 Here is an example of reviews, audience and professional feedback:

'An original interpretation of such an important moment in British history that has been forgotten by so many'. (Alexandra Hamilton Ayres, Bachtrack, 2013)

Such beautiful angelic voices echoed around this wonderful acoustic setting.Can't spoil it "YOU MUST SEE IT LIVE" hats off to all the cast including backstage heroes. (Audience Member Brian Roseblade, 2013)

I think it's superb. Very intelligent, effective and moving. It all fit's together beautifully. (Knud Stuwe Composer and Musician, 2012)

I very much enjoyed our outing to the Riverside Studios this afternoon. Chainmakers told an an impressive story about an important part of our history very well. Please allow an amateur to say that the singing was beautiful'. (Eric Taylor, Vice Chancellor University of Bristol, 2012)

All members of the company have a variety of theatre/music and film experience, links to biographies are available on our company website. http://www.andthenwedanced.com

Other Ways You Can Help

We cannot do this without the support of our friends and family. Please help enable us to take this uplifting story to the international stage. 

We appreciate any and all support you are able to give us. If you are not able to donate to our project in the way of monetary funds, please do what you can by sharing this Indiegogo campaign with everyone you know. Post it on your Facebook page, send out a tweet, a carrier pigeon, alert the local press, stand on a soap box, send out your best smoke signals, and let the world know all about us.

Cast

Victoria Bourne

Yasmin Frampton

Carmen Gabriele

Laura Ollerton

Jasmine Smart

 

Musical Director

Chris Harper http://www.chrisharpersmusic.com

Movement Director

Anna Croxson http://bathspa.academia.edu/ACroxson

Artistic Director 

Victoria Bourne http://www.victoriabourne.com

story:
Support OWLS (Outreach With Lacrosse & Schools), a Chicago-based volunteer organization dedicated to starting transformative lacrosse programs for inner-city schools and communities. OWLS has a dynamic, sustainable approach to sport development for at-risk inner-city youth based on:

● Teambuilding

● Healthy lifestyles

● Academic achievement

Sam Angelotta, Founder and Program Director for OWLS is leading the effort to improve and expand our programming to reach more inner-city kids. Originally from Ohio, he is a graduate and lacrosse alum of Indiana University and DePaul University. Following graduation from Indiana, he went on to coach, teach, and play lacrosse in Manchester, England as a Local Development Officer for the English Lacrosse Association. During his time there he helped organize and develop programs for schools in Manchester, as well as a local club team. Following the completion of the program he earned his Masters in Elementary Education from DePaul University. During this period of hands-on research in Chicago schools he established the OWLS organization as a response to the need for quality after-school/healthy lifestyle programs for at-risk youth. The pilot program for OWLS was launched two years ago at St. Malachy School (West Side, Chicago) where he currently works as a full-time elementary teacher, coach, and program director.  

Over the last two years, hundreds of our student-athletes have experienced quality lacrosse instruction, courses in team-building, and first hand exposure to top-tier high schools and universities.

Our School-2-School Initiative has successfully connected established high school and college lacrosse programs with OWLS inner city school sites. This initiative has helped our boys and girls gain exposure to top-level programs through sport and academic enrichment. Through School-2-School we have been able to connect with elite NCAA programs in the country, including Northwestern University Women’s Lacrosse and University of Notre Dame Men’s Lacrosse, and local teams, including St. Ignatius College Prep, Loyola Academy, New Trier High School, Naperville North HS, Whitney Young HS, Neaqua Valley HS, and Benet Academy.


Our success has created demand for OWLS in more inner-city schools. We are currently improving four school-based OWLS Inner-City Development Projects:

● St. Anns School

● St. Malachy School

● Chicago Jesuit Academy

● John Marshall Metropolitan High School

These new programs will be the foundation for our vision of an Urban Scholastic Lacrosse League (USLL), scheduled for launch this spring. As all of our students play for FREE, we are seeking to raise $15,000 to support this vision. We are asking the greater community to help this holiday season.

From December 18th to February 5th we will be featuring a fundraising video highlighting our recent lacrosse development projects through the OWLS School-2-School Program. This short video will give you an exclusive look into our program and the student-athletes that make it thrive. Give the gift of lacrosse this season, help us build inner-city student-athletes!

Where will the $15,000 Go?

To give you a sense of our programming costs here's a breakdown:

$25 provides insurance and US Lacrosse membership (Lacrosse Magazine subscription) for one student

$50 provides uniform, shorts, and supplemental equipment (mouthguard, cup, water bottle etc.) for one student.

$100 provides team bus transportation for one event/game

$250 provides lacrosse equipment for one student

$500 allows one participant to attend summer camp

$1,000 provides uniforms for one team or coaching stipends for one team

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot donate today, there are other ways to get involved. Help us by spreading the word of our mission through social media, share the link to our video with your friends, or volunteer for an upcoming OWLS event! 

Thank you for your support, help us take our inner-city student athletes to the next level!

Yours in Lacrosse,

The OWLS Team

story:
Our Story

Hi, my name is Marlo Berberian. I am the treasurer of Denver School of the Art's Thespian Officer Board. Denver School of the Arts is a magnet middle and high school that specializes in enriching kid's passions for the arts. We have ten majors including: theatre, dance, band, orchestra, guitar, piano, visual arts, cinema, tech, and creative writing. The thespian society is an international high school honors society focusing on all things related to theatre. This year, we have had more national qualifiers than ever before. This is a huge triumph for our school because it gives kids from all majors the opportunity to perform in front of an international audience and connect with theatre lovers from all over the world. The only problem is we don't have sufficient funds to get there. In order to perform at nationals we need to raise $5000 dollars. It would be such a blessing if we could pay for transportation to and from nationals for our entire troupe.


The Impact

If we are able to get to nationals our students will not only be able to watch and learn by seeing performances from all over the nation, but they will also have the chance to audition for several colleges and scholarships. Because colleges from all over the US attend nationals, students who would usually not have the opportunity to visit and audition for schools outside of the state can and earn scholarships. If we can't get to nationals this incredible experience would not be possible. Students could not audition for their colleges of choice or get to perform and receive feedback from theatre aficionados from all over the country.


What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise $5000 in order to have full transportation to and from nationals. It is about $2500 each way. If this goal is met we will be able to safely get to nationals without having to put stress on families to drive their children for 10-12 hours each way. If our goal is not met, whatever we have will go into the transportation budget and we will request a small check from each family to contribute towards the bus. Asking for a small check of $25 is a lot less than asking for $200 which most of our families can't afford. Any donation would help us come closer to our goal and towards an exciting and educational trip.


Other Ways You Can Help

Spread the word! Tell everyone you know about our campaign and tell them to check us out at http://dsathespians.yolasite.com/ for further information.

story:
Our Story

Outreach Through Dance's "Dance For A Wish" showcase will raise funds to sponsor wishes for children of the Make-A-Wish Foundation, San Diego Chapter. Each choreographer displays a themed medley artistically conveying what is in their hearts, while simultaneously instilling a sense of inspiration throughout our community. These medleys provide as a channel for the audience, the dance community, and our adopted wish child to be a part of an unforgettable and powerful experience. We believe in preserving the arts, raising awareness, and providing positive role models for the community. "Dance For A Wish" is a one-day event consisting of 2 shows. We rent a theater and invite highly respected choreographers to produce works specifically created for this show. All artists, dancers, and staff volunteer their time and energy in hope to pursue a goal; to benefit and touch the lives of others.


The Impact

Your support will allow us to produce “Dance For A Wish”, an event that will raise funds to grant a child’s wish from The Make-A-Wish Foundation, San Diego Chapter.  All volunteers, performers, audience members and OTD supporters that contribute their time and monetary support will be a part of this wish child’s day. “Dance For A Wish” is one day that will make our wish child’s life.


What We Need

$3525 - Theater rental (includes sound technician, space use for technical rehearsals and day of show)

$450 – Lighting designer/technician

$525 – One Day Event Insurance

$500 - Promotion (flyer and poster printing, graphic design, marketing)


Check out the different perks you receive when you contribute to our cause! Thank you for supporting OTD! Your reach is limitless.

poster printing, graphic design, marketing)

Check out the different perks you receive when you contribute to our cause! Thank you for supporting OTD! Your reach is limitless.

story:
Thanks to all your generous support we’ve not only raised our goal but completed our push goals as well! We’ve decided to see if we can make it to one more goal before the end of the campaign.

If we can raise an additional 200 pounds above our current amount we can take a research trip to Malta.

During this trip we will not only be able to rehearse and live together as a company, focusing completely on the work, but also to meet with some NGOs and artists who work with the refugees that often land in Malta. In addition we might be able to provide workshops for migrants and NGO staff. This would be great opportunity for research, rehearsal and networking which will better the final product!

                                  -              -              -

Thank you for all of your generous support! We can't believe we're so close to our goal already, and it's all thanks to your help. Because of all the support you are giving us, we've decided to add some extra goals to the project, to try and improve the quality of our show:

If we can raise an additional 200 pounds above our initial goal we can afford better costumes, set and prop pieces.

At the moment, we’re calculating with the bare minimum, and while poverty can be a virtue on stage, being able to afford higher quality material will definitely benefit the overall appearance and character of the show. 

If we can raise another 100 pounds above our initial goal, we can expand our marketing campaign.

Marketing is always a large post in budgeting – for this production, we again calculated very little for marketing, as we prioritised production costs, but with your help, we can create a three step marketing campaign with more and higher quality material, which will help us to bring our show to a larger audience.


We hide under the boat at the shore. Until they are all gone, until the fire is out, we hide, and then we go. "We go in the boat." Can't you hear it? She is calling us. The sea is calling us.

We are Lost Goose Theatre Company, and we need your help! We’re a physical theatre company, and we’re looking to tour our new show HAVARIE to Ireland, Denmark, and Malta this summer. The company is comprised of four women from four different countries, who met during the St. Mary’s University MA in Physical Theatre Programme: Marie, from Denmark, Mona, from Germany, Louise, from Ireland, and Hannah, from Canada. We are a truly international ensemble, looking to spread our work internationally! So here’s how you can help:


What We Need & What You Get:

We need funding in order to make our tour a reality. Every little bit helps, but here’s a list of our funding goals:

-  Raising £100 will cover the admissions cost to the Galway Fringe Festival

-  If we can raise another £350 we can cover our travel expenses to Denmark.

-  Another £400 we can cover our travel expenses to Malta.

-  The final £150 will cover our production costs while abroad.

In return, we have a whole list of great rewards just for you! From a thank you on our website, to the opportunity to have the Lost Goose Theatre Company perform a personal workshop for you and your friends, all the details are on the sidebar.

Remember! No contribution is too small: If we don’t make our full goal, all of the funds still go to the company. And we can use those funds for the benefit of our production.

The Touring Schedule:

With your help and contributions, this is where we hope to be this summer:

-  Opening night at the Tristan Bates Theatre in London, June 2014.

-  Playing at the Galway Fringe Festival in Ireland, July 2014.

-  Touring theatres and festivals in Denmark, August 2014.

-  Touring theatres and schools in Malta, September 2014.

-  Finishing our tour with a final show at St. Mary’s University, Late September 2014.

Other Ways You Can Help:

If you can’t contribute to the campaign through donations, don’t worry! You can help us out by spreading the word; you can use the Indiegogo share tools to share our campaign with your friends and family, or you can join our Facebook page.

But the biggest way you can help is by coming to see our shows. We will continue to update all supporters and members of our Facebook page about where and when the shows will be playing, once the details of the tour become more solidified.

story:
GutShot Productions are presenting Chris MacDonald's debut play Eye of a Needle at the Southwark Playhouse for a four week run from 27th August until 20th September.

THE PLAY

Set in the offices of an immigration detention centre, the play exposes the cruel absurdities of a system in which gay asylum seekers have to prove their sexuality in order to gain admittance to the UK. We see the individuals trying to stay afloat in a department struggling against the weight of political and media pressure, a lack of resources and outdated guidelines. The play examines the human aspect of the great immigration question: How do you decide who deserves to stay and who deserves to go?

Chris was inspired to write the play by the case of Brenda Namigadde in 2011. In light of the gang-murder of David Kato, a prominent gay rights campaigner in Uganda, she claimed that if she were sent back to Uganda she would be killed. The UK Border Agency said that she didn’t have enough ‘physical evidence’ of her sexuality and thus had to be sent home. Chris embarked on a long period of research, speaking to case workers, lawyers and trawling through cases. The deeper he dug into the issue, the crueler and more ridiculous it seemed. When more news stories emerged about how ‘shockingly degrading’ the questions gay asylum seekers were asked - for example, 'What is it you like about men's backsides?' -  it seemed a pertinent time to present the piece. 

The play has been developed with Sam Potter (currently creative associate of Headlong Theatre) as part of her work with Out of Joint and was longlisted for the Bruntwood prize.

WHO WE ARE

GutShot are a new theatre company set up by Chris MacDonald to present his debut play. 

Chris is an actor and writer from London. He trained at Drama Centre following a degree in English at Nottingham University. This is Chris’ first full-length play. His shorts have been performed at Theatre 503, Yvonne Arnaud and the Bush Theatre. He has written and directed two short films, one of which has played at International Film Festivals in the USA and Europe. As an actor he has worked for the RSC, Propellor and throughout the country in various touring productions.

Holly Race Roughan directs, credits include  Pages from my Songbook (Manchester Royal Exchange, nominated for ‘Best Performance’ - Manchester Theatre Awards), Believers Anonymous (4 Stars Time Out Critics Choice) and as assistant, Hotel by Polly Stenham at the National Theatre and The Pass by John Donnely at the Royal Court.

Ine Van Riet, former resident producer at Tara Arts and now part of the Development team at the Bush Theatre produces, following her success with Mucky Kid by Sam Potter at Theatre 503.

WHERE YOU COME IN

The project has received a Grant from the Arts Council, almost unprecedented for a new company. We now need your help to bring us to the finish line so that we can realise the vision we have for this epic piece.

All of us at GutShot know what it's like to work hard for little pay, which is why we are committed to paying our actors and creative team properly for this project and a huge chunk of our budget will be spent on this. We also believe that this piece needs an ambitious and ingenious set and we want to create the best working atmosphere we can in rehearsals. This subject matter and story is too important toto us to be compromised and so we need your support.

story:
American Classics, Served Fresh

Bob Dylan? Check. Allen Ginsberg? Check. David Mamet, Flannery O’Connor, The Ronettes, Charles Schulz, Rod Serling, Strunk & White, August Wilson, & Warren Zevon? Check - all down the line.

In two years and twenty-seven unique productions, First Person Singular has presented the American voice at its most compelling and essential. Character plus language equals voice, and it’s our mission to provide a routine reckoning with the glorious and terrifying noise this nation has made. 

We serve the voices that define us. And now it’s time to speak for ourselves.

Ahem

On December 3rd, 2012, First Person Singular will present it’s first program of original material: Hear Me Now: Cell Phone Monologues. We’re going to take the unsolicited public theater you witness on a daily basis, and put it in a proper context. 

We’re calling on the strongest writer-performers of the Bay Area to demonstrate what this relatively new form of exhibitionism can inadvertently, and entertainingly, reveal.

Our Cast:

Trevor Allen, playwright and solo theater performer (49 Miles; The Creature; Working for the Mouse)

Kim Addonizio, poet & novelist (Jimmy & Rita; Lucifer at the Starlite; Tell Me)

Alicia Dattner, comedian & solo theater writer-performer (Eat, Pray, Laugh; The Punchline; The Oy of Sex)

Marga Gomez, comedian (HBO; Showtime) & solo theater writer-performer (Long Island Iced Latina; Marga Gomez is Pretty, Witty & Gay; Not Getting Any Younger)

Christopher Kuckenbaker, actor & playwright (The Burroughs and Kookie Show)

Eddie Muller, writer (The Distance; Grindhouse; Dark City: The Lost World of Film Noir), founder of The Film Noir Foundation and The Noir City Film Festival

April Sinclair, novelist (I Left My Back Door Open; Coffee Will Make You Black; Ain't Gonna Be the Same Fool Twice)

Note: IanShoales (Merle Kessler), writer, humorist (NPR's All Things Considered; Morning Edition; ABC's Nightline), & founding member of Duck's Breath Mystery Theater, was part of our original lineup, but he is recuperating from a recent traffic mishap. We wish him a speedy recovery.

How You Can Help

Our costs for the production are more than twice what ticket revenue can cover. This is a one-night-only performance, and we’re asking a host of top talent to both write and perform original material for it. We’re also commissioning a series of ringtone-based musical interstitials from pianist Joshua Raoul Brody. We have a stage manager and co-director whom we’d like to offer more than dinner. In addition, we have printing costs for posters, programs, and scripts. But ninety percent of your contributions will help pay artists. 

We want our first original program to stand with the work that has come before it. So, we’re going for broke.

This campaign goes live on Thanksgiving (our favorite holiday) for a twelve-day funding blitz. Our goal is modest, and tailored to this production, but the future of the series would greatly benefit from contributions above our stated goal.

If you're unable to contribute, you can also help us by spreading the word about this campaign via Facebook, Twitter, or email. And it would mean the world to us if you bought a ticket to the show: 

http://www.shotgunplayers.org/2012_cabaret_fps6.htm

Thanks for picking up!

Joe Christiano

First Person Singular

Please visit us at www.1stpersonsingular.com

Our Bio

Premiered in August 2010, First Person Singular is a dramatic reading series "that means to redefine not only the literary event but the literary as such"  --Greil Marcus, The Believer. Bringing dynamic performers to timeless material in original programs, the series places special emphasis on the richness, variety, and vitality of the American voice. From August Wilson to Warren Zevon, from a 60's girl-group song recital to an all-female reading of Glengarry Glen Ross, First Person Singular showcases the best of our culture in unique and unexpected ways. The series has been presented by Pegasus Books, The Museum of the African Diaspora, The Shotgun Players, and Litquake. First Person Singular was recently honored with an Outstanding Event Award from the Northern California Independent Booksellers Association, and a Best of the East Bay award from The East Bay Express: "Best Remixed Literary Event."

story:
What is Topsy-Turvy!?

Topsy-Turvy is a labor of love for us (India Davis & Indi McCasey). We wanted to see something that we had never seen before: an explicitely all-queer circus performance that highlighted circus artists of color and created safe space for trans and gender variant performers. We also wanted to connect queers to the magic of circus and ultimately to each other.

With this in mind we created Topsy-Turvy, a one-of-a-kind performance that will spin your world upside-down! As part of the 2013 National Queer Arts Festival, Topsy-Turvy reinvents circus arts with acts that defy traditional ideals of strength and beauty, integrate multiple disciplines of dance and performance, and tell a distinctly queer narrative.

Topsy-Turvy will feature circus artists from New York, Colorado, New Mexico, Vermont, Portland, and the Bay Area performing circus disciplines including trapeze, lyra, stilts, acro, juggling, and more!

Why are we asking for money?

In order to bring circus artists from across the country to the Bay Area, these performers have had to dig into their own pockets to front travel costs. Additionally, circus is an artform that can require long hours of training and expensive gear. We want to fully appreciate the time and energy these artists have put into creating their acts and that's why we're asking for support from our community.

With $2,500 we will pay a portion of travel expenses for out-of-town artists as well as contribute to the general pot for performers. The more that we raise, the more we can give back to these incredible artists!

 

Other Ways To Show Your Support!

SEE THE SHOW!

Saturday June 22nd at the Brava Theater in San Francisco! (That's the week before SF Pride in case you're wondering)

SPREAD THE WORD!

Support this project by sharing this campaign on your Facebook page, getting the word out, and bringing friends to the show!

JOIN THE CIRCUS!

If you want to be part of the magic of the circus, please consider volunteering at the shows on Saturday June 22nd. Email topsyturvyqueercircus@gmail to volunteer.

We love you!

India Davis & Indi McCasey

story:
What this campaign is for:

Operation Pedro Pan was an unprecedented mass exodus of 14,000 unaccompanied Cuban children to the United States. Some were able to stay with family and friends, others were placed with foster families or grew up in orphanages. While many of these Pedro Pan Kids were eventually reunited with their parents, the increasing tensions between Cuba and the United States kept some families apart indefinitely.

Cuban-American playwright Nilo Cruz, who won the Pulitzer Prize for Anna in the Tropics, dramatizes this chapter of Cuban/American history in Hortensia and the Museum of Dreams.  Set during the Pope’s visits to Cuba, the play is about two Pedro Pan Siblings who return to their native country to rediscover their heritage. Rather than focusing on politics, this lyrical play celebrates Cuban folklore and shows what happens when the melodies of childhood interweave with rhythms of reality to create songs of hope and forgiveness.

How your contributions will help:

In addition to bringing this unique story to the stage, the funds raised by this campaign would also facilitate a work-shop geared at documenting the experience of individuals that lived through Operation Pedro Pan. Using a technique pioneered by Bill Rauch, the founding artistic director of Cornerstone Theatre, actors would interview “grown children of Pedro Pan,” and then turn those interviews into monologues. These monologues will then be presented to the public as part of a Cuban American Festival surrounding this production of Hortensia and the Museum of Dreams.

Who we are:

CASA 0101 Theatre was founded in 2000 by Josefina Lopez, author and playwright of "Real Women Have Curves". The theatre was established as a means of fulfilling Josefina's vision to providing vital arts, cultural, and educational programs to her home town community of Boyle Heights.  From humble beginnings operating out of a converted store front, CASA 0101 theatre has earned a reputation as a leading arts venue in Los Angeles. With a core mission of nurturing the future storytellers of Los Angeles, CASA 0101 believes the contributions of their artists will one day transform the world.

story:
Continuing a legacy...

Wings of Spring 2013 presents “The Sounds of Spring,” a site-specific dance concert on Ithaca College’s campus.  The performance features students from all areas of the school; from producers to dancers to visual artists to musicians, this year’s presentation is the largest Wings of Spring production yet.  For the first time, the performance is leaving the confines of Dillingham and blossoming out into the larger campus, engaging with and empowering the college community to embrace the newness of spring.  

As with any live event, we need funding.  Our fundraising efforts will go on to support a variety of necessities ranging props to costumes to marketing expenses; the funding also lays the groundwork for next year’s Wings of Spring presentation, solidifying the performance as an immovable entity at Ithaca College.  Your generosity will enable us to continue to build the performance, integrating more of the college community into this annual event.  Together, we can continue to bring live performance to all places, advancing art and enhancing the overall Ithaca College experience for all people.  

For more information, visit icwingsofspring.com or connect with us on Facebook and Twitter.  We look forward to seeing you at “The Sounds of Spring” next month!

story:
Short Summary

The Mechanical is an original post-apocalyptic musical following the journey of a humanoid robot as he ventures onto the surface of the earth for the very first time. What does he find there? Well, we could tell you, but that wouldn't be very fun, would it? Follow our journey and maybe you'll find out! 

The Mechanical is co-written by Marcus Bagala, Megan Dorn, and Kelsey Hercs. Marcus is a recent graduate of The Berklee College of Music, and Megan and Kelsey are recent graduates of The Boston Conservatory of Music. Since its conception, the show has undergone major surgery - characters were added and taken away, scenes were cut, edited and re-written, and readings were held. But we need your help taking the show from the page to the stage. 

Our first scheduled performance will be at the 2013 PortFringe Festival, happening this June. We are relying on your contributions to bring our show to life! 

First clips from The Mechanical!

https://soundcloud.com/mbagala/the-mechanical-i-measure-love

What We Need & What You Get

We need to raise 3,500 dollars in order to bring our show to life. Here are some examples of where your money will go:

* Your money might help us rent a rehearsal space for the day.

* You could help costume the show!

* Your money might even go towards transporting our entire cast and crew from their various locations around the country to Portland, Me, and housing them for the week! 

We appreciate your donations, and we'd like to offer some incentives to help you follow our show from conception to staging.

* If you donate $25, we'll send you a signed copy of the program from our first rehearsal.

* Donate $50 dollars, and we will thank you as an honorable mention in our program, as well as send you a signed copy. 

* Check out our other incentives, but don't hestitate to donate! There are 6 characters that could have your name! If you donate $300, we will name a character in our show after you! Don't wait, there are only 6 opportunities to get your name in our show! 

The Impact

Your contributions will make all the difference in the world. Every donation to our campaign, no matter the size helps us mount the world premiere of this brand new, hauntingly beautiful musical. We hope that the success we have at the fringe festival will propel us to other festivals, performances, and opportunities. 

We can't thank you enough for donating to our campaign. With every dollar, our production becomes more and more of a reality. We hope that you will follow our journey and follow the journey of The Mechanical. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand if you are unable to contribute at this time, but there are other ways to help our campaign.

* Make some noise! Talk about us on facebook, e-mail your friends and family, and help us get the word our there!

* Use the Indiegogo share tools to share us with your friends and family! 

 

Thank you so much!

story:
Who We Are

  • We are a group of McGill students and graduates.

  • We have all been involved with a variety of different musical theatre productions in Montreal and now we would love the chance to start our own company with this very special show.

  • We love what The Last Five Years has to say about love and desire and regret. But we need you to help us bring it to life.

What We Need & What You Get

  •  In order to see The Last Five Years happen and for us to "break even," we need $1200. But we don't expect all of that from you.

  • This $500 campaign will help us to pay for our production budget and our deposit for renting the theatre.
  • With every donation, you are helping us to pay for a costume, a set piece, or to turn on a light.
  • And for every $20, $100, or $200 you give to us, we'll give something back to you. Check out our perks section for more info!

The Impact

  • With this project, we can bring more anglophone musical theatre to Montreal.
  • The Last Five Years will be the very first show for Classic Productions. We hope this is just the beginning.
  • Your donation will help young artists and new art.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word about our campaign to other arts supporters you know.

  •  Be on the look-out for information about our in-person fundraisers.

  • Be a part of the audience!

Thank you for your support! See you at Players' Theatre on April 19 and 20.
